—Petitions have been lodged for presentation as follows:

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the President and senators in Parliament assembled, your humble petitioners showeth that the proposed Australia Card will have a dramatic impact on the lives of all Australians, and your petitioners therefore request a national referendum on the Australia Card Bill before the proposal is resubmitted to Parliament.
As in duty bound your petitioners will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Archer (from 119 citizens), Bishop (from 20 citizens) and Jones (from 27 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.

This petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that we strongly oppose the introduction of the ``Australia Card'' or any other form of National Identification Numbering System.

We believe that the introduction of a National Identification Numbering System is not only totally unnecessary but is a severe threat to our civil liberties and privacy. We condemn the Government's actions on this matter, particularly as no reasonable nor responsible justifications for the proposal have been forthcoming from the Government.
We humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should reject any proposal for a National Numbering system.

PETITION.TITLE: Preservation of the Environment
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled: The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

But for a High Court decision narrowly favouring the Federal Government, 20,000 years old archaeological cave sites near the Franklin River, Tasmania, would have been destroyed, like a United Kingdom Government unable to stop a Wiltshire authority from clearing Stonehenge for a freeway. Constitutional protection for historical and environmental assets is needed.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should request the Government to hold a referendum to amend the Constitution so that the Federal Government has the bounden constitutional duty, which any citizen may legally require it to perform and a right superior to state and local governments, to set above the commercial advantage of one generation, protect and restore all we hold in trust for the future-including relics, sites, features, areas, wildlife, buildings or things of Aboriginal and other historical, cultural, architectural, scientific, aesthetic, ecological or environmental importance and-to care for the maintenance of the balance of nature, manage land, marine and atmospheric use so as to avoid their degradation and act nationally and internationally in any matter seen as related to these including-to prevent military and commercial use of uranium and derivatives, beach and related mining; to preserve Heritage Areas, The Great Barrier Reef Region at least as originally defined in the 1975 Act and extended into Torres Strait.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identity Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
that we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Defence Service Home Loans Scheme
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:
1. That changes to the Defence Service Home Loans Scheme will have the effect of reducing existing benefits to Servicemen and Veterans and are therefore to be condemned.
2. That the results of a review of the scheme should be published by the Government.

3. That the Scheme should be amended to increase the amount of the loan, speed up the processing of loans, and widen the eligibility to include all Servicemen by way of recognition of their service to Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Australian National Airlines Act 1945, and for related purposes.
Motion (by Senator Gareth Evans) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I table the explanatory memorandum and I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill relates to a decision announced in the Budget context concerning Australian Airlines' superannuation arrangements.

Australian Airlines is currently the only approved authority under the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme which is exempt from full cost recovery of employer contributions. This situation has been seen by other approved authorities as resulting in inequitable treatment.

The Australian National Airlines Commission will be required to meet the full accruing costs in relation to those of its employees who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. The change has an effective date of 1 July 1987.

From that date the Commission will therefore be treated in the same manner as all other authorities in respect of the employer costs of providing superannuation benefits to employees who are members of the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme.

At present, section 32E of the Australian National Airlines Act 1945 exempts the Commission from the provisions of the Superannuation Acts 1922 and 1976 that require approved authorities to meet the full employer costs of benefits. The section also in effect limits the employer costs in respect of Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme members to level which applies to Australian Airlines' Ground Staff Superannuation Scheme.

The amendments proposed in this Bill will continue the exemption from the relevant provisions of the Superannuation Act 1922 to make it clear that the Commission has no further liability in respect of employees whose service ceased before 1 July 1976. However, the Commission will become liable to meet the full costs accruing from 1 July 1987 in respect of benefits payable under the Superannuation Act 1976.

An actuarial assessment will be made of amounts that will become payable to persons becoming beneficiaries after 30 June 1987 in respect of their service after that date. It will then be determined what fortnightly employer contributions the Commission should make to the Consolidated Revenue Fund that will provide, with an allowance for imputed interest, for those benefits. An arrangement under subsection 159(2d) of the Superannuation Act 1976 will then be entered into whereby the Commission will be required to make the necessary payments.

It is estimated that the Commission's employer contributions will be increased by $4.9 million in 1987/88 as a result of the changes announced. This increased cost was taken into account in setting the ANAC's dividend for 1986/87, which is payable this financial year.

An effective date of the 1 July 1987 is provided for under transitional provisions in the Bill. Action relating to the calculating of the Commission's liability and the entering into of an arrangement for payments will be regarded as having effect from that date. Payments made from 1 July 1987 under the provisions now being omitted will be treated as made under section 159 of the Superannuation Act 1976. It is also made clear that the Commission will not be required to make employer contributions in respect of a period of service before 1 July 1987.
I commend the Bill to honourable senators and present the explanatory memorandum.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Short) agreed to:

That the following Bill be introduced: a Bill for an Act to amend the Flags Act 1953 to ensure that the Australian National Flag is not altered except with the approval of the Australian people voting in a referendum, that the Australian National Flag is not supplanted by use of the powers under the Act, and that the appointment of other flags and ensigns is subject to disallowance by either House of the Parliament.
Motion (by Senator Short) agreed to:
That the Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to incorporate my second reading speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill provides for amendments to the Flags Act 1953 which designates the familiar Blue Ensign as the Australian national flag and empowers the Governor-General to appoint, by proclamation, other flags and ensigns of Australia.

The Bill is identical to that introduced into the Senate in 1984 by Senator Peter Durack. That Bill was passed by the Senate early in 1985. On transmittal to the House of Representatives, however, its progress was thwarted by the Hawke Government and it was not debated.
The double dissolution of the Parliament in June 1987 removed the Bill from the House of Representatives Notice Paper.
The reintroduction of the Bill is designed to rectify that situation.
The purpose of this Bill is to prevent changes to Australia's national flag occurring without the prior consent of the Australian people through a referendum.

The Australian national flag goes to the very heart and soul of our nationhood. It has a particular resonance in the hearts and minds of Australians-it is what helps us in having a sense of ourselves as part of the nation.

We are a young nation, with few national symbols. The Hawke Government early in 1984 abandoned our national anthem, and replaced it with what until then had been a national tune, namely, Advance Australia Fair.
Seventy per cent of the Australian people still do not know the words of the new anthem.
The Government did not make known its intention to replace the previous anthem. There was no public discussion, and accordingly all debate was precluded.
Australia's national flag is too important to the nation's spirit to allow what happened to the anthem to be repeated with the national flag without widespread debate, and public consent.
National symbols provide a people with a sense of their roots, their history. They have a special meaning and significance.
The degree to which national symbols gain meaning and significance among a people is partly derived from their longevity.

Their place in the minds of a people evolve over time. It is the processes of history which breathe life into a nation's symbols, and it is history which provides us with a sense of direction for the future.
Arbitrary replacement of Australia's national flag would seriously weaken our sense of national spirit.
All the available evidence suggests that arbitrary replacement would cause widespread division and deeply felt reverberations for years to come.
The Australian national flag has accumulated great meaning and significance over this century. This is clear when we observe its place in the nation's history.
History

In 1901, the year of Federation, the Barton Government conducted a competition to choose a national flag. 32,822 entries were submitted. The judges decided to divide the prize money of 400 pounds between 5 competitors.

The statement read by the Prime Minister, Edmund Barton, on 3 September 1901 when Australia's national flag flew for the first time-from the Exhibition Building in Melbourne-includes the rationale behind the Judges' decision:
. . . it was apparent (to the judges) that a Commonwealth flag, to be representative, should contain:
The Union Jack on a blue or red ground;

The six pointed `star' representing the six federated States of Australia, immediately under the Union Jack and pointing direct to the centre of St George's Cross, and of a size to occupy the major portion of one quarter of the flag;
The Southern Cross in the flag as being indicative of sentiment of the Australian nation.

In November 1901 the flag, together with another flag which incorporated the Union Jack in the top left hand corner, were submitted to King Edward VII. On 20 February 1903 the King announced his choice of the flag now known as the Australian national flag.

In 1908 a minor alteration was made-a seventh point was added to the Commonwealth star to symbolise the Territory of Papua which had been recently acquired. Over time this seventh point came to represent all of the Commonwealth Territories.
The National Symbol

Attempts to change the flag are attempts to rid ourselves of our British heritage. It is not the star of federation to which supporters of a change to the national flag take umbrage; nor is it the Southern Cross which symbolises our geographical location.
It is the Union Jack that is the target of the attack on the Australian flag, because this symbolises our British heritage.

It is precisely the presence of the Union Jack, however, which symbolises the origins of our institutions that guarantee our freedoms which have been, and still are, the source of much of Australia's greatness.

When we delve into our history it is evident that Australia is extremely fortunate to have been settled by the British, a nation that possessed the best legal and political institutions in the world. Indeed, at that time these institutions were the envy of other nations.
It is not the origin of Australians that the Union Jack is symbolising. Rather, it is the origin of our legal, judicial and political institutions that is symbolised.

British settlement brought with it our Westminster system of government which has served us so well. It has been the engine of political stability and cherished democratic freedoms. It is because of our British heritage that we are not forced to live under arbitrary and despotic rule.
Equality before the law, the right to a fair trial, and the presumption of innocence until proved guilty have been enshrined in the Australian way of life as a result of British settlement.
All Australians, be they of British, European, Middle Eastern, Russian, American or Asian ancestry can feel pride in Australia's national flag.

The guarantee of freedoms and rights under these political, legal and judicial institutions have been fostered and nurtured by successive generations of Australians. They have formed the basis of Australia's attraction for Australia's old and new immigrants.

For those who have fled the arbitrary harshness and brutality of totalitarian and despotic regimes and those who come here to enjoy the opportunities and freedoms Australia offers, the Australian national flag is their symbol.
Its symbolic significance has not been restricted to Australians of British origin.
Popular acceptance of the flag gained momentum during both world wars when governments encouraged citizens to fly the flag over their homes, offices and factories.
The depth of feeling for the flag is beautifully described in a passage of Mr Frank Cayley's book, Flag of Stars:
The first Allied flag raised in Singapore after the Japanese surrender in 1945 was an Australian Ensign that had been made in secret by Australian prisoners of war.

A small Union Jack, which had escaped discovery during the many searches made by the Japanese guards, was stretched on to the corner of some blue material `borrowed' from Japanese stores; handkerchiefs from Red Cross parcels provided the necessary white for the Commonwealth star and the stars of the southern Cross-and the flag was in readiness when news was heard by secret radio that Japanese surrender was imminent. When surrender came, the flag was raised over `X3' working camp at Bukit Panjang and later over AIF headquarters at Changi.
Widespread acceptance of the national flag as our national symbol and standard has not been restricted to times of national crisis such as war.
At the Olympic Games, regardless of where they have been held, Australian athletes and spectators have inevitably reached for the Australian flag to vent their pride.
It is telling that at the closing ceremony of the last Olympics, Australian competitors broke ranks to circumnavigate the Los Angeles Coliseum carrying a giant Australian flag.
Results of contemporary national opinion polls continue to register popular support. Most people do not want a change in their national flag.
The Bill
The Bill seeks to strengthen and reinforce the flag as the symbol and standard of the Commonwealth of Australia, the Government and our nation.
These changes are necessary because as things stand any government can change the national flag virtually by executive fiat.
That the Hawke Government has on its agenda replacement of the national flag is evident from the Labor Party's 1986 policy platform:

In the context of the preparations or bicentennial celebrations, to initiate and support moves to establish with popular acceptance an Australian flag, national day and national anthem which will more distinctly reflect our national independence and identity.
It is clear that members of the Labor Party do not understand the importance of national symbols.
In 1985 the present Government provided funds for the campaign to change the national flag which went under the title of the Ausflag 88 campaign. The machinations of that campaign are instructive.
They teach us two lessons.

First, attempts to change the national flag will inevitably be divisive. The Ausflag saga aroused widespread controversy and heated debate culminating in the Labor Party backing down when the polls showed clearly that Australians did not want their flag replaced.

Second, there is no alternative flag which can command widespread support. The Ausflag Committee itself was engaged in bitter internal wrangling and could not decide upon the winning entry. Even this small group could not settle upon a single replacement and the Committee was split in its final decision.

That the present Government has done an about face on this issue is cold comfort. It is not because it understands the importance of national symbols, nor is it because it is no longer hostile to what the flag represents.
It is simply a matter of pragmatism. When the opportunity arises then will be the time to strike, no doubt in a similar fashion to the technique used to replace the national anthem.
A government which implements policies concerning the nation's cherished symbols solely on the basis of pragmatic and opportunistic considerations cannot be trusted.
Any change to the Australian national flag without the endorsement of the people will constitute a loss in our sense of nationhood.

Fortunately, the flag is prescribed by the Flags Act 1953 whereby the flag designated the `Australian national flag' can only be changed by legislation. However, the Act allows the Governor-General to `appoint such other flags and ensigns of Australia as he thinks fit'.

Without consulting the people, therefore, the Government may advise the Governor-General to appoint other flags to replace the Australian national flag for specific national purposes. A different flag can be appointed as the flag flown at the Olympic Games, at the United Nations, or above government institutions.
If sufficient `other flags or ensigns' were appointed the Australian national flag would be effectively replaced or undermined as the symbol of our nation.
Accordingly, the Bill will effect the following changes:
1. `Other flags or ensigns' to be appointed by the Governor-General by regulation, not proclamation, so that the Parliament has an opportunity for review.

2. Prohibition of the appointment, upon the advice of the government, of `other flags or ensigns' as the standard for the Commonwealth of Australia, the government of the Commonwealth of Australia or of the Australian nation.
3. Referendum provision so that the Australian flag may not be altered or changed without a referendum on the matter.
This Bill will avert any such attempts either to downgrade or replace the Australian national flag because it will ensure that any changes to the national flag must have the support of the people.
Hopefully these amendments will guarantee that the flag continues to fly proudly over Australia as the symbol and standard of this country and its people.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Gareth Evans) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALKER.NAME: Senator GARETH EVANS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Transport and Communications)

TALK.START.PARA: - I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows -
BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984.

The three Acts constitute the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Scheme. This scheme provides partial compensation to refiners for the cost of transport by sea or pipeline of allocated crude oil (Bass Strait crude oil purchased at Western Port in those volumes and at the import parity price determined by the Government) to their refineries for processing. The amount of compensation is based on the actual transport cost incurred by refiners in transporting their allocated oil from Western Port to their refinery.

While the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act falls within the portfolio responsibility of my colleague, the Minister for Industry Technology and Commerce, I shall also address the proposed amendment to that Act which is contained in this package of Bills.

Under the existing marketing arrangements, refiners are subject to the requirements of the crude oil allocation scheme, under which they are obliged to lift over a calender year an average of 350 000 barrels a day of crude oil from Bass Strait and the total production of crude oil from other producing areas, excluding Jabiru. Each refiner is required to purchase a share of the total allocation obligations, with the share determined according to its market share of sales of specified petroleum products. Crude oil purchases are made at the prevailing import parity price for the relevant producing area.

As announced on 21 June 1987 by the then Minister for Resources and Energy, Senator Evans, the Allocation Scheme will terminate on 31 December 1987 and be replaced by deregulated marketing arrangements from 1 January 1988.

However it is possible that a number of refiners may not have lifted their share of 350 000 barrels per day-the 1987 target for Bass Strait crude oil-by 31 December 1987 and it is therefore necessary to implement some transition arrangements to ensure equity between all refiners.

Refiners who are underlifted against their Bass Strait allocation obligations on 1 January 1988 will need to clear their underlift in 1988 before being permitted to purchase Bass Strait crude oil on the free market.

This Bill provides for the continuation into 1988 of the collection of the Bass Strait coastal freight adjustment levy, at the same rate that will apply during December 1987. This levy, which is paid by producers, will only apply to liftings by refiners that have not met their allocation obligations and until such time as these obligations have been met.

The Bill also provides for the Minister to set a nil rate of levy. This rate would be set after all refiners have met their liftings obligations and thus effectively terminate the scheme. Amendments to the other Bills in this package remove the liability from the producers to pay the levy on exports and free market sales after 1 January 1988, and for the disbursement of the funds in the Freight Adjustment Trust Fund that have been collected under these arrangements.
It is envisaged that the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act and the other two associated Acts will be repealed in 1988, following finalisation of all outstanding payments.
The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT LEVY COLLECTION AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The principal purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from the current Allocation Scheme to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984. The amendments in this Bill are consequential on those to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill, the purposes of which I have previously addressed in relation to that Bill.

The amendment contained in this Bill will remove the liability on the Bass Strait producers to pay the Bass Strait freight adjustment levy on all exports and free market sales of crude oil made on or after 1 January 1988.
The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
BASS STRAIT FREIGHT ADJUSTMENT TRUST FUND AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Trust Fund Act 1984 to enable the implementation of transitional arrangements for the marketing of Australian produced crude oil from a regulated to a deregulated or free market. The Bill is part of a package of measures which includes amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act 1984 and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Act 1984. The amendments in this Bill are consequential to those of the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Amendment Bill and the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Amendment Bill, the purposes of which I have previously addressed in relation to those Bills.

The amendments contained in clauses 4 and 6 of this Bill, in conjunction with the proposed amendments to the Bass Strait Freight Adjustment Levy Collection Act, provide a mechanism by which the Bass Strait producers will be deemed to have paid the levy on free market sales, including exports made on or after 1 January 1988.
Clause 4 provides that where such amounts are deemed to have been collected then they are also deemed to have been paid into the Freight Adjustment Fund.

The amendments contained in clause 6 of this Bill will allow disbursements from the Trust Fund to be made at the end of January 1988 to the Bass Strait producers on the basis of their exports and domestic free market sales during December 1987 and to those refiners that exported allocation sales of Bass Strait crude oil. Disbursements from the Trust Fund to refiners, on the basis of their purchases of allocation sales of Bass Strait crude oil, will be deferred until all refiners have met their 1987 Bass Strait allocation obligations. At that stage, the Minister shall set a nil rate of levy to apply to future sales of Bass Strait crude oil-which will effectively terminate the coastal freight adjustment scheme.

The base period for the calculation of these disbursements from the Trust Fund to eligible refiners will be extended from 1 July 1987 to the month in which this nil levy rate is set, in accordance with clause 3, while the amounts paid to refiners will be made in accordance with the provisions of the new sections 8 and 9.

Sub-clauses 6(3) and 6(4) also allow for any arrears of levy, that is amounts of levy that should have been paid in previous periods, to be paid into the Freight Adjustment Fund and for corresponding disbursements to be made to the relevant parties on the basis that would have applied if the arrears had been paid at the time the liability became due.

Clause 5 of the Bill provides that no disbursements from the Freight Adjustment Fund will be made at the end of December 1987. Payments of the amounts that accrued during that month are to be made in accordance with the provisions of clause 6 as outlined above.
The Bill will have no direct financial impact on the Commonwealth.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill, and commend the Bill to Honourable Senators.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 18 November, on motion by Senator Gareth Evans:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No.1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88, I have to reflect on the priorities of this country. I say `this country' because I do not blame just this Government for the state we are in. It is the result of a succession of governments, not just this one. I come again to the issue of young people and the status of youth at the moment. This year is the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless. I have already had words to say in the Senate on homelessness among young people but I will repeat some of my remarks, if just briefly. The status of young people in our society is worse now than it has ever been before. More young people are on the streets now, homeless, than there have ever been before. That is not being addressed satisfactorily by this Government or by any group in society.

SPEECH.PARA: The other horrendous situation facing young people is youth suicide. One in seven deaths of young people between 15 and 19 years of age is a result of suicide. This figure should be pressing panic buttons throughout the community. But it seems that the matter has become a political football. Peter Shack, in the other place, proposed a national inquiry into youth suicide. For his trouble he was accused of politicising the issue. I remind the Senate that today is not a broadcast day. My raising the issue of youth suicide cannot be criticised as promoting suicide, as Peter Shack was accused of doing. For his pains of trying to raise the issue of youth suicide he was accused of promoting it by making the issue public. To address the problem of youth suicide calls for strong, united and bipartisan action.

As I see it and from my experience as a youth worker, I know the figures on youth suicide are far greater than the bald statistics about young people who have deliberately attempted to take their lives. From my experience I know that a lot of drug related deaths and automobile deaths are disguised suicides. Young people are faced with profound despair. They have been marginalised, they are homeless; and they are unemployed. There have been no serious attempts to redress the problem of youth unemployment. There have been countless initiatives and the creation of lots of programs which have been nothing more than a reorganisation of current arrangements, but calling them something else. The net effect is to take unemployed young people out of the unemployment statistics and put them in other statistics about young people in courses.

Too often I have seen the disillusionment and despair of young people who do these courses thinking that when they have finished they will get some employment but who find at the end of them that they have no greater chance of getting work than they had in the first place. So a concerted effort to find work for young people is needed. There is certainly no lack of ability to exploit young people financially and in other ways, and in commercials to try to sell consumer goods to them and to create the vision of a lifestyle of unlimited wealth and lots of fun. Yet in reality the prospects facing young people are quite gloomy.

Not the least factor is young people's fear of nuclear war. Some have criticised the peace movement and its work in publicising the dangers of nuclear war as being responsible for some of the despair felt by young people, but I cannot see how pointing to danger can be in some way the cause of the danger. Because we point to the danger of nuclear war, that does not mean that we are creating the threat; it means that we are saying that something should be done about it. If young people have heard the message, as they have, we cannot be held responsible for the threat. Those who refuse to do anything constructive in the long term to avoid nuclear war must bear the responsibility.

Homelessness, suicide, unemployment and marginalisation face young people today. They also face Aboriginal people, the original owners of this land, people who have been continually oppressed since the arrival of Europeans in this country. Aboriginal homelessness is worse now than it has been at any other time. Aboriginal deaths in custody continue relentlessly even though there is an inquiry into them at the moment. I congratulate the Government on appointing that inquiry. Unemployment amongst Aboriginal people is still horrendous. Aboriginal child mortality rates are still cause for shame. And still there has been no real effort to come to terms with the problems and to introduce concrete programs with achievable goals which will demonstrate that by the year 2000 Aboriginal people will have sovereignty, homes and an equal place in this society and that there will be a partnership between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in the management of this continent. Instead of that all we have is talk of a compact. And still Aboriginal people die, still Aboriginal people are unemployed and still Aboriginal people are homeless.

I turn to Australia's defence-or so-called defence-arrangements. The other day Senator MacGibbon talked about the need to project force and lamented that we could not project force in the region, meaning that we could not invade and take over some other country in the region if we wanted to. I would like to address the question of security and just what security means for ourselves and for the region. Security is more than military security. Security is more than just being safe from invasion or being in some way militarily weaker than some other nation. Security has a whole range of economic and social aspects. Security implies that there is justice. Peace without justice is impossible, and peace without security is impossible. Peace which is established through force is not security.

One of the things that is militating against security is military expenditure. The other day Senator Vallentine, Senator Jenkins, Senator Sanders and I nailed an eviction notice to a door at the American Embassy to suggest that the Americans should remove themselves from Pine Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think you were invited.

—We were not invited; we were deliberately not invited. We had formally written to the Ambassador, asking to meet him and present this petition to him. He wrote back in a very arrogant way and said that he knew our views and there was no point in meeting us. It is no surprise that Mr Beazley has given us the same sort of reply. So we decided to take the eviction notice to the Ambassador. It was nice to see that a friendly marine took the eviction notice from the door into the Embassy.
—The Ambassador was very courteous.

—The Ambassador was very courteous. In his remarks to us over the barrier at the front of his place, he pointed out to us that the United States Government has been in deficit for years in order to police the world against terrorism. That is a remarkable statement for an ambassador to make. He admitted that the United States deficit is, in large part, the result of United States military spending. If we look at other places around the world, we will see that the foreign debts of most of the Third World countries are largely the result of their military spending. So not only is the United States in debt because of its military spending, but also it is exporting debt to the Third World. There is economic instability around the world as a result of debts and deficits. Our Government, with its deficit, is merely part of the trend; it has joined the trend. It has a fashionable deficit, like that of everybody else. It is only its commitment to a free market, to a deregulated financial market, that is becoming unique. While every other country is retreating into protectionism, our fashionable Treasurer (Mr Keating) is continuing to keep our doors open to financial and other exploitation.

SPEECH.PARA: Military spending is responsible for a great deal of the economic instability facing the world today. Unfortunately, if we look at both sides of the Parliament, the only level of economic vision we can find is a real estate salesman level of economics-a pre-occupation with taxation and income. There is no sense of how economics is not the economics that is practised in the world; economics is power. The Bonds, the Holmes a Courts, Conzinc Riotinto and all the rest do not practice the sort of real estate salesman economics that our Treasurer and Senator Stone practice. That sort of economics is put together by academics and is grasped by real estate agents and used car salesmen. I do not denigrate the work that real estate agents and car salesmen do-they perform a valuable service-but the sorts of economics that are used to run a used car agency, a real estate agency or a farm for that matter are not the economics used to effect global change.

TALK.START.PARA: —Lay off the farmers.

—I compliment the farmers on the work they have done. It is the farmers who feed us; it is the farmers who have created a large part of the exports, so I am not knocking farmers. Farmers are workers like anybody else. The problem is that the large multinational corporations which are responsible for the economic direction of this Government and other governments have interests other than profitability. They are interested in survival and growth. A short term for a multinational corporation might be 10 years. So it might be in the interests of a large corporation to take a cut in its profitability for a while, to encourage smaller and less robust economic entities to go to the wall so that in the long term they get the advantage. That is power politics; that is not economics.

SPEECH.PARA: Large corporations are quite happy to use bribery as a tool of their economic policy-witness the Japanese situation and the bribing of Prime Ministers and others. This is not the economics that Senator Stone and Senator Walsh argue about at length and very dryly in this place. It is politics and it is corruption. So economics is not a science; economics is political decision-making. We can look at the parlous state of many economies around the world, at Third World debt, at our debt and at the United States deficit which results from an attempt to gain power and to maintain it. The way it is protected is through nuclear war fighting strategies. Probably the nub of my message today is that our Government should get out of thenuclear war fighting strategies of other countries.

Senator Vallentine moved an amendment to the Address-in-Reply to the Governor-General's Speech. Certainly a lot of heat, if not light, was generated in the debate that followed in this place. We were told that our suggestion that the United States is planning for a limited nuclear engagement was crazy. We were told that everybody knows that once a nuclear war started it would be the end for all of us and that neither the United States nor the Soviet Union wanted that to occur.

In fact, something quite different is occurring in nuclear strategy planning, and it has been for some time. The Western nations have moved away from the MAD doctrine - the doctrine of mutually assured destruction. The fundamental assumption of the MAD doctrine is that a nation's nuclear arsenal must provide a credible deterrent against attack by the other state. But just what is a credible deterrent? It is the achievement of overall superiority. The problem is how one decides who has overall superiority, especially considering that the Government of the United States for the last 15 years and more has lied to its own people and its allies. Every year, around US Budget time, we hear about yet another Soviet threat - it is going to be ahead in the number of bombers, in the number of short range missiles or in space research. These theories have all been postulated by the United States military to justify its own expansionism.

TALK.START.PARA: — What about long range missiles?
— That is true of long range missiles as well. There is not one area of military and nuclear capability in which the Soviet Union is ahead of the United States.
— It certainly has more tanks.

— This question concerns its nuclear capability. Of course, when we do the Soviet Union versus the United States mathematics we do not take into account the military budgets of Great Britain, France and other countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO). One of the areas in which the Soviet Union is ahead of the United States is in the number of soldiers it has deployed outside its own border - some 115,000 of those being in Afghanistan. The other side of that statistic is that the United States has soldiers in more places than the Soviet Union, so those comparative statistics are sometimes not terribly useful. As Senator Robert Ray has pointed out, for example, the Soviet Union has more tanks. But in global strategic terms, the US has always had the edge.

SPEECH.PARA: The US now has the edge in the NUTS doctrine, in nuclear utilisation target selection. I think that it was probably a fairly whimsical person who put that acronym together to show that we have transcended MAD and now have become NUTS, but that is what has happened. The United States and the Western powers have moved to a situation of deliberate planning for the use of nuclear weapons. The US has placed more emphasis than the Soviets on a NUTS strategy and a first strike capability generally, and that has been so for more than a decade. In 1982 McNamara stated that within four to five years the United States would be ahead in its ability to wage a limited nuclear engagement. The whole point of NUTS is to win a first strike, which is to strike first and wipe out the other side's ability to fight back. In that sense, one's command structure and war fighting structure survive and one sustains less damage than one's counterpart. That is the thinking of a large number of the military in the United States and that is the direction in which its nuclear development has gone. Smaller and more accurate missiles, such as the MX, are designed for silo sized targets. We have moved away from holding cities as hostage. Soviet missiles are still fairly city size in their accuracy, in terms of what they are capable of targeting; whereas Western missile systems are now--

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not correct. The latest Soviet ballistic missiles are highly accurate.

—I am quite happy to give my sources to the honourable senator to show that the United States is far ahead of the Soviet Union in terms of the accuracy of its nuclear weapons. The point is not whether the United States is ahead or the Soviet Union is ahead. The fundamental and important point is that that is the direction in which nuclear strategies are heading.
—You would move away from mass destruction surely.

—I am against mass destruction. Is the honourable senator suggesting that any sort of nuclear exchange will not lead to mass destruction? I suggest it is that thinking that is at large in the Pentagon. Being able to target more accurately does not mean reducing the size of the explosions one sends across, but that one can direct more accurately one's weapons of destruction. The problem is that once it starts, it does not stop. In that sense, the fundamentals of the MAD doctrine still apply, because once it starts, it does not stop. The United States has said often that it would not baulk at being the first to use a limited nuclear strike in Europe. It has threatened that, should the Soviets move outside of their borders in Europe, it would not hesitate to use nuclear weapons in Europe.
—It has not said that.
—It has said that. I am quite happy to provide the evidence of that. The point of it all--
—The point of it all is that you are not putting equal pressure on the Soviet Union as you are seeking to put on the US.
—We do put equal pressure on the Soviet Union.
—I have not heard a word of it today.
—The reason the honourable senator has not heard a word about the Soviet Union at the moment, and I did mention Afghanistan, is that- -
—Yes, but you did not even say that Soviet troops ought to get out of Afghanistan.

—I think that Soviet troops should get out of Afghanistan. I think that the Soviets believe that too. I think that the Soviets should get out of Afghanistan and that the United States should leave Nicaragua alone. Nicaragua has a democratically elected government. The thrust of all of this is that the United States is pushing the direction of the nuclear race into one where it thinks that a nuclear war is thinkable and not unthinkable and where people will begin to think that a limited nuclear engagement is preferable to a full nuclear engagement, when the only proper course is total and absolute disarmament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88 and cognate Bills most of my colleagues have spoken of the Government's failure in economic management. I endorse what they have said and endorse, in particular, our proposed amendment, which calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other microeconomic policies with a view to providing Australia with a more appropriate economic framework to meet the current economic dangers. What I want to speak about today would appear to be a consequence of that failure of the Government in economic management coupled with what I would suggest is a lack of long term vision or resolve to take domestically difficult decisions. In relation to the Appropriation Bills I want to deal with this Government's foreign aid record and intentions.

SPEECH.PARA: I want to direct some specific comments to that part of the aid program relating to the Philippines. We are part of a wider world community and there are those, many not far from our shores, who are not as well off as we are and who deserve our attention and support. Therefore, an aid program is usually-I make no excuse for it-based on humanitarian grounds. I guess the real test for humanity occurs when things start to become a little tight at home. I suggest that the program need not be based on humanitarian grounds alone but also can be based on pragmatic, self-interest grounds. I suggest that foreign aid can legitimately be considered an investment in our own security. In those terms, when we look at the appropriations and the attitude of this Government, we see that there is justification for real concern.

It is fascinating that this Government, which has massacred the Australian aid vote and its reputation as an aid donor internationally, nevertheless accepts the rationale which I have just put. When one looks at the 1986 supplementary Budget Paper on foreign aid one finds that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) stated:
Australia's foreign policy and bona fides were enhanced by our status as an aid donor.

He then went on to explain that owing to the need for budgetary restraint foreign aid for 1986-87 was being reduced by $70m compared with aid for the previous year. The effect was to reduce aid in real terms to its lowest level in 20 years. When we look at the Third World we see that there is no more sure path than that leading from economic deprivation to political instability. In order to preserve our security and our way of life we expend, as we know, a great deal on the need to defend Australia but a much lesser sum on the prevention of the circumstances that might lead to that threat or the need for defence. By that I mean that the poverty and the failure of the very modest economic aspirations of our neighbours can create the environment from which further trouble can develop. Economic poverty renders the neighbour either vulnerable from within or vulnerable to pressures and influences from without. I guess that in relation to the Philippines both circumstances apply. In other words, I am saying that unfortunately this Government has said very publicly, for domestic political reasons, that charity begins at home. I suggest that as a result of so short-sighted an attitude, it fails the true leadership responsibility given it by the Australian people.

Unfortunately, the picture gets worse. As a result of the 1987 May mini-Budget, Australia's foreign aid budget was cut by a further $20m. This will affect overseas student charges and bilateral and multilateral aid programs in 1987-88. The current level of official development assistance is only 0.36 per cent of gross national product (GNP), a drop in real terms of 3.4 per cent from the previous year. I remind the Senate that the target figure which is set by the United Nations and to which this Government claims it still directs its mind is 0.7 per cent. So Australia's level of assistance has been reduced to nearly half of the target figure. We have witnessed a real reduction of 20 per cent since 1984. It is interesting to note that of all the areas of government spending, foreign aid appears to have been subjected to the toughest cuts. This area has been made to bear a heavier share of the burden that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) so often talks about. I believe that this is a major indictment of the Government and should be recognised as such by the literally hundreds of thousands of supporters of non-governmental aid agencies who work tirelessly in this field to help those who are not as well off as we are. Certainly, on the figures, this Government should be condemned.

I want to put the self-interest argument which I mentioned in the context of the Philippines. Political stability in the Philippines is vitally important for Australia. Its position in the Association of South East Asian Nations, its geographical location on the major access route to Japan, its critical role as host to major United States bases in the wider Western alliance, all remind us of the importance of the Philippines to us. Yet, as we know, the Philippines remains vulnerable and its democratic government remains fragile. So much of that vulnerability results from economic deprivation that is caused by so many factors-from internal exploitation by the former Government and authorities through to the international price collapse of the Philippines' principal commodities. Whatever the cause, I am arguing that it remains in Australia's best interests to support Mrs Aquino and her Government in their attempts to overcome the economic deprivation because the very survival of that Government depends on the achievement of that goal.

After more than a 13 per cent decline in GNP over 2 1/2 years, the Philippines achieved a rise in GNP of 5.53 per cent for the period June 1986 to June 1987. This improvement resulted mainly from a more vigorous industrial sector which expanded by nearly 10 per cent in that period. Despite this slight rallying of the economy, formidable economic problems continue to plague the Aquino Government. Lack of opportunity in the rural areas, where about 60 per cent of the people live on incomes below the poverty line, has obviously created a situation of uncertainty for the Government. Unemployment and underemployment affect almost 50 per cent of the work force. Filipinos witnessed a steady decline in their real incomes for five years before the slight turnaround that I mentioned a moment ago. The $28.6 billion foreign debt will, unfortunately, siphon off for debt service nearly 35 per cent of this year's expected earnings from the export of goods and services.

Further, the more recent problems experienced by the Philippines as a result of the political destabilisation of the August attempted coup have had an adverse effect on investment and could affect anticipated future export growth. Continual labour unrest and illegal strikes have added to the current difficulties, all of which obviously contribute little to getting the economy back on its feet. I am arguing that it is in Australia's interest to help the Philippine economy get back on its feet. I readily accept we will not ever be a key player in that regard. I guess we experienced that when the Australian Government pledged to the Philippines Government that it would actively support international co-operation in rescheduling the Philippines' foreign debt in 1986, but in the end it found that there was no role for it to play in that eventual rescheduling. Unfortunately, the Australian Government's position to influence such decisions is very limited and that relates to the very small contributions that we are now giving to institutions such as the World Bank. We remain strong on rhetoric, but we are low on clout. Accepting that we will never be a key player, there is, nevertheless, an unfortunate tendency to take it one step further and say that because we will not be a key player it enables us to excuse ourselves from playing a role within our capacities. I would suggest that that excuse is unjustified.

I was pleased that the Australian Government sent an aid mission to the Philippines in April 1986 with the purpose of looking at what areas aid should be directed. The report of that mission identified a number of areas. I will, very briefly, bring some areas to the Senate's attention. They are higher education, science, vocational and technical training-really all areas of training were found to be in need of support-selected aspects of agriculture and rural development; food security, particularly post-harvest handling and storage, which is something that we find is consistent with so many Third World countries. One needs only to remind oneself of the cost in Africa because of the lack of handling and storage facilities for grain. There are selected aspects of health, population, water supply and sanitation; selected aspects of energy; regional and provincial planning for development; and small and medium enterprise development.

Those findings seem to be largely in accord with the findings also made by the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence in its report last year on Australian-Philippine relations. The test now is to assess how Australia is achieving progress in contributing to such areas. Although, regrettably, the information upon which to make that assessment tends to be more difficult to find than hens' teeth, on what I have been able to find it would appear that we are not going too well at all in our contribution.

Mr Hayden outlined the strategy that he intended to adopt based on that aid report I have mentioned and he did so in a speech to the Queensland branch of the Australian Institute of International Affairs on 28 March 1986 and he repeated it in this Parliament on 12 and 13 March of that year. He referred to the following goals and guidelines. He said the first was to provide an input into the development of trade between the Philippines and Australia. This would appear to me to be the first area of failure because on any objective assessment this Government has done little to redress the imbalance of trade between Australia and the Philippines. I remind honourable senators that Australian exports to the Philippines were valued at over $200m in 1985-86, whilst we imported from the Philippines in the same period only $123m, little more than half of what we exported. This imbalance in bilateral trade has been described by the Department of Trade as a perennial irritant and there is no doubt about that. A few months ago the then Trade Secretary, Mr Conception, came to Australia with proposals seeking a preferential tariff reduction for his country because of its unique problems on a limited time basis.

TALK.START.PARA: —What country is that?

—The Philippines. It would seem that his proposals, put in the best interests of his country-if honourable senators accept my argument, they were also in the best interests of this country-were dismissed. The Australian Government was to provide an extension of a revolving trade credit facility of $50m which was to have expired on 15 March 1986. From my research this also never eventuated. I suppose the most recent comments on the subject came from the Philippine Agricultural Minister, Mr Carlos Dominguez, who issued a number of sharply angled comments on his return to Manila after a visit to Australia in recent times in an attempt to redress this trade imbalance. Regrettably it seems that he received little support from the Australian Government in what I would argue is in the best interests of the Australian Government to pursue. He pushed for increased importation by Australia of Philippine coconut oil, coffee and cocoa, garments, tuna and prawns, but this Government does not seem to have taken any action that would facilitate that very worthwhile objective.

SPEECH.PARA: The second area that Mr Hayden referred to where he would be ensuring that his Government achieved something in the best interests of the Philippines was a continuation and acceleration of existing projects. It would seem that there has been a continuation of the major projects to completion, such as the Zamboanga project and the near completion of the Samar project, but there is no evidence at all of any acceleration of these projects or any other projects in the best interests of the Philippines and, therefore, the Government has failed to live up to and achieve the goal that it set in that regard.

Mr Hayden also spoke of the Government's intention to provide increased education assistance particularly through training in Australia. I need hardly remind the Senate that two areas in which the Government has reduced funding have been training support and student subsidies. Overall, overseas student subsidies have dropped from $98.6m in 1984-85 to $85.2m in 1987-88, while training support dropped from $5.9m in 1985-86 to $5.2m in 1987-88. In the case of the Philippines, training assistance dropped from $1.7m in 1985-86 to $1.5m in 1986-87. The overseas student subsidy fell from $624,000 in 1985-86 to $596,000 in 1986-87. So the Government has blatantly failed in that stated objective which Mr Hayden put to the Parliament in relation to increased education assistance through training.

The fourth point that he made in stating the Australian Government's intention to help the Philippines was that there would be studies to lay the foundation for longer term expansion which he said will compose, in the main, projects directed at helping poor, rural and urban groups and promoting equitable economic development. I have said that to try to find information on what is happening in relation to studies is almost impossible, but on what I have been able to get to date there is very little evidence of either success or significant contribution in this area.

The fifth point Mr Hayden made was a possible meeting of requests from the Government of the Philippines for the provision of balance of payments by providing support in key sectors, such as energy. This is an area in which Australia can obviously provide support, particularly in the provision of coal which would not only be materially beneficial to this country but would also significantly help the Philippines in overcoming or reducing its balance of payments problem. But again it appears that nothing has eventuated. This Government is strong on rhetoric, but when it comes to action to put the rhetoric into effect it is regrettably failing once again.

Mr Hayden also referred to Australian assistance in aid co-ordination. He said that Australia had offered a venue for meetings of the consultative group on aid to the Philippines. This is another area that, on my research, would appear not to have been pursued. I will give credit to the Government for having met one of its promises. In 1986 Mr Hayden said, on visiting the Philippines, that we would increase our aid by 50 per cent, from the 1985-86 figure of $17m to $25m in 1986-87. This the Government has done. But I fear for the future because the increase in aid was couched in terms such that it depended on the economic circumstances of Australia. As I think I have demonstrated, this Government has been very ready to use the economic difficulties that we face in Australia to justify reductions in aid.

As I understand it, on the indicative planning figures that are available it would appear that the Government is looking towards a downturn in the years 1989-90 and 1990-91. So it has built up the aid figure to $35m for 1988-89 but I am told that the estimate for the following year is that it will be reduced to $28m and, for the year following that, a further reduction to some $13m is likely. If this occurs, not only will it be detrimental for the Philippines but also, on my argument, it will be detrimental to the interests of this country. The needs of the Aquino Government are as vital now as they were when Mrs Aquino came to government, and arguably they are even more critical because time is running out.

In summary, I urge the Australian Government, not only for humanitarian reasons but also in the interests of Australia, to keep up our aid contribution and our support for the Philippines, at least in real terms. I urge the Government also to test the application of that aid against the very reasonable objectives that were set out in the aid review. I urge the Government to provide leadership, which it has failed to do to date, to rectify the trade balance that we have with the Philippines, and to provide more public information in order that those interested in this matter might more constructively be able to monitor progress and provide advice. As Cardinal Sin of the Philippines reminded us in this very building only a few weeks ago, many Filipinos put their lives on the line for the chance to live under a system of democratic freedom which we so cherish in this country. I would suggest that they deserve our support. A stable, democratic Philippines is very much in the best interests of Australia.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and the Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 I wish to place on the record my comments about the Federal Government's 1987-88 Budget. I wish to look at the deficit figure and I will then turn to the revenue and outlay figures which make it up. I also intend to compare the Budget that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and the Government have presented to us with the present state and needs of the Australian economy as I see them.

SPEECH.PARA: The Treasurer has been acclaimed for delivering to Australia a virtually balanced Budget. According to his assessment the Budget deficit will be only $27m this year. Brian Frith of the Australian said:
On balance, it really does exceed all expectations.

Frith, like many other journalists, applauded what he termed `a zero deficit'. If that were the truth of the matter, let me say unequivocally that, while I consider it to be decidedly less than the Government ought to have achieved, I would congratulate the Government for being so bold thus far. Of course, the Budget deficit is the result of fudges and rubbery figures. These fudges totally undermine the Government's claim that the Budget is balanced.

Perhaps superficially the most obvious and glaring fraud in the Budget is that the Commonwealth plans to sell $1,000m worth of assets and to deduct the money that it receives from the amount it claims to be spending. This Commonwealth Government goes out and spends $79,146m, sells $1 billion worth of assets and then uses the money. It then comes back to the people of Australia and says that it has outlaid only $78,146m. It simply takes off $1 billion from the outlays and says that it has not outlaid that money-but, of course, it has. It is precisely the same as a family spending $20,000 in a year, selling the family car for $5,000 and trying to pretend that it has spent only $15,000. It is absolute nonsense.

I do not care what the Treasurer says about whether it is acceptable accounting for governments-and this Government has double standards by any measure-because it is certainly not acceptable and no person could be expected to operate in such a fashion. Honourable senators could imagine what a bank manager would say if one took those balance sheets into a bank seeking an overdraft. It is no wonder that our credit ratings have now been downgraded by the two major credit agencies. Likewise, the Commonwealth cannot sell assets to finance public consumption. On 26 November 1985 Senator Peter Walsh, when referring to the South Australian election, said in this place:
Mr Olsen says that he will fund his tax cuts by selling assets. That is another way of saying that he will liquidate assets to fund current expenditure.
Senator Walsh went on to say:
We all know where that road leads. If one keeps going down that road for long enough, one finishes up insolvent.

If we substitute `current expenditure' for the words `tax cuts', that warning applies precisely to the Commonwealth and the Government of which Senator Walsh is a Minister. It can be seen already that the deficit is not $27m, as is claimed, but on that arithmetic alone it is at least $1,027m. But there is more. The Commonwealth Government has also fudged a profit figure from the Reserve Bank of Australia. Last year the Government received a large profit windfall from the Reserve Bank which came predominantly from currency transactions during the period when the Australian dollar was particularly volatile. On page 354 of Budget Paper No. 1 we find the statement that the profits reflected a substantial increase in realised gains from the sale of foreign currency. Budget Paper No. 1 states that the profits of the Reserve Bank:
. . . can vary substantially from year to year, depending on the current state of monetary policy and market factors, particularly movements in the interest rate and the exchange rate.
By way of comparison, in 1982-83 the Reserve Bank's profit was $663m; in 1983-84 its profit was $746m. Last year it was an extraordinary $2,934m.

As I have said, the profit has been due, of course, to currency movements. It is acknowledged in the Budget Papers themselves as being subject to large variations. One has to ask: What should an honest and prudent government include as expected profit figures when drawing up its Budget? The profit for the Reserve Bank this year will be almost $3,200m, which is a further and substantial increase on that which it achieved last year. It is an increase of slightly more than 9 per cent on last year's figure. Either that figure will not be realised or the Government is impliedly telling us that it expects the Australian dollar to devalue even further, even more substantially, than it has in the past. Certainly on the recent performance of the dollar we could be forgiven for thinking that this was the Government's intention. However, if Reserve Bank profits fall to something more like their historic levels we could add at least another $1,000m on to the deficit for this year. Clearly, the claimed $27m deficit is wrong. It is unsoundly based on the use of money from assets sales and it depends upon substantial profits from the Reserve Bank in the unpredictable area of foreign exchange transactions.

It will be no surprise to people familiar with this Government that it has relied more heavily on increasing the taxation it collects than on pruning its own expenditure. Taxation revenue is expected to rise again this year by 8.5 per cent. Of course, the Government again will rely on taxation by stealth or on increases through bracket creep as a means of increasing the income tax take. I have a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library which indicates the number of people who will cross into higher tax brackets over the next three years, on the assumption that the income tax scales do not change-that seems highly unlikely in the present economic circumstances-and that average weekly earnings increase at 6.9 per cent, which is the rate over the period of the Hawke Government. I seek leave to have the table incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. The table shows that if there are no scale changes more than two million people who are already paying tax will cross into a higher bracket. This does not include the people currently below the threshold who will be compelled to pay tax for the first time. In 1987-88 alone, almost three-quarters of a million people will cross over into higher tax brackets, with a consequent reduction in the real value of their take home pay. This is how the Treasurer will find some of the revenue he needs to fund this Budget. It will come off the backs of the ordinary Australian workers.

SPEECH.PARA: Recognising these facts, it really rubs salt into the wound that, after the Budget, the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) revealed in a moment of rare, frank honesty that there are something like 200 areas where expenditure reductions could have occurred but this Government did not have the political or intestinal fortitude to take the appropriate, necessary, in fact, imperative, action. There are other matters about the revenues which I wish to discuss. These are the capital gains tax, interest rates and the fringe benefits tax. In the last Budget, receipts generally were $910m in total greater than expected. Tax receipts from non-pay as you earn income earners were $982m higher than estimated. I hazard a guess as to where a large part of that money might have come from. Until recently, as almost every citizen knows, the stock exchange has been very much on an upward trend. The all ordinaries index, between June 1986 and June 1987, rose from 1,180 to 1,765, a rise of something like one-third.

It would not surprise me if a significant amount of the increased revenue the Government has received has been through capital gains taxes levied on successful share speculation. That tax on share speculation is the same tax which has already been levied. As we all know, the Australian stock exchange has recently taken a dramatic fall. A very lucrative source of capital gains tax revenue has been stopped dead in its tracks. One might expect a prudent government to have assumed that the market would not keep rising and the Government might reasonably have been expected to be cautious with its revenue estimates from that source. Yet, with the exception of withholding tax, there is not one category of income taxation in which the Government estimates a rise of less than 6.5 per cent. In the classification under which capital gains earners could fall, the Government is budgeting for more than a 10 per cent increase. With the fall in the share market, the same capital gains simply are not there to be made. In fact, the Government is likely to have people seeking deductions for the losses they have made in the recent spectacular fall of the share market. Government estimates of revenue from capital gains must now be considered to be very rubbery, to say the least.

The Treasurer has also acknowledged in a statement in the Commonwealth Record of June and July this year that there has been an exceptionally large increase in the number of provisional taxpayers, reflecting, I imagine, a large increase in interest earnings. We have been told that there will be an interest rate fall. People who pay provisional tax are estimated in the same Budget figure as capital gains earners where, as I have already said, an increase is expected. I cannot tell what the future will hold but it seems to me that the Treasurer has banked on increased revenue from areas prone to fluctuation. His figures are looking shakier by the minute.

As was predicted, the fringe benefits tax has proven to be a major impost on business. The Government raked in $535m from the fringe benefits tax, which was $210m above and beyond that which the Government expected and budgeted for. My opposition to that form of taxation is well known. Now is not the time to canvass it extensively. I simply seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two tables from Appendix 3 of the Budget Papers, which will reveal which areas the fringe benefits tax is hitting the most and how much tax is being paid.
