TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. I also note that the Treasurer finally has woken up to what the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia have been telling him about negative gearing from the time he proposed outlawing it. After driving rents through the roof he has now been forced into a humiliating and inevitable backdown. He has again allowed people to offset against other income any losses they make on properties. He has now restored the position of people who own houses to the same position they were in before and the same position as any other business. It is a shame that he did not earlier take the good advice of the coalition and save a great deal of pain, anguish and financial distress to people caught up in his rather absurd and bizarre scheme.

SPEECH.PARA: On the outlay side, I have already mentioned the most glaring fraud; that is, that the Commonwealth has simply deducted from the figures for outlays the money it expects to receive from asset sales. This, of course, is nonsense. True outlays, as I said earlier, are $79,146m, not $78,146m. Rather than growing by 4.3 per cent, as stated in the Budget, they are growing by more than 5 per cent. It is worth closely examining how this allegedly tough Government goes about pruning back its expenditure. A major component of Commonwealth expenditure is transfers to State and local governments. I am not to be taken as suggesting that State and local governments do not have to share their part of the burden of fiscal restraint. I simply want to contrast the standards this allegedly tough Treasurer of the Commonwealth Government sets for himself and what he expects of others.

Let us look at outlays by the Commonwealth Government, which are within what might normally be described as discretionary spending powers such as in the welfare, community services, economic services and administration areas and then net out interest payments, which might be regarded as fixed payments, and transfers to other governments. We find the Government's spending has increased by 9 per cent-which is a real increase. The increase in transfers to other governments is 3 per cent-which, in real terms, is a fall. Thus, and not for the first time, the Treasurer is caught applying one law for himself and another law or impost for others. This is made all the worse when we remember that Senator Walsh says that there are an incredible 200 areas where Commonwealth spending could have been reduced but this Government simply did not have the political courage to make the appropriate and necessary cuts.

Another aspect of Federal Government outlays which does not rate a mention as often as it should is how the money is being spent. Even a deficit Budget, which this Budget is, can often, in some circumstances and some respects, be justified if the spending is occurring on capital works. Presumably, in the future they will return some benefits to the community. If we are building roads, bridges or similar facilities and infrastructure we might, at least in the long term, enhance our economic prospects. Sadly, these things take a long term vision and this Government is hooked completely on its public image and it considers these matters as expendable: they do not register quickly in the opinion polls, they do not flow into popular community appeal, so they are dismissed out of hand.

I turn to the table indicating outlays of capital and current consumption nature. There is a 6.9 per cent increase in current outlays and an 11.7 per cent fall in capital outlays. The total capital outlays by the Commonwealth are expected to decline by 20 per cent in real terms. This is to a large extent the result of reductions in State Loan Council borrowings. This in turn has reduced the State capital works programs. Of the $1,000m cut from the States in the May Loan Council meeting, $751m was cut from capital spending. Capital grants to the States have fallen over the last five years both in absolute terms and as a proportion of the total money the Commonwealth allocates to the States. I am fully aware of the interest rate effect on a gung ho approach to capital spending and the effect of a bloated public sector borrowing requirement but, if the Government believes it should spend the money, it would serve the long term interests of this country if it gave priority to capital rather than recurrent spending. Of course, in my view there ought to be a significant reduction in both, but if this Budget is predicated on not reducing outlays, clearly the emphasis in the long term interests of the viability and profitability of this country ought to be on cuts in recurrent and not capital expenditure.

The final part of my speech is directed to assessing how well the Budget meets the needs of the economy generally. I remind the Senate that 7.7 per cent of the work force is unemployed. There are 596,300 people unable to find work under this Government. More than one in five people between the ages of 15 and 19 years are out of work. Twenty per cent of today's youth are unable to find work and the average length of time that an unemployed person spent out of work in the last 12 months under this Government was 47 weeks. By way of contrast, in 1982-83, the last financial year in which the coalition was in government, the equivalent period was about 32 weeks. So there has been a dramatic increase under this Government. As they are average figures, by definition they must mean that many people now are spending many years out of work. This Government clearly recognises the link between wage costs and unemployment levels. On page 23 of Budget Paper No. 1 it says:
The relative buoyancy of employment growth seems to owe a good deal to the factor substitution flowing from the now sustained fall in the relative cost of labour.

In other words, if labour costs go down employers will substitute labour for capital equipment. What this means is that if labour does not price itself out of the market employers will have the scope to employ more people. Despite this, the Government plans a 1.5 per cent increase in the first tier wage adjustment and another 4 per cent increase across the community in wage rates. There is also the continuing spectre of the inevitable superannuation claims. Rather than taking a firm line on wage costs, the Government caves in for the sake of its mates in the trade unions. The unemployed, who are not so powerful and who do not have a union or the clout of the unions, are left to fend as best they can. I do not wish to be taken as saying that it is all the fault of the workers; clearly it is not. Estimates of labour on-costs such as fringe benefits tax, workers compensation, superannuation and payroll tax, to name just a few, are part of the costs on which an employer bases employment decisions but they are not part of the take home pay for the employee. On-costs in the last 12 months have been estimated to be somewhere between 20 per cent and 40 per cent-in some cases 50 per cent-of the total cost of employing labour. Of course, it is possible for labour costs to employers to rise without employees actually having an increase in their take home pay. That is exactly what has happened. Over the last three years the total cost of employing people has risen faster than the employees' wages, indicating a very significant increase in on-costs. Labour costs are one of the factors which contribute to the cost of our goods and in turn their competitiveness on world markets. Ultimately they affect our horrendous current account deficit.

Total costs of employing people rose by 6.3 per cent in Australia in the last financial year while the equivalent cost for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) rose by only 4.4 per cent. Clearly, this undermines any beneficial effects from the devaluation of the Australian dollar. Our competitiveness is undermined by our general level of inflation, which is about 2 1/2 times the OECD average. It is infinitely greater than that of Japan, where prices are actually falling. It is about 13 times greater than that of West Germany, which has an inconsequential rate of 0.7 per cent. Inflated prices for our goods simply reduce our exports and make it inevitable that our balance of payments will continue to deteriorate. That is in turn causing an increase on our mountain of foreign debt, our gross foreign debt already being $110 billion and climbing. To put this into some kind of perspective, it would, for instance, take us the equivalent of 50 times the value of last year's wheat exports or more than 50 times last year's iron ore exports to pay this debt. It would take about 35 times the value of the wheat crop to pay off just the increase in foreign debt during the period of the Hawke Government.

I now turn very briefly to living standards and tax savings. Last year real household disposable income fell again, by 1.2 per cent. So living standards continued to fall. They were dropping because, although labour costs to employers were rising beyond tolerable levels, an increasing proportion is going in on-costs and taxation and not finding its way, as I said previously, into the pockets of the employees. Once it does, it is then attacked by the nation's highest taxing, most avaricious Treasurer. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard a table prepared by the Parliamentary Library which shows the increasing tax take from a family with two dependent children from the time this Government came to office projected forward assuming there is no change to the tax rates and with the increase in annual earnings continuing at 6.9 per cent.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Removing family allowance, the tax take will climb from 13.2 per cent of average weekly earnings to 20.8 per cent, a rise in tax of more than $70 per week. Set any family income package against that and see how the bottom line comes out. With the remainder, a family has to try to keep up with inflation, pay off a car, pay off a house and raise children. When examining the costs families face, it is important to note a recent survey conducted by economic analysts Peter Bennett and Associates for the Australian Retailers Association. It was found that government taxes and charges had increased relatively more than the prices of food and clothing or the consumer price index figure. In Perth, for example, since 1981, transport fares and electricity have increased by 59.6 per cent and 56.7 per cent respectively while food and clothing have increased by 42.7 per cent and 44.3 per cent respectively. Increased taxes and high inflation in turn affect a family's ability to save. The proportion of household income which is being put aside for savings has fallen for four years in a row under this Government. Every year for the last four years, the capacity of people to save has significantly deteriorated. Of course, without these savings, we simply cannot invest and create new wealth, unless we borrow abroad which, as we have seen recently, significantly increases our foreign debt.

SPEECH.PARA: In closing, let me say that in my view this Budget has done very little to put Australia on a firmer footing. The deficit figure is a fraud to be used for the Government's selfish political purposes. The Government has cut capital spending and transfers to other governments rather than seriously taking a knife to its own bloated spending. It has, as is usual and inevit-able, relied upon increasing taxation. In turn, this increases pressures on already struggling families, making their lives more difficult, and reduces savings for investment. Pressures are created, of course, for wage rises in a labour market which is awash in a sea of unemployment, and further fuel is added to our already roaring inflation rate. Together, they do very little to stop our rising foreign debt. This failure increasingly imperils our future.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sheil Sen G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is the third term of the Hawke socialist Government, so I presume that it has placed the economy in as satisfactory a position as it wants. This is all very well for a socialist government that is rapidly becoming fascist because of the association of big government, big unions and big business, but the conservative side of politics sees the economy as being in an unholy mess. Senator Stone has foreshadowed an amendment to the motion for the second reading of the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88. TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. One of the important areas that I want to touch on is company registration. I know there is now a big move to simplify the legislation covering companies and to have a national register. Everybody is having a problem deciding which companies should be on a national register and which should be on a State register. I wish to promote the continuation of State registration for companies, simply on the ground that it will give them a better opportunity to operate without constraints. During the great health debate, the only thing that saved Australia from nationalisation of health care was the fact that all the doctors were registered in the States; they were not registered nationally. Therefore, the Federal Government could not bring them all under its wing. The same applies to company registration. The longer they remain registered in the States, the less likely they are to suffer from the depredations of a big Federal government.

SPEECH.PARA: The companies that would be brought under the national wing, of course, would be the bigger companies-the companies that trade interstate, the companies that trade overseas, and others. I give them this word of warning: keep out of national registration and stick to State registration. If we allow companies to have only national registration, that will lead us further down the track towards the fascist state to which I referred earlier. I recognise that company law has become complex, largely because of high taxation and, of course, the assaults of certain organisations-and I include trade unions in that group-and this has led to the moves to have national registration. I add that if we had a single rate of tax at 25 per cent, a lot of the problems would disappear.

Management has been slow to respond to the challenge from these organisations and has only recently started to fight back. Over the years the manipulation of the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission has had a detrimental effect on our companies and industries. One cannot altogether blame the trade unions for that because, in order to bring the processes of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission into operation, a dispute had to be created; so the unions had to create disputes to get action. That situation should have been rectified long before now. I recognise that there have been bad management practices over the years, and even recently. Honourable senators will remember that in the last few weeks the Australian and New Zealand Banking Group Ltd has been exposed as having bad management practices in regard to employment. These bad management practices are usually seen in old, established and constipated enterprises. They are rarely seen in the new, dynamic and active businesses, where management and labour are teaming up and working together enthusiastically to produce their product.

Apart from the high and complicated taxes, the actions of the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission, bad management and bad union practices-I include in bad union practices disputes up to and including the Mudginberri, Dollar Sweets Co. Pty Ltd., plumbers and gasfitters, and Peko-Wallsend Ltd disputes-there is now being added the advent of this network of legislation which is threatening to tie up industry. Gulliver was tied up by the Lilliputians because he was a dangerous giant. That tied him up so that he was ineffectual, but when they untied him he was, of course, greatly beneficial to their people. I do not want to stress the politicising of the bureaucracy that has gone on, Aboriginal land administration which has tied up industry, selective export policies such as the uranium policy, the heritage listing that is going on, or unbalanced environmental policies. The new imposts that have eventuated are industrial democracy-or, as it has been called, employee participation-the national superannuation, affirmative action and equal employment opportunity (EEO). They all sound very good.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you agree with them?

—We are looking for good outcomes. The Minister is asking whether I agree. I do agree with good outcomes, but industrial democracy is hardly off the ground. It has been included in a few pieces of legislation. It was included in the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation Bill, but I do not think I have seen it anywhere else. We will have to watch its progress. Magazines that are sponsored by the Government, promoting industrial democracy, are sent to my office all the time. I am nervous of this because it tends to allow employees to take over the role of management without having to buy the shares. The same applies to national superannuation. It is just on the drawing boards; it has not got off the ground. But affirmative action and equal opportunity have got off the ground and have been in operation throughout all government departments for a couple of years. We are able to assess some of the results.

SPEECH.PARA: Under the equal employment opportunity rules, departments have to put in a report on their activities every year. In recent Estimates committee investigations we were able to assess some of it values. EEO, as it is now known, has been put into several Bills, a couple of which are pending. Shortly a meat Bill will come into the Senate followed by a wheat Bill. Industries need that legislation and are prepared to accept it without too close an examination of its EEO provisions. The Commonwealth says that these provisions will have no effect on Commonwealth income or expenditure and that everything looks hunky-dory. In fact it sounds great. EEO sounds very enlightened, very progressive and very difficult to argue against, particularly when one looks at its aims and objectives. I will read them; they are taken from the Public Service Board's 1985-86 annual report. Of course, the Public Service Board has been disbanded since this report was made. The aims and objectives of EEO are:

To ensure measures are adopted by departments which enable women and members of designated groups (Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders, people of non-English speaking backgrounds and people with disabilities) to compete for promotion and transfer and pursue careers in the service as effectively as other people; To ensure measures are taken by departments to eliminate all forms or unjustified discrimination within the service against the above groups . . .
The word `unjustified' is the operative word and I query who decides what is unjustified. I continue with the aims and objectives of EEO:

To ensure procedures are adopted for appointment, transfer and promotion which preclude discrimination on the grounds of political affiliation, race, colour, ethnic origin, social origin, religion, sex, sexual preference, marital status, pregnancy, age or physical or mental disability.

Honourable senators will note that merit is not mentioned once although it was a matter of considerable debate. I also quote from the explanatory memorandum of the Wheat Marketing Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 which is pending before the Senate:

. . . in particular the definitions of an equal employment opportunity program relate to a program designed to ensure that appropriate action is taken by the Board with respect to employment, to both eliminate discrimination against and promote equal opportunity for, women, Aboriginals, Torres Strait Islanders, migrants and their children, persons who are physically or mentally disabled and any other class of persons prescribed by the Public Service Act 1922.

As I have said, EEO programs have been implemented in government departments for at least the last two years and we are now in a position to assess some of the results. I point out some of the fears we had with the introduction of EEO. One was that quotas or numbers of people would replace targets when employing people, that administration costs would increase, that positive discrimination or affirmative action would apply, that the genuine, red-blooded all-Australian men and women would be discriminated against and that it would create disharmony in the work force. Finally, we were very concerned that merit should be the operative principle by which EEO worked.

I can remember romancing over the niceties of the definitions of what the words `target', `goal', `quota', `affirmative action' and `positive discrimination' meant. Just for clarification I have looked up the definitions-they are short-of the words `quota', `target' and `goal' from the Macquarie Dictionary, the Collins Dictionary and the Oxford Dictionary. I quote them to honourable senators so that they can see the semantic argument we have got ourselves into. The Macquarie definition of the word `quota' is `a proportional part or share of a total which is due from, or is due or belongs to, a particular district, area, person etc. A proportional part or share of a fixed total amount or quantity' or `the number of persons of a particular group allowed to immigrate to a country, join an institution etc'. The Collins Dictionary describes the word `quota' as `a prescribed number or quantity, as of items to be manufactured, imported or exported, immigrants admitted to a country, or students admitted to a college'. The Oxford Dictionary defines `quota' as `a total number or amount required or permitted'. The Macquarie Dictionary's definition of the word `target' is `a goal to be reached'; the Collins Dictionary defines it as `a fixed goal or objective'; and the Oxford Dictionary describes it as `objective or result aimed at'. The Macquarie Dictionary defines the word `goal' as `that towards which effort is directed; an aim, or an end'; the Collins Dictionary describes it as `the aim or object to which an endeavour is directed' and the Oxford Dictionary describes it as `object of effort, destination'.

The people who are trying to implement the EEO program have said that they are aiming at targets, not goals or quotas. However, when one analyses the situation one finds that it is all about numbers and that the words `target', `goal' and `quota' are almost interchangeable. Historically, the term `affirmative action' was introduced during the administration of John F. Kennedy and it meant that the effects of any legislation on minority groups in the United States of America had to be taken into account when implementing such legislation. That was most appropriate for America because it had many minority groups, such as Eskimos, Red Indians, Latinos, Hispanics, Hawaiian Islanders and Japanese. It had many minority groups and it was appropriate that the effects of legislation on these various minority groups should be taken into account. The population mix in the United States is entirely different from that of Australia at the moment. For example, by no means could women in the United States be considered a minority group. Admittedly, there would be women in minority groups but, as a whole, women could not be considered a minority. Above all, affirmative action did not mean that legislation had to be passed in favour of the minority groups; it was merely a matter of estimating what would happen and trying to ameliorate any adverse effects.

The affirmative action lobby in Australia took the Kennedy concept and turned it upside down so that minority groups became disadvantaged groups in which women were included. Under EEO women are the major group to which attention has been turned. Instead of taking into account the effects of legislation on minority groups, it has been changed so that there has to be positive discrimination in favour of disadvantaged groups and women. So we can now look at and analyse the effects of the implementation of EEO policies in Australia today. I refer to the Hansard record of the Estimates Committee D hearing on 29 October 1987 on page D172. I asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs:
You are not working towards a quota, are you?
Mr Taylor-We have set some indicators and some targets through our consultative process with the unions. We do not call them quotas, we call them targets.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could you tell me what the targets are?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Taylor-They are in numerical terms and they relate to the various levels. They are spread over the next two years and are based on anticipated vacancies that might arise at particular levels. Our target is to increase the SES by two over the next two years and we have set similar targets for other levels. For example, in the clerical structure, we have set a target to increase the number of class 10-11 posts by 40 over the next two years. For class 8-9 level the target is 60; for class 6-7 level the target is 150 and for the class 4-5 level it is 200. So far we have only been as specific as that in the clerical areas. We have some difficulty getting to that stage in the hospitals because of the diversity of classifications and the complexities of attempting to do so, but we are working towards targets right across the organisation,

That is just for women. Other categories have to be accommodated by this equal employment opportunity program, such as Aboriginals and Islanders, people with disabilities both physical and mental, migrants and their children and people who have difficulty with English and so on. Here is another quotation:

TALK.START.PARA: —Could we now hear about the women's unit?

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Letts-Women's issues for the Department are handled by a unit in the secretariat section of the Department. Three people in it are directly concerned with women's issues, of whom two are women. The unit is headed by a woman. An example of the things they are involved with is the Budget booklet which is put out each year in relation to women's issues. It is co-ordinated by the Office of the Status of Women. Veterans' Affairs has a place within that. The booklet is prepared by the women's unit in the secretariat section. You probably have read that the Government has decided to provide treatment for those ex-service women . . .
And so it goes on. I use that quotation to point out that there are quotas, numbers and goals.

One of the issues about which we are concerned is costs, and the Government keeps stressing that there is very little cost involved in this. When one considers that there are equal opportunity cells scattered throughout all the Federal Government departments, one realises that there must be considerable costs. I have found out that the EEO program has a network of SHCOs, or sexual harassment contact officers, throughout the departments. There is a national consultative council which meets four times a year, usually in Sydney or Melbourne, and that involves travel costs. Data banks are being formed. That is a trigger term for me. The one being formed at the moment is the sex data bank. It would be intriguing to find out what is in that. Something called PAPAS has been invented-the personnel and pay administration system. That is another computer being loaded up. If people were afraid about the information stored in the identity card system, they should see what will be stored on PAPAS for all Commonwealth public servants. It will be an enormous record of personal details, which will be available, as far as I can see, without any privacy provisions.

Further costs are caused by monitoring the system. Monitoring officers check progress. That process is different from evaluation and is a whole separate part of the EEO provisions. Check sheets for ongoing activities are produced every three months. There is a monthly report on problems, activities and issues. Pamphlets on entitlements have to be produced and circulated to people-for example, pamphlets on maternity have to be circulated to any woman who falls pregnant. On top of that there is evaluation, collation and distribution of the reports. One of the big problems at the moment is how to assess non-women. Only a bureaucrat could think of a word like that. I presume that I am one of them. Another problem is the identification and concentration of target group numbers, and there again we have the quotas rearing their ugly head. The programs have to be updated after every 12-month report. I have a copy of the annual EEO report of the Department of Veterans' Affairs and, for the interest of honourable senators, I seek leave to table the document.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document. Honourable senators want to see how detailed the report is, and it might be of some use.

SPEECH.PARA: That is a list of the sorts of costs involved in running equal opportunity programs within departments, and now it is coming out into legislation and being pushed into the community generally. I understand that certain big organisations, such as the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd, have voluntarily decided to institute EEO programs, thinking that they are enlightened in doing so. I think that it is obvious from what I have said so far that EEO involves positive discrimination and works to the detriment of healthy Australian men and women because it means that fewer jobs are available for them. The EEO cells currently concentrate on replacing people who leave the work force. A committee decides who will replace the person leaving, and EEO principles are used in that process. Obviously, more and more of these groups will be employed and fewer and fewer positions will be available to healthy men and women.

Another of the considerations that worried us was disharmony in the work force. I have made inquiries and even spoken to employees in departments where these policies are in place to find out whether there is disharmony in the work force. There is, but a lot of it is covert because people feel that they should not complain. For example, they find it difficult working with deaf people or people whose physical disabilities are such that they cannot stack a file of paper. I have employed handicapped people myself-I went through a period of doing this sort of thing-and I know that they have their own frustrations and they can exhibit rebound irritability, which can cause trouble at the work place. When people with disabilities have jobs, they tend to want to have the whole job organised around their disabilities and to change the whole system to suit them. That is happening where EEO policies are being implemented now.

For example, we have all had experience of rush hour at the airport where men and women are accepting luggage and checking people on to planes. The women just cannot work as hard and as fast as the men, so everybody queues up at the men's desks so that they can get on the plane quicker. So the women do not have so much work to do, but they get the same amount of pay. That creates disharmony. Many of the problems are small, such as repeating instructions for deaf people, but they create irritability and there can also be this rebound irritability from those with disabilities. I would not want anybody to think that I do not have charity in my heart and that I do not want to help. For 30 years, I have been an employer, mainly of women, in a hospital. I had another business where I had mainly men working for me but I found that they were no good and had to replace them with women, because the job was more suitable for women.

The Government has an enormous conflict here between its policies and the costs that industry already has. It is now being inflicted with a whole lot of other unnecessary on-costs. As time has gone on and we have grown up, things have changed. My father was one of a family of three brothers and three sisters. The three sisters stayed at home while the brothers went to university, but all their children, whether boys or girls, have been given a university education. The effluxion of time has taken care of a lot of this, without having any organisation legitimised by law. The Government has a conflict because it is asking us to export, to compete, to be leaner and harder and all these things, while putting lead in our saddle bags so that industry can hardly raise a trot.

I support the amendment foreshadowed by Senator Stone. I sincerely hope that somebody will heed the words that those unrepresentative organisations which are benefiting from the Government and are now being used by the Government to actively promote its own ends should somehow be taken off the backs of our industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to speak to the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) and Appropriation Bill (No. 2), I feel like the last batsman going in to bat at the end of an innings. Most of what can be said has already been said. However, I was very happy to see that the names of a few more honourable senators were added to the speakers list before the Minister speaks in reply. As we debate the three Bills, it is timely to reflect on where we are going. The Hawke-Keating Government has failed continually to face up to the real problems and issues and the need for adequate and timely adjustment. Why is Australia in the situation it faces? After all, Australia has many natural resources, fertile soil, minerals and products of the sea and, above all, willing and able, healthy people. One of the reasons is that for far too long Australia has relied on its primary industries to keep up with the rest of the world. I include minerals and energy in my interpretation of primary industries.

SPEECH.PARA: In reflecting on what has gone on in Australia, I have taken a 15-year cycle dating back to approximately 1973. There are various cycles-daily, weekly, 28-day, yearly and so on-but I have chosen a 15-year cycle. In 1973 we were hit with spiralling oil prices caused by the oil crisis. We overcame that crisis, but it was not the only disaster that hit us in 1973. The oil crisis set many other things in motion. When the wheat crop was planted in 1973 we expected an average return of $50 a tonne. By the time it was harvested, we received $104 a tonne. That was the beginning of a prosperous era. Lately, our wheat crop has been going through a downturn, but yesterday's Australian Financial Review showed some optimism. It stated:
In January the listed price for Australian Standard White wheat was $US105 a tonne . . . and has risen to $US117.

That has occurred, while plantings are down. So we can see that there is some bright area around the corner. In 1973, an academic at the University of Western Australia, Dr Schapper, who is a reader in agricultural economics, told us all to wind up our wheat growing operations and plant trees or something like that. One can see what has happened since then. A result of the world oil crisis in 1973 was to make synthetics more expensive and, therefore, wool returned to its rightful place on the market. In 1971, when the then Liberal Government was trying to get a wool commission going, we were told by another academic-unfortunately, I cannot remember his name-that wool had had it; it was a thing of the past and we should forget about it. We can see for ourselves what has happened since then. The Australian Wool Corporation did come into being and that is probably the only thing for which I give the Whitlam Government credit.

In 1982 we saw the beginning of the present gold boom. Since that year, production, in dollar value terms, has increased fivefold. There are continuing finds. Again, I quote from yesterday's Australian Financial Review:
Broken Hill Metals NL has discovered more gold at its Hopes Hill . . . in the Yilgarn goldfields . . . while at Hopes Hill a 27 metre interval was discovered that averaged 17 g/t-

that is, 17 grams a tonne. That is a find of some significance. That is just one of a large number of small shows in Western Australia and throughout Australia and it is estimated that it will produce 70,000 ounces a year, worth $49m. The price of wool rose sharply this year. Wool is about to regain its position as Australia's biggest commodity export earner-passing coal.

The lower dollar value has allowed us to procrastinate on facing up to the day of reckoning-the day that the pigeons will come home to roost. Primary industry income, which makes up 85.5 per cent of Australia's income, has insulated us from the realities. The Government has been spending to keep in favour with its supporters. Its own Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) has sounded repeated warnings that have not been heeded. He has told us about the Argentinean road. He sounded various warnings to the Labor Lawyers Conference in Perth. He can see these things. He can see them because, like me, he has been there and has done that. To a certain extent, before he became a senator, he risked his own dollar. Senator McKiernan can grin as much as he likes.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is enough of the hero worship.

—I do not mind giving credit where credit is due, although I am unable to do so very often. That is why Senator Walsh can see these things. I do not know why the Government has not heeded what he has said. The result of this excessive spending to keep in favour is a record national debt of $105 billion-I repeat: $105 billion. With all the production we have now, we can repay only the interest. Anyone can see that we are slipping down the ladder and cannot keep up with our competitors. Where has the manufacturing industry been in this endeavour to get us out of the mire? The manufacturing industry has been hamstrung by union demands for more wages, better conditions and shorter hours. The industry's productivity cannot sustain those demands, which are far above those made in other countries.

SPEECH.PARA: I shall give Senator McKiernan a typical example of productivity which occurred last week. As honourable senators probably know, I am endeavouring to build a regional office in the Western Australian country. I found that as no such office was already available, the only solution was to build one. Having got the project going I had to journey to Perth for a load of bricks. That order had been placed well beforehand and was documented with order numbers, et cetera. I arrived at the gate of the brickworks at 9 o'clock and gave the order number and my name. I had not been heard of, but that was quite okay with me. However, I was told that there was no such order. After spending an hour on and off the phone trying to locate the builder in order to ascertain to whom he gave the building order, I established that he had given it to X. When X was hauled to the front counter he said, `Yes, I took that message but I forgot to put it in the book'. Instead of loading up with bricks at 9 o'clock, I loaded up at 12 o'clock. That is the sort of attitude to productivity that one encounters.

TALK.START.PARA: —What brickworks was that?
—I do not want to harm anyone's reputation by mentioning it here.
—Oh!
—All right, I will tell the honourable senator. It was the Midland Brick Co. Pty Ltd. I ask whether that satisfies the honourable senator?
—Yes.
—I know that that is music to the honourable senator's ears. It was the Midland Brick Company.
—You can see why we need a new one.
—No, I cannot. In these hard times the Government has supported a first tier wage rise of, I understand, $7 a week. It has also supported the second tier wage rise of $4 a week.
—Four per cent.

—Right. Australia is attempting to keep up a standard which we cannot afford. We are doing this by ever increased spending. The young expect to start off where their parents left off. This morning I heard Senator Wood speak of how disadvantaged the youth of Australia is today. I know that there are some disadvantaged youth today. I know that there are some very disadvantaged young people. Unfortunately, we are not all in the position of having good parents. However, I maintain that the majority of young people are well looked after. These people must accept their position in life until they are in a position to do something about it and to improve their circumstances. I am criticising not only the youth of this country but also the adults. These people also expect to have the sort of living standard of some other people in the country, for example, people who are on lemonade wages such as ourselves in here or on big solicitors' or doctors' wages. Once again, I think that they should accept their position until they can work their way out of it.

SPEECH.PARA: Once upon a time, when I was young, if a family got a car it was regarded as well off. Now it seems that everyone expects not one car but two cars. Now it has got to the stage where every family must have a four-wheel drive-mainly used to destroy our parks and beaches, et cetera. There is no greater reason for this than that everyone else has such a vehicle. I suppose that Senator McKiernan did not know that sometimes I am an environmentalist at heart. More and more money is owed on the plastic cards. On 31 December 1986 we owed $1,492 for every man, woman and child. That did not include the amount owed for housing. I understand the debt is now around $2,000.

The stock market crash has shown what can really happen. If the situation gets any worse we could find ourselves in total depression, thus affecting the sale of our export commodities. That would be a total disaster. Even our primary industries, about which I have been speaking, would not carry us out of that situation. I will quote from the Budget Speech presented in the Senate this year by the Minister for Finance.
He said:
Mr President, I have described tonight how Australia is successfully responding to the most adverse external economic difficulty we have faced since the Great Depression nearly 60 years ago.

That statement was made before the stock market crash. If we want to take into consideration the stock market crash, I think we must go back 160 years to find a worse situation. Australia has to get back to work. It has been done before. It was done pre-war and post-war. It was done during the Great Depression and after. Above all, Australians must start saving money. Australia has a big unemployment problem-8 per cent. However, a lot of able-bodied people can be employed, although such employment may not be at their doorstep. I know that many people are unemployed because of no fault of their own. I refer here especially to people over 45 years who have a wealth of experience. I have been an employer for most of my life. I have always prided myself on the fact that behind my stern face I have a heart of stone. However, even I can see that there are problems and that we have to work to get rid of them.

There are far too many unemployed people in urban areas who would rather remain unemployed than take jobs in inland areas which remain unfilled. Of course, this is not an across the board situation, but nevertheless it exists. I mention, for example, jobs in agriculture and mining. Australian farmers are the most efficient in the world. Figures show that our productivity per head in agriculture is 2 1/2 times that of Great Britain, over three times that of Germany, 1 1/2 times that of the United States and 6 1/2 times that of Japan. Australian miners also are efficient. They are 1.67 times more efficient than miners in Britain, 2.4 more than Germany and 1.29 more than Japan.

While I am on the subject of mining, and in case I move past this point in my notes, I would like to express my great disappointment at the honourable member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe), who is one of two people lately who have called for the reintroduction of the gold tax. As I said in my maiden speech, if people spent time in the gold areas, especially those of Western Australia, in order to see what gold is doing for the economy, they would not countenance the idea of imposing another gold tax, especially at this time when it is providing so much foreign income and employment.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is the second biggest export now, is it not?

—Yes, that is right. I thank Senator Messner. Manufacturing industry could take a look at the efficiency of these mining and agricultural industries. Also, if the unions and the Government agreed, wages policy for young people who are still in the learning process should be looked at. I think that it is far better to take a bit less for a short while in order to finish up with a lot more in the long run. Can any honourable senator tell me why it is that loader drivers, who work in what is regarded as a semi-skilled occupation and in air conditioned comfort, can earn in excess of $1,000 per week on mining sites? As everyone knows, that is in excess of what back benchers in this place earn. I can tell honourable senators why it is that such drivers earn so much: the jobs cannot be filled. Probably the job of a loader driver could be done by three men at $330 a week. Instead, people appear to be more content to remain unemployed in order to stay close to the beaches. High unemployment, in Western Australia at least, seems to be in the best beach areas of Margaret River and Broome. High non-employment is in the goldfields. Just lately in local government we advertised for a shire clerk. This was for a position 375 kilometres from the city and for a salary of $45,000 per annum. There were no applications. All facilities were provided. The only thing that we have not got up there is the beaches.

SPEECH.PARA: Australians have too much time off. That probably includes those of us in this chamber. Australian workers are paid for the 57 days they do not work each year, while American workers are still on 19 days. The Swiss have got their own set-up. I understand the referendum that the Swiss want has already been mentioned in this chamber. We have to get back to work until things get better.

I will refer briefly to work practices and then I will refer to management practices. Work practices is nothing other than two people and, in some cases, three people getting paid to do one job. From the employer side, management practices is an excuse to give in to keep things moving. Some managers give in at all costs. Australia must tighten its belt. If we have not got it, we should not spend it. This takes us back to the handbag economics system which is quoted fairly often by Wilson Tuckey but practised by myself. In essence, if it is not in the bag we should not spend it. It might make some people aghast to know that I run a farm that crops 15,000 acres and runs 15,000 sheep and I do not have a written budget; it is all mainly in my head. I believe in having the money in the bag before one spends it. We must return to thrift and honesty. People must do a day's work for a day's pay. Honesty cuts across a lot of facets of life. If we are honest we do not steal someone else's wife or steal someone's car, but if we take wages without earning them or if we employ people without paying them adequately we are stealing and that is dishonest. As our efficiency figures show, the work ethic has not been completely lost in the areas of mining and agriculture; it has only been misplaced. Australia has got to get up and go, but the Government has got to give it the lead and take tough decisions. After all, the election is behind the Government.

So far I have mainly spoken about doom and gloom. We have to recognise the facts. If we recognise the facts and get on with the job at hand, the doom and gloom will disappear. I will use the example of an alcoholic belonging to Alcoholics Anonymous. Fortunately, I have never been an alcoholic. I rue the day when I cannot drink at all. I understand the biggest problem with alcoholics is recognising that they are alcoholics. Similarly, the biggest problem with Australia is recognising that we are in strife. The sooner we recognise and accept that we are in strife the sooner we can move. We have to be reliable suppliers.

Let me refer to the waterfront. I understand the waterfront of Fremantle has the highest penalty loading on ships in the Western world. We rate the same as the Arabian Gulf and that is in a war zone. In other words, ship owners require a high premium because of the doubt as to when they will get the ships back. We have to do something about that. We have to get efficiency back on the waterfront. I will not bore the Senate with figures that were quoted yesterday about the New South Wales waterfront, but the workers are loading 17,000 tonnes per employee. In America, with the same equipment, the figure is 100,000 tonnes. Of course, the Americans do things their own way. A simple example that was used and put in front of the McColl Royal Commission into Grain Storage, Handling and Transport was that in New South Wales the conveyors were shut down every smoko. With all the employees around these conveyors it was a simple method to stagger the morning and afternoon tea breaks and let the conveyors flow. I understand that has been done.

The failure of the Hawke Government is shown in our vulnerability to sudden change in world economic conditions at this time of crisis. The Government has squandered time and resources and has run Australia into massive debts. As I have already explained, Australia is in debt by $105 billion. All we can afford to pay is the interest. The Government must move to prevent further disaster.

I support Senator Stone's foreshadowed amendment. I know that it has been repeated by every speaker who has risen in this debate. I apologise, but I have to repeat it again. If honourable senators on the other side of the chamber are frightened I will bore them to tears, I will stress the main part, which reads:

. . . because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options . . .

I have given the Senate all the reasons, as have other speakers, why we are at a crisis point. We can only point them out, but it is up to the Government to take heed because as Premier Burke says in Western Australia time and again, not all the bright ideas come from the Government side. I do not think all the bright ideas come from the Government side in this chamber. I ask the Government to take that on board.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would like to concentrate my remarks on the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill 1987-88, Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 and Appropriation Bill (No. 2) 1987-88 to those areas that come within my brief on disarmament and social justice. There are three areas that I wish to concentrate on, starting with the decision to allocate 9.5 per cent of the Budget outlay to defence, which, in turn, represents almost 3 per cent of gross domestic product. There will always be members of our society who believe that the Government should give defence a higher priority when it comes to Budget allocations. It is ironical that the people who urge greater defence spending are also those who call for lower government spending. I do not understand how they would purchase multi-billion dollar battle fleets complete with aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines along with giving pay increases to the armed services and bringing back conscription.

SPEECH.PARA: When I consider the cutbacks in the Budget in the last year which have obviously affected the underprivileged more than the affluent in Australia along with cuts in overseas aid, which have affected the poorer nations of the world, I feel more strongly than ever that the one area where we could obviously meet people's real security needs is by reducing defence expenditure. In doing so we would be following the example of countries such as China and Peru which have also reduced their defence expenditure this past year to give priority to domestic needs. That is a welcome note of sanity in a world where everyone seems bent on escalating the global arms race and making us all more insecure than ever.

As an article in the Sydney Morning Herald on 14 September pointed out, global military expenditure in the International Year of Peace reached $US900 billion. Those who argue that nuclear weapons and the United States bases in Australia have maintained world peace for 40 years need to remember that 35 million people have been killed in wars since 1945, as many people as died during that war, and that today some 40 wars are being waged around the world. However, I do not accept that it is not simply a question of further paring the current defence outlay. I am suggesting that only a fundamentally different approach to defence could allow for the cuts I am recommending.

As a Quaker and a pacifist I have always said that my personal preference is for a system of national defence based on social non-violence. But that prophetic position has to be tempered by political realism. In arguing for a strategy of transarmament I speak today for a system of non-offensive defence, or defensive defence, that would still allow for substantial reductions. This would have to be coupled with a new approach to strengthening international security and peacekeeping mechanisms and alternative forms of conflict resolution. I would like to recommend to honourable senators the United Nations Association of Australia initiative entitled `The Bilateral Peace Treaties Proposal'. I seek leave to table this document, which has been put out by the United Nations.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I table the document. The United Nations bilateral peace treaties proposal is an area where the Government could be spending a lot of energy. It would not cost very many dollars but a lot of energy would be needed to create a climate of peaceful attitudes between Australia and all other countries which are members of the United Nations. I quote briefly from the document, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: Australia is in a unique position to make a significant contribution to world peace by offering to each nation-state in the world a Bilateral Peace Treaty containing just two proposals:
1. We will settle all disputes between us by negotiation or other peaceful means.
2. We will never be the first to resort to force, violence or war.

Such bilateral peace treaties would go a long way towards creating a climate of peace and negotiation between all countries. Presumably other countries would be encouraged to follow Australia's lead in this regard.

I note that in the last few years a large part of defence expenditure has gone on covering depreciation of the dollar with respect to overseas capital equipment purchases. A quarter of last year's defence budget was committed to ongoing equipment purchases, with around 85 per cent of the total overseas imports of capital equipment coming from the United States of America. I gather that Australia now comes second only to Saudi Arabia in terms of having such a high percentage of defence imports from the United States. Without needing to remind honourable senators of the way in which the Reagan Administration treats Australia on other matters, such as trade, I seriously question the need to buy such sophisticated and expensive equipment from the United States, in particular the $35m allocated to each FA18 tactical fighter. That program involves a total price of $4,411m. A strategy of non-offensive defence would place much more emphasis on equipment that we could make in Australia, which would suit our own defence needs, instead of buying expensive guided missile frigates as well as the FA18s whose main role is to lock us into United States strategic needs in the region and not be concerned with the defence of Australia. It is particularly foolish to depend so heavily on the United States, not only when it undercuts our economy by trading its surplus wheat to our alleged common enemy at reduced prices, but also when it refuses to buy more than a trifle of defence equipment from Australia in return.

It is significant that people in the farming community traditionally associated with the conservative side of politics are now also beginning to question the value of the United States alliance. I note, too, the article that appeared in the Australian Financial Review magazine last month on our new submarines which made the point that somewhere between $500m and $1 billion could have been saved if the capability for espionage activities performed on behalf of the Americans were dropped. The article stated that the Royal Australian Navy has had to confront the fact that the United States finds far more use in our having conventional submarines than nuclear submarines, provided they have the range to get to the Soviet bases in the northern Pacific and stay on silent patrol there. I would very much appreciate hearing from the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) what Australian submarines patrolling in the north-west Pacific have to do with the defence of Australia and why Australian taxpayers should subsidise dangerously provocative activities of this kind. For example, of what relevance to Australia's defence is the chasing of United States nuclear submarines off the coast of Hawaii in joint exercises conducted there last year, which cost the Australian taxpayer millions of dollars, but which were conducted well outside our area of strategic interest as defined by the defence White Paper.

Another area where we could save a great deal is the totally unnecessary move of the Royal Australian Navy from Sydney Harbour to Jervis Bay, a move that will ultimately cost more than $1 billion. The Navy does not want to go, and Navy families do not want to go as there is little prospect of jobs in the area, so there could be more resignations if the move goes ahead. The locals do not want the expansion of current facilities in what is a very beautiful area, the fragile ecology of which would be irreparably damaged by the massive intrusion planned by the Department of Defence. In fact, the only people who do seem to want the move are a handful of bureaucrats in the Department of Defence.

Although I think the Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities and the defence White Paper were steps in the right direction, apart from their continued involvement in, and commitment to, the ANZUS nuclear alliance, I believe that the community debate must cover wider security needs. The Dibb report was not meant to go beyond its brief, so it is up to parliamentarians and the citizens of Australia, who have to pay for all this military equipment, to ask some very fundamental questions about what constitutes security in the nuclear age. This is especially so in an area to the north of which a regional arms race is grossly distorting economic priorities. This is occurring in both Indo-China and some Association of South East Asian Nation (ASEAN) states. In Indo-China, Vietnam boasts the fifth largest army in the world and, in some ASEAN states, military expenditure increased by a massive 159 per cent between 1974 and 1983. Thailand's expenditure increased by 145 per cent, as did expenditure in Singapore.

I would rather see a reduction in expenditure on expensive items like the FA18s which, on current estimates, will cost this country $4.4 billion, and an increase in measures which would contribute far more to both national and international security, such as more training of our diplomats in negotiating skills and conflict resolution, along with an increase in language training. For the cost of one FA18 the Government would be able to develop the Peace Research Centre at the Australian National University and establish other such research centres around the country, developing more effective models of international conflict resolution and national security rather than increased investment in more lethal military hardware, the end result of which is to kill people if a perceived need arises.

What baffles me about those who would spend more on defence and invest in aircraft carriers and nuclear submarines is why they think this will make Australia more secure. If we invest in this equipment, other countries in our region will feel the need to arm themselves even further as well. This could result in a rapidly developing arms race, which is hardly guaranteed to make anyone feel more secure.

Security in our region ought to be seen more in economic terms than in military terms, so I find it appalling that the Government has seen fit to reduce overseas aid to 0.36 per cent of gross national product (GNP), the lowest figure for 21 years. This is likely to take us below the forthcoming 1987 average for the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) countries and ranks us with countries notorious for their meanness, like the United States, the United Kingdom, Switzerland and Japan.

I remember the original Australian Labor Party (ALP) promise to allocate 0.7 per cent of GNP to overseas aid and the ALP Conference decision in Hobart which aspired to a goal of 0.55 per cent by 1990. I note that it is now about half of the original goal of 0.7 per cent, though the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) rationalises the latest cuts by saying that the figure is still above the current average of 0.35 per cent for OECD states. The state of our economy is no real excuse, given that other countries with unhealthy economies, for example, Norway, the Netherlands, Sweden and Denmark, have passed the 0.7 per cent mark.

As I observed just now, real security in our region means economic security, not military security, particularly for the island states of the Pacific. It does not make sense to increase military aid and cut economic aid, or to tell the Japanese to provide aid because the United States and Australia can no longer afford it. Aid is not an automatic outflow from Australia; around 80 per cent of it comes back to this country in the form of orders for goods or services or international consultancies. Our farmers benefit from the extensive food aid program and honourable senators can see how much this is worth if they read Budget-related Paper No. 4. Australia has taken an up-front position in support of the frontline states in southern Africa, yet we have reduced our aid to those countries when they most desperately need it, particularly Mozambique.

Nearer home, both India and Bangladesh are currently suffering from food shortages due to cyclones. Our economy looks positively healthy compared to their economy and the economies of many of our neighbours. In 1983 Australia ranked thirteenth in the world out of 142 countries in terms of per capita GNP income and eighth in economic social standing-that is, where the three factors of GNP per capita, education and health are combined.

I am firmly convinced that if Australia were to make regional security its priority instead of its present commitment to an offensive nuclear alliance for which ANZUS now stands, we could not only redirect what money we have, but substantially cut the defence budget and allocate resources to the poorer sections of the Australian community as well as overseas. I raise these issues not only because I want to question our priorities in government expenditure but also because I think we need to rethink our whole notion of security; that is, security for whom, and how do we achieve it?
I am glad that the Government has pledged to eradicate child poverty by 1990 though I note with some alarm that in the Governor-General's Speech the revised statement read:
. . . by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty.
I note that child poverty overall has increased since the Labor Government came to office in 1983, as Senator Coulter reminded honourable senators in his superb first speech on 21 September.

Considering again the concept of security, particularly with reference to sole parent families, I also note the speech by Julian Disney of the Australian Council of Social Service at the national Labor Lawyers Conference on 19 September, in which he said:
The number of people living below the Henderson poverty line, which is the most widely used measure in Australia, has more than doubled since the mid 70's and is now in excess of two million.

This year, 1987, is also the International Year of Shelter for the Homeless, identifying again another group of disadvantaged people whose concept of security is more likely to be economic than military. I am not surprised that the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is holding a national inquiry into homeless children-announced on 22 September in Sydney-as I have seen so many articles about homelessness among young people, especially in the big cities.

According to the 1984 Department of Housing and Construction study of homelessness and inadequate housing there are approximately 40,000 Australians who live out of doors or in refuges. The study also showed that there are 700,000 Australian households living below the poverty line after paying rent or mortgage costs, a figure confirmed by a study by the social welfare research unit attached to Sydney University. The latter research also shows that housing-related poverty has almost doubled in the last decade, rising from 6.6 per cent in 1972-73 to 11.1 per cent in 1981-82. Any genuine study of housing policies designed to lead to adequate housing for all in Australia must face the fact that more than two million citizens are inadequately housed.

As we approach the somewhat embarrassing Bicentenary, which should be used as a soul-searching exercise about our past and our future, we should be re-evaluating our current goals and aspirations and, I believe, setting some new directions for this country. Until we acknowledge formally, as a nation, Aboriginal people's prior claim to this land, we will neither have, nor deserve, harmony in the Australian community. It has taken the tragic deaths of 67 Aboriginal men and women in custody over recent years to finally focus the attention of the nation on the appalling rate of Aboriginal incarceration-symptomatic of grave problems facing our indigenous people. However, the issues cannot be treated as Aboriginal problems, but as problems to be shared by all of us.

It is a national disgrace, which diminishes us all, that Aboriginal people who lived proudly, with dignity and in harmony with this harsh environment for 30,000 years or more before the arrival of Europeans have suffered so gravely and that most of them continue to suffer appalling degradation. The Muirhead Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody will reveal some very unpleasant aspects of relationships between Aboriginal and non-Aboriginal people in this country. We need to know the worst, particularly in the bicentenary year, in the hope that community attitudes towards our Aboriginal brothers and sisters will change so that non-Aboriginal Australians will feel moved to grant self-determination to Aboriginal people-to listen to their voices.

How outrageous it is that on the eve of the Bicentenary, and on the eve of World Expo 88 in Brisbane, Don Neal, Minister for Corrective Services in Queensland, has seen fit to re-open the black hole at Boggo Road prison in case of Aboriginal protests. Maybe these underground cells would not be used only for Aboriginal troublemakers. But for whomever they are intended, they are not fit for human habitation. The Royal Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals would be justified in prosecuting anyone keeping animals under such conditions.

Where is the compassion in our society? It is sadly lacking in that case, and in many cases relating to Aboriginal people. Maybe the Minister for Corrective Services needs to be reminded that the use of such cells would contravene article 10 of the International Covenant of Civil and Political Rights, and article 5 of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights, both of which have been ratified by Australia. It would also place Queensland in contravention of article 21 of the Minimum Standard Guidelines for Australian Prisons.

Although this is a State matter for the Queensland Government to decide, that Government must be persuaded by concerted action from concerned citizens around the country that such behaviour is unacceptable on moral and humanitarian grounds.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.45 p.m. the debate is interrupted in accordance with sessional order 106a. The Senate will now proceed with the debate on matters of public interest.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to make certain remarks about a report which was circulated in this Parliament some time ago and on which a number of people missed the opportunity of making a contribution. I refer to the Constitutional Commission's Advisory Committee on Executive Government. It struck me when reading that report that in most of the areas of the Constitution that were examined, the Committee actually recommended no change to current practice. This is from a body which was actually set up by a government which seeks to radically alter the Constitution and it attests, I believe, to the integrity of the Chairman of the Executive Government Advisory Committee, Sir Zelman Cowen, and of some of his colleagues.

SPEECH.PARA: I was pleased to see that the Committee recommended no move towards republicanism and admitted that the form of the constitutional monarchy which this country has is the finest around. I was also pleased to note that the committee supported the Westminster system, stating that it be retained. I think it is sobering to look at the two countries that have actually dismantled or are dismantling the Westminster practice; I refer to South Africa and Zimbabwe.

South Africa, of course, has polarised even the more radical tensions in that country and the second dismantling, of course, is swiftly leading to an entrenched one-party Marxist state in Zimbabwe. The Executive Government booklet also refers favourably to the appointment of Assistant Ministers and recommends an added provision to the Constitution to allow such appointments. I think it is a pity that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) did not wait until this report came out before recommending that the Governor-General appoint the current dual ministerial system. We saw recently just how quickly this sort of half-baked proposal can become unstuck when a so-called senior Minister in this place, Senator Evans, and his so-called junior, Mr Duncan, contradicted each other in the Parliament. The fact remains that the Prime Minister must realise that both Senator Evans and Mr Duncan have a sworn responsibility for the whole of the Department of Transport and Communications and in law, regardless of any administrative arrangements, both men are responsible for all aspects of the portfolios that they represent.

I turn now to the Committee's discussion about the power of the Senate to reject Supply. This is naturally a very sensitive issue in this place and I recommend all honourable senators and others interested in such things to read the proposal suggested to the 1978 Constitutional Convention by Sir Charles Court, which the Committee outlines on page 26. Sir Charles suggests that as an alternative to removing the power of the Senate to block supply a double dissolution should be held if the Senate rejects or fails to pass the Supply Bill within 30 days. Now the last occasion on which the Senate failed to pass Supply led to a general election. The result of that election totally vindicated the actions of the coalition in this chamber. This power should not be removed as the Committee has recommended. I believe that Sir Charles Court's proposal has some merit which deserves further consideration.

One thing that has disappointed me is that this Executive Government booklet fails to examine what I believe to be the most serious threat to parliamentary democracy, as we are concerned. This is the steady encroachment of the Executive. Under governments of all political colours, the Prime Minister and the Ministers have reduced the role of the private member or the senator. All too often in this place, and also in the House of Representatives, Question Time has degenerated. I think yesterday was a typical case. On one hand, Government members are provided with dorothy dix questions and allow Ministers to comment on some aspects of policy, or at least they tell a Minister that they are going to ask a question on a particular topic.

In fact, yesterday I was chastised for not telling a Minister beforehand of a question in relation to a skin cancer topic having regard to the fact that this week is skin cancer week; I should have referred the matter earlier to a Senate Estimates committee, or I should have at least told him about it and, in any event, he had no brief. I find that totally inappropriate in a week which is skin cancer week. On the other hand, I believe that the Ministry tends to be defensive about all questions that come from the Opposition, even those genuinely trying to get some information. Very rarely are private senator's or private member's Bills even committed to any sort of debate, although on some occasions the object of the Bill may be worthy. I should imagine that Senator Vallentine would be supporting me on this score.

I believe that the serious results of the Executive's increasing grip on Parliament merits some examination and I would have thought that the Executive Government Committee could have examined this aspect. As another illustration, I refer to the decimation of the Public Accounts Committee. We talk about the need to maintain the independence of Parliament, and how important that is, but the staff of that Committee was reduced, without reference to that Committee, without reference to the Opposition, and without reference to the Deputy Chairman of that Committee. The resources were suddenly taken away, from 15 down to five, and they are expected to carry out their previous tasks. This is what I referred to as the steady encroachment by the Executive. The Executive provides the resources to the Committee, and if the committees of the Parliament are starved of their resources, they are not going to operate in a fair and independent way.

Perhaps it is the independence of that Committee that the Government has most to fear, because in the new range of committees that it is setting up, most of the references are going to be given by Ministers to the committees. The Constitutional Commission was established by the Government despite the opposition of the coalition and many academics and jurors. This report shows that there is a lot of time wasted and expense incurred for no real gain other than a self-indulgent critique of the Australian Constitution, as is obvious by the very few and flimsy recommendations the Committee eventually made and its begrudging acceptance that most of the present constitutional provisions seem to work. The Government continually reminds us of the economic state that Australia is in; at the same time it funded a costly inquiry which really has achieved very little. I believe the money could have been better spent elsewhere.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, in March of this year a Queensland student made application for independent status under Austudy on the basis of homelessness. The student claimed that due to a breakdown in her relationship with her father she was unable to live at home. Various declarations were tendered to support the application. In July the Department of Employment, Education and Training ruled that the student was not eligible to receive Austudy at the independent rate. My first comment in this case is on the Department's inordinate delay in arriving at this decision.

SPEECH.PARA: In August, the student approached me asking that I support her request for a reassessment of this decision. After informing myself of the relevant facts I considered that her request for a reassessment deserved my full support. I therefore wrote to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and argued that her academic ability would be severely limited if she was forced to live at home with her father. I requested that the matter be given urgent consideration, taking into account the special circumstances of the case.

If the Department did treat the matter as urgent it would apparently take forever to make a decision on a matter regarded as not urgent. It was not until early November that I received a response dated 30 October from the Department. It is worth noting that the Department could not even be bothered to send me a personal reply. Officers of that Department apparently considered it acceptable to send a copy of a reply that they sent to one of my colleagues. While the Department may consider this to be acceptable, I do not. The departmental officer who signed the letter expressed his concern that the homelessness provision should not be abused and that only genuinely needy cases be approved. It was claimed that for this reason the Department is required to:
Administer the homelessness provisions in accordance with strict guidelines and to approve independence only where sufficient evidence has been furnished.

The evidence presented by the student to support her reasons for leaving home was found to be not of `substantial nature'. According to the Department applicants must establish that the nature of family conflict is:
exceptional rather than the expected types of friction occurring in many families where students have not become independent of their families because of tertiary studies.

As the student could not provide any additional information to support her request for reconsideration and as she had been forced for financial reasons to return to live in the family home, her application on the ground of homelessness was deemed to have lapsed. I am not satisfied that in this case justice was done. Those who knew this student were of the opinion that she should not have been forced to live at home. Her doctor confirmed that such a living arrangement would have a detrimental effect on her mental well being.

Furthermore, the application was rejected despite strongly supportive evidence from the Department's social worker in Brisbane. Is the homelessness provision of any use if, as in this instance, smug central bureaucrats with snug homes to return to each evening are able to overrule the decisions, of well-informed local officers? While the Department claims to be concerned about the difficulties faced by the many young people in this situation, it does not seem willing to act on these concerns. It would appear that in an attempt to prevent the possible abuse of the system, some highly deserving applicants are being severely disadvantaged. It is my belief that the student to whom I am referring was such an applicant and that she should have had every right to be considered favourably. The departmental officers in Canberra who rejected her plight deserve severe condemnation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak for a few minutes today about an issue which is emerging as one of national importance.
