It involves the three areas that I have been elected to represent-peace, social justice and the environment. I am concerned about the Rudall River National Park area in Western Australia. It is located approximately 500 kilometres south-east of Port Hedland in the eastern Pilbara region. Following the recommendations of the Australian Academy of Science in 1963 and the Western Australia Conservation Through Reserves Committee in 1974, it was gazetted as a national park in April 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: The Conservation Through Reserves Committee cited the need for the unique habitats in the Little Sandy, Great Sandy and Gibson deserts to be represented in a system of reserves. The gazettal of the Rudall River National Park was therefore a major step in the conservation of desert ecosystems, particularly as it is the only national park in Australia that encompasses an entire seasonal river system in the arid zone. This system, dry except during rare cyclonic activity, is the remains of a vast inland swamp, part of a verdant rainforest from some 200 years ago. A range of vegetation groups is represented and all are dependent on the intermittent occurrence of water. Regeneration after disturbance is therefore tied to good falls of rain. In addition, the area is extremely vulnerable to the removal of ground cover, because of wind erosion and erosion caused by sporadic intense rainfall.

In addition to the Conservation Through Reserves Committee and the Academy of Science's recognition of Rudall River as an area of outstanding conservation significance, it is included on the register of the National Estate, a further measure of the park's importance to the natural heritage of this country. The assessments of these expert committees stand in direct contrast to myths propagated by the Western Australian Minister for Mines and Energy, Mr David Parker, that Rudall River was gazetted for purely political reasons by the previous State Government. But it is surely one that warms the hearts of CRA Ltd executives. It is clear that CRA and the mining industry in Western Australia have a strong advocate in Mr Parker. The question is: who is standing up for the natural and cultural heritage values of the park itself on behalf of the people of Australia?

The public first became aware of mining related activities in and around Rudall River National Park following the appearance of an article in the Australian Financial Review on 4 December 1985. The article led to further investigation by the Australian Conservation Foundation which indicated that exploration was being carried out inside the park boundary. In Western Australia mineral explorations and mining are permitted in national parks, because the Mines Act overrides the National Park Act. The current controversy over the State Government's mining and national parks policy review, better known as the Bailey report, was somewhat of a farce, in that the option of not allowing mining at all in these special areas was not considered.

In addition to Rudall River's natural conservation values there is another aspect to this area's history and significance. Although archaeological investigation in the Rudall River region is still in progress, preliminary indications suggest that Aborigines have been living in the Great Sandy and Gibson deserts for well over 10,000 years. Much of our knowledge of the region comes from the Western Desert people who were removed only three decades ago and who in recent years have been moving back to their traditional country. Survival in such an arid environment requires very careful attention to seasonal fluctuations and ecological diversity. The Rudall River and the chain of salt lakes were crucial economic registers in this round of daily and seasonal life, and figure prominently in the social and cultural geography of Western Desert religious belief. Dreaming tracks, the paths of mythological ancestors, criss-cross the region, and ceremonial life revolved around periodic gatherings of large numbers of people when conditions warranted.

Today, these water resources are still the lifeblood of Western Desert people who have moved back to their own country inside of Rudall River National Park, to the communities of Punmu, Pangurr and recently Kalkan Kalkan. Because the Western Australian Government refuses to recognise Aboriginal rights to traditional land, neither community has the security of tenure upon which the provision of essential services can be guaranteed. Despite the neglect shown them, however, Western Desert people have made the decision to remain in their own country. Taken off their land as recently as 30 years ago and now having returned under the most arduous of conditions, with little government support, the communities face the legendary power of a multinational company exploring for and wishing to mine uranium.

So, in addition to the destruction that this and other mining companies pose for the Rudall River ecosystem, they also threaten the social welfare of people who have gone to extraordinary lengths to reassert their cultural integrity and vitality. Continued mining exploration may result in driving the Aboriginal people from their homeland and the first degazettal of a national park to clear the way for deadly uranium mining.

In view of the Western Australian Government's flagrant disregard of the natural and cultural values of Rudall River National Park, it is imperative that the Western Desert people know whether this Commonwealth Government supports the disgraceful neglect shown by the Labor Government of Western Australia. It is also imperative for the rest of the people of Australia to know whether this National Park is going to set the precedent for other parks around the country which multinational development companies happen to earmark for development.

Last week the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers (CONCOM) met in Perth to discuss conservation needs and issues of national importance. I have not discovered whether they had anything particular to say about this situation developing at Rudall River. But it is the responsibility of the Federal Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) to reconfirm the Council of Nature Conservation Ministers endorsement of the international definition of national parks as large areas, free from destructive activities, which the highest authority in the land is committed to uphold. Clearly, there is a federal government responsibility involved here.

It is most important that people right around the country are aware of David Parker's stated aim to change the Australian Labor Party's three mines policy relating to uranium mining. This policy, which was instituted when the go-ahead was given to Roxby Downs mine, was intended to be a phasing out policy. Now that the Nabarlek mine is nearing the end of its productive life, there is a danger that instead of phasing out, we will be faced with a substitution policy if David Parker has his way. It should be noted by members of Labor Party branches that lobbying is under way in preparation for next year's ALP conference either to include Rudall River as the third uranium mine or to overturn the three mines policy altogether to allow further uranium mines to be opened up.

The close connection between CRA and the State Government and the Western Australian Minister's obvious support for the concept of uranium mining are very worrying factors. But when the Western Australian Minister derides the current three mines policy, he does have a point in claiming that it is illogical. Indeed, how can some uranium mines be okay and others not? Of course, I have come to a different conclusion from the Western Australian Minister because I am opposed to uranium mining under any circumstances and that is in connection with uranium being the primary resource material from which nuclear weapons are made; as such, uranium mining is totally indefensible, in my opinion.

The Rudall River exploration leases which have been handed out by the Western Australian Government pave the way for uranium mining. A huge row is building on this issue, aptly described in the Times on Sunday earlier this year as a triple headed monster-uranium mining, on Aboriginal land and in a national park. There will be concerted action by peace groups, social justice groups and environment groups to make sure that that does not come to pass.
Sitting suspended from 1.06 to 2 p.m.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Government in the Senate)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I inform the Senate that Senator Richardson is absent from the chamber for Question Time today as he is holding a series of meetings in northern Queensland concerning World Heritage listing. Any questions in this chamber which would normally be directed to Senator Richardson in relation to his portfolio or those he represents should be directed to Senator Ray.

—I have to advise honourable senators that catering services were withdrawn today between 12 noon and 2 p.m. The catering staff have taken industrial action in relation to a claim for a 4 per cent second tier wage increase. The matter was considered by the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission on Thursday, 12 November 1987. At that time the Commission advised that the productivity and efficiency items identified to date were insufficient to warrant a 4 per cent increase and that further work would be required before the Commission would be satisfied. The Commission set a further hearing date of 1 December 1987. Since last Thursday, the Joint House Department and the Department of Industrial Relations have been conducting further negotiations with the union. These negotiations will continue and the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission will be notified of the industrial action. I sincerely regret the disruption caused to senators, members and other users of the catering services.

—I remind the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce that a little over two weeks ago in this Senate, supported by Senator Michael Baume and Senator Parer, I urged the Government to take action to end union sabotage of the steel industry plan. Whilst the Minister was not able to be present on that day, is he aware that the only response from the Government's second stringers in that debate-namely, Senators Collins and Childs-was to accuse the Opposition of a union bashing exercise and to try to shift most of the blame for the disastrous drop in productivity on to Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP)? Is it true, as widely reported today, that BHP has warned the Government that it would consider closing down its Port Kembla operations and not invest any more money in the steel industry unless there is a dramatic reduction of industrial disputation? Does the Minister now agree that the Port Kembla unions are sabotaging the steel industry plan and that there is an urgent need for the Government to end this sabotage. I ask: What does the Government intend to do about this matter?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been a number of discussions between the Government and BHP. It made a presentation to the Caucus industry committee the other night, I have had discussions with it and it has had discussions with my Department. These discussions have covered the prospects of the steel industry both overseas and in Australia and the implications for the operations of BHP's plants. There was no mention in those discussions of the closure of plants such as Port Kembla if the industrial relations situation did not improve. I want to come back to that. There was, however, discussion of the prospects for further investment in an unstable industrial relations environment, which is a different issue. There have been problems at Port Kembla, of course, associated with the commissioning of new plant-that is a well known fact-and from industrial disputes earlier this year.

ANSWER.PARA: The urgency debate which Senator Lewis proposed a few weeks ago, as he said, in my absence, related essentially to the revelations in the Steel Industry Authority report about industrial relations problems and commissioning problems in the earlier part of this year. That is to say, there was a retrospective view from which Senator Lewis invited us to draw, I understand, certain conclusions about the future. In my view there are reasons for optimism in spite of what has appeared in today's newspapers. The level of industrial disputation has dropped significantly since the middle of this year and productivity across BHP's three integrated steelworks is currently approaching the record levels which were being achieved in 1986. There has been a series of meetings between BHP and unions, including a meeting on 28 October convened by the Steel Industry Authority. Those meetings have made progress in negotiations on dispute settling procedures, particularly at plant level.

It should also be noted that those meetings have perhaps more importantly set the scene for an industry agreement to be achieved next year which will hopefully be a basis for industrial relations harmony in the post-steel plan period after 1988. I personally remain confident, given an improvement in BHP's steel returns, a supportive industrial relations environment and success in achieving much needed productivity gains, that the company over time will look to an expansion of capacity with resultant new job opportunities.

With regard to what appeared in this morning's Press-I think I have answered the substance of Senator Lewis's question-let me say I sometimes doubt the wisdom of carrying on industrial relations policy in the newspapers. I think industrial relations matters are very much like a marriage. If one has an argument with one's wife, one does not normally carry it on in the columns of the Melbourne Herald. There is much to be said for the same--

TALK.START.PARA: —When the taxpayers pay it is a bit different.

—Senator Walters should listen instead of interjecting. There is much to be said for the same sort of conduct in matters of industrial relations because, after all, the fortunes of employees and employers in an industrial enterprise are intimately bound together for better or for worse. It is their decision collectively as to whether it will be better or worse. As to the last part of the question, `What is the Government going to do about it?', just as I do not favour the carrying on of disputes of this kind in the newspapers, I make the simple point that it is again like a marriage: essentially, it is for the parties to sort it out themselves.
—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Does that mean the Government does not intend to do anything about it?
—If I answered yes to that question Senator Lewis would go away elated. No doubt he would put out a Press release stating that the Government is not doing anything about this important problem.
—That is just what you said in the last sentence of your answer. You read it in Hansard.

—Well, why did Senator Lewis ask a supplementary question if I gave that answer in my last answer? Did he just want to hear his own voice? I gave Senator Lewis a lengthy answer; he ought to be satisfied. In the course of that answer I said that the Steel Industry Authority had convened a meeting on 28 October between the unions and BHP to discuss the industrial relations situation and to try to reach an agreement for next year. That is, if you like, a Government intervention, but the Government will take it no further than that.

—Is the Minister for Home Affairs aware that in this chamber yesterday afternoon unfounded and superficial aspersions were cast on the impartiality of the electoral redistribution system by Senator Julian McGauran? Can the Minister assure the Senate, and in particular Senator McGauran, that the redistribution procedures established by the Government are entirely fair and impartial?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would be delighted to tell the Senate in answer to Senator Devlin's question that those procedures are fair. Of course, this question arises from time to time. This is the third time in five weeks this old chestnut has been raised. It is pleasing to me because it reflects a loser's mentality in the Opposition. It is the sort of thing that the Australian Labor Party would have done in the 1950s and 1960s: whinge about the electoral system, say `we was robbed' and then go on to do nothing more. I welcome the comment from that point of view. The specific allegation was that the seat of Burke was gerrymandered. Prior to the 1984 election and prior to the redistribution, the seat of Burke was a 64.5 per cent Labor seat. After the election, the figure was 52.9 per cent. What a brilliant job we apparently did there, carving into our majority by 12 per cent!

ANSWER.PARA: I also point out, in relation to the Australian Labor Party submission to the commissioners, both in regard to Burke and the whole of northern Melbourne, that the commissioners very conveniently ignored every suggestion we made and drew boundaries that were not akin to our suggestion or, indeed, that of the Liberal Party of Australia. I also note that there are always re-hearings at which time political parties can object to the boundaries. I did a little checking and found that the National Party of Australia-Senator McGauran was not a member at that stage, so it probably lacked a bit of intellectual power-failed to object to those Burke boundaries in 1984. I would have thought that if there was some allegation of a gerrymander, the National Party in Victoria would have objected to those boundaries.

If Senator McGauran wants to pursue electoral reform and an interest in fair boundaries, I draw his attention to the honourable senator sitting next to him. He might like to have a conversation with Senator Boswell about the Queensland boundaries. The size of the western-northern zone is 46.3 per cent that of the south-eastern zone. Maybe Senator McGauran would like to take that up with his National Party colleague and give him the benefit of his expertise in that regard. The National Party has never had a particularly good history in terms of electoral boundaries. It stood over the Menzies Government in the 1960s. At one stage, during the 1966 election, there were seats of 29,000 and others of 140,000, in Melbourne simply because the National Party tried to protect itself from the attack of the electorate and tried to maintain as many seats as it could.

In regard to the current state of seats, there is only one seat Australia-wide that is outside the 10 per cent variation within a State. I do not think there has ever been an occasion, at a second election after a redistribution, when the boundaries have been so impeccably fair. Also, I think Senator McGuaran is still a Melbourne city councillor-I see that he is nodding his head-representing the central business district, where there are 1,500 residents. The Labor wards in the Melbourne City Council have 6,000 to 7,000 residents. West, Hotham and Park wards have 7,000 resident voters. I presume that he no longer gets the $2,000 honorarium for that position. I hope he does not, because that would be an office of profit under the Crown. I hope he has given up that role in the council. I hope that in future he will vote for a fair redistribution of the Melbourne City Council boundaries. Then, next time he faces election to that body, he will probably have to convince 6,000 or 7,000 residents to vote for him, rather than 1,500.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce and follows the question asked by Senator Lewis today and a question asked by Senator Lewis on 4 November on the same subject. On 4 November, the Minister referred to discussions between the Steel Industry Authority, steel producers and the unions which, at that time, he was optimistic would produce negotiated agreements on work force reductions and improved industrial relations. In view of the reported warnings to the Government from senior officers of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) this week-these were referred to by Senator Lewis today-that the company would stop investing in the industry unless unions were brought under control, I ask: Is the Minister saying today that the talks have met his expectations? In particular, I ask: Has the Authority obtained union agreement to abandon industrial action in opposition to further work force reductions? What is the Government's position on BHP's proposed voluntary reductions in the steel industry work force-voluntary reductions which are allowed under the terms of the steel industry plan?

—Let us get the facts right. Senator Chaney referred to a reported warning to the Government. In answer to Senator Lewis I said that no such warning was given to the Government, and that the matter was being carried on in the columns of the Press. I do not want to prejudice in any way a process of ongoing discussions about industrial relations in the steel industry. It would be premature for me to say that the discussions have met with my expectations or hopes, or otherwise. I think somebody once said that the proof of the pudding is in the eating. We will have to wait until those discussions have gone a little further down the track before we can give an answer on that point. In regard to the last part of the question, about whether there is an understanding within the Government of negotiations regarding reductions in the work force, and that those reductions should be accomplished either by attrition or voluntary retirement, that is the Government's position and understanding, and will remain so for the duration of the steel plan.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the Minister's desire not to interfere with a process of negotiation, but can he tell the Senate what amount of taxpayers' money this Government has provided by way of bounty or any other subsidy to the steel industry under the steel plan? Will he confirm that that was done in the expectation that there would be a rationalisation of the industry, with the agreed co-operation of the trade union movement? Is not the Government under an obligation, in these circumstances, to take more than a passive bystander role and to seek to ensure that the terms of the steel industry plan are met by all parties, including the trade unions?

—The steel industry plan is not, and never was, a legally binding or contractual document. It was based on expressions of intent and goodwill by the various parties. I cannot tell Senator Chaney precisely what amount of money has been invested by the Government in the steel industry plan, but it is less than half the anticipated amount. I will obtain the details in respect of that part of the answer in due course and provide them to Senator Chaney. There was an understanding within the steel industry plan that there would be some rationalisation of the industry, but the circumstances have changed in a variety of ways since that understanding was reached in 1983.
—The need for it has got greater.

—No, that is not correct, Senator. It is probably a good interjection, but it is not a valid comment. The Government is not involved in the detail of rationalisation at various plants. For example, at Whyalla, which is one of the major steel centres, there has been a significant decline in the production of railway lines for export because of changes that have occurred in export markets. All of these things will affect any rationalisation process. The Government has constantly sought the co-operation of the unions and the company in terms of the plan. That co-operation has occurred between 1983 and the first quarter of 1987. I do not know why the Opposition is getting so excited about a breakdown in those arrangements which, I must say, worked very well until the first quarter of 1987.
—Last year's report on the steel plan suggested major problems.

—None of these things is without problems and attendant difficulties. I know it is a long time since Senator Chaney was in government, but he ought to remember that. On the whole, the plan has made good progress. I very much regret what has happened, and I have said so in the Senate, in terms of both commissioning problems-that is, the breakdown in the introduction of new plant, for which I think the company assumes responsibility-and associated industrial relations problems. I have said some fairly firm things about the industrial relations situation. We are now indulging in a sort of retrospective exercise.
—My question relates to next year.
—It was not a very clear question to me. Certainly, co-operation would be expected from the unions, the company and the Government, as has been accorded in the past.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY SCHOOLS: CORPORAL PUNISHMENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories confirm that corporal punishment will no longer be used in Australian Capital Territory government schools from the beginning of the 1988 school year? If so, have school administrators been advised of this new policy? Will the Government now consider issuing an ordinance to prevent the use of corporal punishment in all schools in the Australian Capital Territory, both government and non-government?

—The Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority has decided that corporal punishment will not be allowed in government schools in 1988. School administrators will be informed of the new policy in due course and in time for implementation in the new school year. The answer to the second part of Senator Colston's question is that the Minister is considering the preparation of an ordinance to prevent the use of corporal punishment in both government and non-government schools.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Finance. Will he confirm a report in yesterday's Melbourne Herald that the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Investment Trust (SFIT), which administers the superannuation of some 320,000 Commonwealth Government employees, has lost about $500m in the stock market collapse? Can the Minister provide details of how much money was lost in the stock market crash by other Commonwealth Government authorities and business enterprises? Can he say what the effect of these losses is likely to be? Finally, what proportion of the investments held by Commonwealth Government authorities and public enterprises is held in the shares of foreign companies?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have a note about this matter, including some specific figures. The Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Investment Trust had a portfolio of shares valued at $4.3 billion in June. I do not know what the present figure would be but, obviously, it would be a good deal lower than that figure. Of that amount 23 per cent was invested in Australian shares and 8 per cent was invested overseas, that is, just over $1 billion and $362m respectively. The Superannuation Fund Investment Trust, in common with almost, if not all, superannuation funds, would have had significant paper losses over the last few weeks. It is almost certainly in the position in which its exit benefit rate will have to be reduced. I may be able to say something a little more definitive about that matter shortly.

ANSWER.PARA: However, I am advised that the SFIT's exposure to the share market is low compared with that of most other superannuation funds whose weightings vary from about 40 per cent to 70 per cent as against just over 30 per cent for the Superannuation Fund Investment Trust. I do not know the situation regarding other Commonwealth Government authorities. Off the top of my head I cannot think of any other Commonwealth Government authority that would be likely to have shares in some other company, but I will see whether any information is available on that matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to the transcript issued yesterday by the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Howard, in which he rebuked the Liberal Party of Australia President, John Elliott, for his comments made the previous day in Adelaide to the effect that Australia's exchange rate against the United States dollar should be targeted at 61c or 62c? Is the economic lesson given to Mr Elliott by Mr Howard on that occasion an accurate assessment of why he was foolish to speak in the way he did?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the transcript and I think it is worth quoting a section of it. The transcript states what Mr Howard said yesterday morning in what has come to be known as the doorstop interview. In reply to a question about Mr Elliott's statement, he said:

ANSWER.PARA: Well my view and the view of the Liberal Party is that there should be a float. There's a role for the Reserve Bank, smoothing an interventionary role but I have never made it a practice and I never will, of nominating a particular level for the dollar. I have always made the point that allowing the dollar to go into a free fall is not a quick-fix for our economic problems. There are costs involved in the dollar going down. Higher interest rates, higher inflation, higher debt. Therefore, I don't make it a practice, nor does the Liberal Party, of nominating at a particular level.

Later in the interview he said that he had recently talked to Mr Elliott. Essentially I agree with the points that Mr Howard made. However, I do not accept that Mr Howard's motives were as pure as he would like to have us believe. Prior to the 1983 election the then Minister for Foreign Affairs-he is presently the Deputy Leader of the Liberal Party-tried to talk down the dollar and to get a run on the currency. More recently Mr Peacock has been at it again as have Mr Howard and Senator Stone from time to time. They have all made public statements.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has clearly made a thoroughly objectionable allegation as to the motivation of three members of parliament and what they were doing. I insist on a withdrawal. Suggesting that the members were seeking to promote a run on the currency is, in my view, a highly disorderly statement and should be withdrawn with respect to all three people mentioned.
—It could be seen as a personal reflection on the members concerned. I ask the Minister to withdraw.

—Very well, I withdraw the reflection, Mr President. However, it is a fact that the three people whom I have named-Senator Stone, Mr Howard and Mr Peacock-and a number of others even less important than any of those three people have made statements, the effect of which is likely to be as I have stated. Mr President, in deference to your ruling, I will not comment on their motives. The real message which Mr Howard was trying to get through to Mr Elliott is that if one is trying to talk the dollar down, one cannot be that brazen about it. One has to hide one's intentions a little more effectively than Mr Elliott did.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer to comments made yesterday by the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and on which he elaborated last night during an Australian Broadcasting Corporation television interview that murder `in defence of basic rights, or to try to get a free society' could be justified. I ask: Does the Minister share Mr Hayden's views? If so, can he inform the Senate of the circumstances which he considers would justify the murder of one human being by another?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not normally in the habit of quoting the Pope but the Holy See in its instruction on Christian freedom and liberation of 5 April 1986 defended the right of the oppressed to revolt and, as a last resort, to use armed struggle to put an end to an obvious prolonged tyranny. What else is armed struggle but the commission, on a systematic scale, of murder, if one chooses to put it in those terms? Similarly, the third preambulate paragraph of the Universal Declaration of Human Rights refers to the need to protect human rights if man is not to be compelled to have recourse, as a last resort, to rebellion against tyranny and oppression. Many similar statements can, of course, be quoted.

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Government has a long established policy of supporting a peaceful solution to the problem of apartheid. As a matter of principle, the Australian Government cannot condone the use of violence in any form. Because of the emotion that the practice quite understandably generates, the Government cannot condone, in any circumstances, the phenomenon of necklacing which featured so large in the sanctimonious rhetoric we heard yesterday from members of Senator Stone's Party and the Opposition generally. This practice, amongst others, is an example of the inhumanity which the apartheid system has inevitably engendered among South Africans. It would not occur in a South Africa where black aspirations could be pursued by peaceful, legitimate means, the very means that are denied to them. It is not the only abuse occurring in South Africa and it is more than matched by the harsh repression of black South Africans by the South African Government.

In view of the South African Government's refusal to change its policies fundamentally and in view of the violence meted out to those who actively oppose those policies, the Australian Government understands, and has said so consistently-not just yesterday and not just in the United Nations a day or two ago by Ambassador Woolcott-how some South Africans, in reaction to this violence, have felt compelled to resort to violence themselves. As a matter of principle, the Australian Government cannot condone the resort to violence and force. We have made that clear to black nationalist leaders such as Oliver Tambo. However, we will not condemn them for doing so, and that is the context in which Mr Hayden made his remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question as a result of the Minister's response. Will the Minister distinguish between the concept of armed struggle-a term on which he dwelt, referring to a papal annunciation-on the one hand and the actions of individuals, such as the necklacing of persons, usually of blacks by other blacks, on the other? Will he distinguish between the concept of armed struggle on the one hand and, on the other, the placing of bombs in shopping centres resulting in the murder of totally innocent civilians? Will the Minister bring his intellect to bear upon distinctions of that kind?

—I do not propose to engage in the sorts of pontifications on this subject with which Senator Stone used to prop up the bar at the National Press Club every Friday night for years in previous incarnations, although that might be more congenial to his approach to this subject of high seriousness. These are questions of high seriousness and I refuse to trivialise them in the way that Senator Stone has.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware of the report on Australian Broadcasting Corporation radio on 12 October 1987 concerning American foreign policy in the Philippines which claimed that the Americans are considering moving their military bases to Australia? Have any officers of the Minister's Department been aware of this consideration, which affects Australia's interests? In the light of the Defence Minister's recent assertion that American South East Asian bases are essential for Australian security, can the Minister say which American military functions are being mooted for possible relocation in Australia?

—I am aware of the report referred to, which consisted of no more than a speculative comment by an American journalist about the future of the facilities in the Philippines. The United States has not made any approach to the Australian Government concerning the relocation of those facilities. With regard to the United States military facilities in the Philippines, the United States objective is to achieve a successful outcome to the forthcoming negotiations with the Philippines Government, resulting in a continued United States military presence there beyond 1991. Mr Beazley's remarks in Bangkok and Kuala Lumpur this week confirm the Australian Government's view of the important contribution made to regional security by these facilities.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware of an article in the Bulletin of 27 October 1987 which, in some detail, examines the income and expenses of a Dr Y who laments the hours that he works for what he regards as the meagre net pre-tax income of $36,900? I ask the Minister whether he has any information that might shed any light on the productivity of Dr Y. If so, can he indicate what would be the effect on the Australian economy if all workers had a similar level of productivity to that of Dr Y?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen the article, published in the Bulletin about a month ago, and I think I should quote a couple of extracts from it. It purports to quote a Dr Y as saying:

ANSWER.PARA: What I have to put up with is a `something for nothing' mentality in which people troop into my surgery, toss their Medicare card down and expect instantaneous service. Doctors these days are regarded very much as the servants of the people. . . It's amazing the rubbish that I have to put up with from all sorts of bludgers, whingers and hypochondriacs.

He then claimed that he worked a 48-hour week and earned, on average, $1,025 a week, out of which he had to pay expenses of $570. As he put it, he earned $21.35 an hour. The article went on to purport to give the details of the costs that this doctor incurred in his surgery, such as the purchase of magazines and periodicals. I do not think that I need to go into all of that detail. The 10 November issue of the Bulletin contained a letter to the editor from a Dr Alan Skapinker. He said:

I was interested to read Dr Y's practice statistics (``The Crisis in the Surgery'', B, October 27, 1987). His gross income is $1025 per week. The Medicare rebate for a standard consultation is $15 and he therefore averages 68.3 consultations per week (presuming that he bulk-bills). The average standard consultation lasts for 15-20 minutes. According to his calculations, he must be working for only 17-20 hours per week. This would leave Dr Y plenty of time to do his own cleaning and laundry, adding an additional $6600 to his income. He would also have plenty of time to get a job in a busier practice for at least one day per week, earning him an estimated $10,000 per annum. This would raise his income to $53,500 per annum and he will probably still have time to play golf one day during the week.

I do not think that there is any need to say any more about Dr Y and his alleged hard work and moderate remuneration. But if Dr Y's working hours were to be adopted by the work force in general, the effect would be a fall of close to 50 per cent in national product and national income.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Communications, Senator Gareth Evans. I refer the Minister to the matter that I raised in Question Time yesterday, namely, whether the construction of the Aviation Central Training College will go ahead in Canberra, and the Minister's answer that he was `not up to date with the latest developments'. Has the Minister now been brought up to date with the latest developments and, in particular, in view of media reports yesterday and today that the Government is considering relocating the college to Launceston, can the Minister specifically advise whether he has received advice from his Department to the effect that Launceston would be an unsuitable alternative location for the college? Can the Minister advise the Senate how much has already been expended on the project, and when will he be able to give an unequivocal assurance that the Aviation College will proceed in Canberra as announced and planned?

—The training of air traffic controllers is essential for the safe and efficient operation of the airways system and the construction of the proposed Central Training College will involve the expenditure of several million dollars of public funds. Very little of that money-I am not sure how much-has so far been expended; there has just been the initial planning. I will check to find out for Senator Reid. However, substantial expenditure is proposed for this facility. Complex issues are involved in this matter, so it is entirely appropriate that Mr Duncan, the new Minister who has been handling operational aviation matters on my behalf, should fully examine these matters, as he has, to ensure that the proposed actions constitute the best possible course. That examination in which he has been engaged has required a short delay in the final consideration of tenders for the proposed siting of the college at Watson High School. I stress that no decision has been taken to alter the proposed siting of the college at Watson High. It is correct that the Tasmanian State Institute of Technology, based in Launceston, has proposed to the Government that it undertake air traffic control training, suggesting that this would achieve significant cost savings for the Government. The Government sees itself as clearly obliged to evaluate the proposal as part of the project as a whole. I am certainly extremely conscious, as is my colleague, of the need to avoid any unnecessary delay in the project. I certainly expect that the examination of the issues that are involved can be concluded very expeditiously and I would anticipate an announcement being made in this respect next month.

—The Minister for Justice will be aware of comments on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation program AM this morning in which Mr Zdenkowski called on the Federal Government to oppose the reopening of the `black hole' at Boggo Road prison in Brisbane. Can the Minister inform the Senate what the Federal Government is doing to ensure a minimum standard of conditions for prisoners in Australian gaols?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did hear Mr Zdenkowski's comments on today's AM program. Indeed, I almost choked on my cup of tea because the last thing I want from Mr Zdenkowski is advice on this matter. Usually the last thing I get from Mr Zdenkowski is advice on matters to do with prisons and sentencing. Mr Zdenkowski preceded his comments calling on the Federal Government to oppose the reopening of the Boggo Road black hole, as it has been called, by saying:

ANSWER.PARA: . . . the time has come when I think that prisons are on a political agenda . . .

The Federal Government put the matters of prisons and sentencing on Mr Zdenkowski's agenda on 23 July 1984 when he was appointed as commissioner for the Australian Law Reform Commission to produce a report on this very topic. Three years and four months later Mr Zdenkowski is still travelling around the Commonwealth having hearings on his discussion papers without any report in the hands of the Federal Government. He has asked for an extension well into next year, having already got an extension, in order to complete his report. By the way, he receives something like $70,000 a year.

In the terms of reference that were given to Mr Zdenkowski some 3 1/2 years ago it was put to him, amongst other things-I think that, initially, this reference was given by Senator Peter Durack and led to an interim report being produced by the Law Reform Commission many years ago-that he should take into account that such laws and proposals as he recommends are consistent with articles of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. It is essential that, if the Federal Government is to have any role in the conditions that might be put in place in Australian prisons, lock-ups and other places of custody, we have to use the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights, or some such instrument, because, clearly, State gaols are within State jurisdiction rather than Federal jurisdiction.

Moving to the whole question of the so-called black hole at Boggo Road, one simply need go no further than the Courier-Mail editorial of yesterday. In an excellent editorial the newspaper, having asked what justification there was for reopening punishment cells that are barbaric in the extreme, described them in this way:

The cells are not merely places of solitary confinement; they are places where the hapless prisoners are deprived of normal sensory stimulation. In short, they don't know whether it is night or day, hot or cold. The same kind of cells were used during the Korean War on United Nations prisoners as a method of extracting information. Does Mr Neal-
the relevant Minister in Queensland-
really want Queensland to be seen in that company?

It appears that Mr Neal and the Queensland Cabinet are happy to see Queensland in that company. Clearly, the Federal Government, and I think most Australians, are filled with revulsion at the thought that that might be the case. As I have said, it is probably at odds with our international obligations. It is for that reason that the Federal Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission is taking up the question of that prison in Brisbane.

The Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission has received a complaint which has triggered its consideration of the conformity of the black hole with Australia's international obligations under articles 7 and 10 of the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights. Whether the Commission needed that complaint or whether it would have taken up the matter of its own notion, I am not sure. Nevertheless, a complaint has been received. In addition, my colleague the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, Mr Gerry Hand, has had discussions with the Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission with a view to it undertaking such an investigation. I know, from my discussions this morning with Mr Brian Burdekin, the Human Rights Commissioner, and informally with Mr Justice Marcus Einfeld at the Alan Missen Memorial Dinner last night, that the Commission will get its investigation under way. I hope that it will not come to an exercise of the Commission's powers of investigation. I would think that, even on a crude political judgment which might appeal to the Queensland Cabinet, a decision could be taken not to proceed with the decision to reopen the Boggo Road gaol facility.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Minister for Finance advise the Senate when the decision to issue the Australian Tax File Number Advice Card was made and when the Australian Taxation Office issued the first of those cards? To whom are they issued? What is the estimated cost of the production and issuing of the cards? What plans, if any, does the Government have to extend the use of this card to other departments?
—Senator Patterson asked about six sub-questions and I do not know the answers. However, I will get them as soon as possible.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: LIBERAL PARTY OF AUSTRALIA: FUND RAISING

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Home Affairs whether his attention has been drawn to an article in yesterday's Melbourne Herald entitled `Democracy at work: how to get a politician's ear for $1000'. One wonders how much the other parts would cost! I refer to the article covering the attempts by the Victorian branch of the Liberal Party of Australia to raise money through a special persons special privileges donation scheme. I ask: Is any such money raised subject to Commonwealth disclosure under the Commonwealth Electoral Act? If not, what action does the Government propose to take to extend legislation to such donations?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I did notice in yesterday's Herald a reference to an American fund raising-style campaign which offers access to information and members of parliament in return for money. I was almost tempted to join myself because then I would probably find out which areas of Government expenditure the Opposition proposes to cut. I may also discover when the communications policy promised before the last election but never delivered by Mr Beale will arrive. Indeed, we might even receive the costing of the Liberal Party's education policy which Mr Shack refused to release before the election.

ANSWER.PARA: Apparently there are six categories of this scheme. If a person joins the candidates forum it costs $25 and to join the members forum-that is, the Victorian lower House members forum-it costs $50. For the upper House in Victoria one has to pay the grand sum of $100 and, for the House of Representatives forum, $250. I am sure that everyone in this chamber will cheer when I say that it costs $500 to join the senators forum. Here at last, Mr President, we have due recognition for this chamber. We are no longer the K Mart of Australian politics. All I can say is: it is a lot of money but, just think, one could pay $500 and meet Senator Lewis, Senator Short, Senator Alston, Senator Patterson and Senator Hamer, who is not with us today. The final category is the Cabinet forum, which costs $1,000 to join. I do not know exactly what is involved there because there is not a Liberal Cabinet on the mainland of Australia. I assume that it is $1,000 because one would have to pay the air fare to Tasmania. The Liberal Party has lost 14 mainland elections in a row. Maybe people are just paying their $1,000 in the hope that the odds will finally turn around.

I also read in the article that most of the funds will go to the State campaign fund for the Liberal Party and, therefore, would be in no way disclosable under Commonwealth legislation. Further, if any of that money were used in the Liberal Party maintenance fund for its general administrative operations, again it would not be disclosable. If any of the money were used for Federal election purposes, only those donations over $1,000 would be disclosable. So for those individuals who donate $1,000 to the Cabinet Fund, and if any of that money were diverted to Federal expenditure, it would, therefore, come under the provisions of the Commonwealth Electoral Act. I do not see any need to take any substantial Commonwealth action in this regard. I do not think that those forums will be much better than those that existed in the forums of, say, fourth or third century Rome.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: MINISTER FOR THE ENVIRONMENT AND THE ARTS: RAVENSHOE VISIT

TALK.START.PARA: —I address my question to Senator Gareth Evans. I note his reply to a question by Senator Stone in which he condoned violence under extreme provocation. In light of that answer, does he believe that Senator Richardson deserved the treatment he received in Ravenshoe when he tried to take 750 people's jobs and 3,000 people's jobs indirecty by closing down the north Queensland timber industry?
—I do not know which portfolio representation this question comes under, but I call Senator Evans.

—Just to clarify the record for Senator Boswell, I did not say that the Government condoned violence. I said that we did not condemn it in the context of the extreme provocation to which people may be put in the context of South Africa-the oppression, the violence, the rape, the torture and the detention; all the horrors of that particular environment. If Senator Boswell is prepared to trivialise the particular provocation that he sees his residents of north Queensland as being subjected to by making comparison with the horrors of South Africa, then I am afraid that Senator Boswell, for all the quickness of feet he has so uncharacteristically shown in asking that question, does not really deserve our respect.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories to the Committee of Inquiry into Folklife in Australia, established in March 1986 by the former Minister for Arts, Heritage and the Environment. I ask the Minister: Firstly, has the Committee delivered its report to the Minister and, if so, when was the report delivered; secondly, when will the report be tabled in the Parliament; and, thirdly, can the Minister give an indication as to when the Government is likely to make a response to the Committee's findings?

—I am informed by a document I have here that the report has been delivered to the Minister. The report presently is in the hands of the Australian Government Publishing Service. It is a major document recommending a range of measures for safeguarding Australia's heritage of folklife. Unfortunately, there have been substantial delays in the production of the report. Because of these production delays it will not be available for tabling this session-I add, that is if we finish on 18 December. However, I am aware that there is a great deal of interest in this particular report. I understand that the report will now be available for release early next year. It will be tabled in the Senate at the earliest opportunity. The Department is looking at the recommendations in the report. Once the report has been tabled, the Government will respond formally to these recommendations, once there has been adequate opportunity for public comment.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services. I refer the Minister to the admission earlier this week by his colleague the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr John Brown, that he had given a verbal nod to a company owned by Mr Bob Rogers in respect of a contract to provide the theatre in the Australian pavilion at World Expo 88 and that Mr Rogers would be entitled to compensation following the subsequent decision by the Minister not to sign the contract. I also refer to the statement by the Prime Minister that `no contract has been entered into'. I ask the Minister whether the Department of Administrative Services is responsible for the determination of the Government's purchasing policies and for the production of an official Commonwealth purchasing manual. If so, did Minister Brown contravene the Government's tendering and contracting policies and processes by conveying to Mr Rogers in discussions the clear expectation that he would be awarded the contract? If compensation is paid to Mr Rogers in respect of a contract it is claimed he did not have, what is the legal basis for such payment and how does the Government propose to prevent the successful pursuit of compensation claims under similar circumstances in the future?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Responsibility for the award of a contract for a theatrical production within the Australian pavilion at World Expo 88 originally rested with the former Department of Sport, Recreation and Tourism. However, the Department of Administrative Services became involved in February 1987 when the Government decided to call fresh tenders which were to be evaluated by a committee under the chairmanship of the Department of Administrative Services. Five Australian companies plus an American company owned by Mr Bob Rogers were invited on 25 February 1987 to bid for the contract. Bids closed on 9 March 1987. The committee issued reports on 21 March 1987 and 4 April 1987 recommending the award of a contract to AAV Australia, which I think is located in Moorabbin. The Government accepted the recommendation on 13 April 1987. Throughout the tendering and evaluation processes between 25 February and 13 April 1987, Mr Rogers was in no different position from that of any of the other tenderers.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short asked a series of other questions, some of which relate, I think, to events prior to the time at which the Department of Administrative Services became involved. Firstly, I think he asked some questions concerning the legal basis. I cannot give a legal opinion here. Not only am I not qualified to do that but, as I have said on many occasions, I would not want to lessen my reputation around the place by pretending to be a lawyer. I am sorry to see that Senator Button is not looking pleased. Therefore, I cannot help the honourable senator in that respect. Senator Short also asked questions as to how this contract relates to the manual on tendering, if I heard him correctly. That is a fairly extensive document. I do not know it word by word. I will take that part of the honourable senator's question on notice.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of all honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a delegation from the Supreme Soviet of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics, led by Mr Hishanov. On behalf of all senators I extend to the delegation a warm welcome and trust that their stay is a success.

—My question, which is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, is in two parts. The first part relates in particular to the death of Bernard McGrath in police cells in Kalgoorlie. The second part of the question relates to deaths in custody generally. Bernard McGrath was found in a police cell, apparently on his knees, slumped against a door with a towel around his neck attached to the door. In respect of the fact that the Kalgoorlie police initially released a statement saying that there were no suspicious circumstances attached to the death and in light of a Special Broadcasting Service interview with an alleged witness to a homicide who was waiting to make a voluntary statement at an office of the Aboriginal Legal Aid Service, will the Minister advise the Senate-if he is aware-whether the Kalgoorlie police interrogated any of the nine short term prisoners in respect of a possible homicide before they were released?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I understand it, Bernard McGrath was picked up on Saturday, 14 November, at about 11.30 p.m. whilst playing pool. He was picked up on a warrant issued by the Community Services Department over his non-completion of a community work order. He had been ordered to do 100 hours of community work over a wilful damage charge but had completed only 50 hours. He was not affected by alcohol when arrested. The body of Bernard McGrath was discovered by another prisoner about 5.30 a.m. on 15 November. Western Australian police originally stated that there were no suspicious circumstances and that the death appeared to be a suicide. Twenty-four hours later Chief Superintendent Ron Kjellgren said that more investigation was needed into some aspects of McGrath's death. Late on Wednesday Western Australian police declared the matter a homicide and the Criminal Investigation Branch took over investigation.

ANSWER.PARA: As I understand it, nine prisoners were in the Kalgoorlie cells on the night of the death. The cell doors were open to the exercise yard and adjoining shower and toilet. All prisoners had access to McGrath. Most of the prisoners were in for being drunk and disorderly. The morning following the death, all prisoners were released without questioning. On the face of it, it is an extraordinary dereliction that not one of the prisoners was asked one question in relation to the death that had occurred in that cell. No doubt the matter is subject to coronial inquiry. I guess an inquest is being prepared for. I have no more to say by way of assessment or analysis. That is my understanding of the facts.

Senator Collins also asked a general question concerning the Federal Government's possible role in relation to Aboriginals being held in custody, or some other form of detention. The fact is that I reported to the Senate about a meeting of police and corrective services Ministers in Melbourne on 10 September. That meeting had been held, I thought, with a very good spirit and sense of purpose and had produced a draft summary of those practices and procedures that ought to be put in place in regard to the detaining and remanding in custody of Aboriginals around Australia. I had expressed my hope at that meeting that consultation would take place. Indeed, that was an undertaking given by the Ministers present-that such extensive and rigorous consultation would take place among the Ministers, Aboriginal communities and Aboriginal legal services within their own jurisdictions to enable us to go to the meeting tomorrow week in Hobart of the Australian Police Ministers Council and to resolve on a code of practices and procedures that ought to be put in place in regard to the holding of Aboriginals in custody.

When I went to a meeting of the National Aboriginal and Islander Legal Service last Thursday night, 12 November, I was dismayed to be told-and after going around the table, this was the judgment I made-by the national representatives that this consultation had not taken place in any of the State or Territory jurisdictions of people who had been present at the meeting on 10 September in Melbourne. To say that I was dismayed and disappointed at that lack of consultation would be an understatement. The consultation did not take place as promised and this has led to the situation where I do not believe that the meeting to be held next Friday in Hobart can be expected to resolve on a code of practices and procedures. The spate of four deaths in the past week indicates the tragic dimensions of failure to address this problem expeditiously. Unless it is grappled with with a sense of urgency, which apparently is lacking at the moment in State and Territory jurisdictions, we all share a premonition that this tragedy will continue and spates of deaths, as have occurred in the past week alone, might well recur again.

I believe that consultation with Aboriginal communities and their legal services is an essential precondition to give any authenticity or credibility to any code of practices and procedures that might be enunciated by police and corrective services Ministers. Until that consultation does take place, I believe we are greatly disadvantaged as police and corrective service Ministers in grappling with this problem with the urgency which it deserves.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: STRATEGIC DEFENCE INITIATIVE PROGRAM: X-RAY LASER

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday at Question Time, Senator Vallentine asked me a question which I think I can best summarise by saying that it related to development work by a laser company in Australia and the strategic defence initiative (SDI) program. I was unable to give an answer yesterday. The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows: The United States Department of Energy is responsible for, among other things, the production of United States nuclear weapons. The United States Strategic Defence Initiative Organisation (SDIO) is responsible for the SDI program and the United States Department of Energy acts as SDIO's agent for some aspects of the SDI project. The Australian Government does not monitor the extent to which private firms and organisations are seeking to become involved in the SDI program, nor are private bodies required to make the Government aware of their involvement or intended involvement.

ANSWER.PARA: The Government would be faced with considerable practical difficulties were it to attempt to impede the export to the United States of innovative high technology developments by Australian industry which might, at some future time, have a possible role in the program. I am informed that the Australian laser in question would have a power output less by several orders of magnitude than would be needed for an operational SDI system should the United States decide to deploy one.

In my reply to Senator Chaney on the same issue in October of last year, I reiterated the Government position. Private sector involvement in SDI is a matter for commercial judgment. But the Government has made it clear that it does not endorse SDI and will not enter into an umbrella agreement with the United States Government to establish ground rules for any Australian participation in SDI funded research.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Also at Question Time yesterday, Senator Panizza asked me a question about tariffs on diesel injection pumps and turbo chargers. I have obtained an answer which is somewhat longer than might be gripping for those members of the Senate who do not have a specialist interest in diesel injection pumps. I seek leave for the answer to be incorporated in Hansard.

ANSWER.PARA: Leave granted.
The answer reads as follows-

Importers of replacement parts used for diesel injection pumps and turbo chargers not manufactured in Australia will continue to have the opportunity to import their goods at 2% duty irrespective of the proposed tariff changes referred to by the honourable Senator.
This will be possible subjet to the normal provisions of the tariff concession system administered by the Australian Customs Service.

As from 1 January 1988, the Australian Tariff will be based on the harmonized commodity description and coding system which has also been adopted by most major trading nations to standardise their commodity descriptions and tariff codes and thus simplify the administration requirements of international trade.
In adopting the hamonized tariff, Australia is obliged to adhere to all the internationally agreed tariff items while maintaining those Australian items necessary for industry policy reasons.

Under the current tariff structure most parts for diesel injection pumps and turbochargers are classified to the same tariff item as the complete goods and therefore pay the same rates of customs duty.
However, under the harmonized tariff the rules for the classification of parts for such goods will change.
Parts will fall to new items in the tariff and will not be classified to the same item as the complete goods as is presently the case.

Therefore, diesel injection pump and turbocharger parts, currently dutiable at the 2 per cent rate applying to the complete goods, are being amalgamated into new items with parts for other pumps mainly dutiable at 25 per cent.

In determining the rates of duty to be applied to these amalgamated items, regard had to be given to the protective rates of duty applying to the Australian industry involved in the area, since many of the parts falling to the amalgamated items are manufactured in Australia.
As a result the industry protective rate was the rate considered to be appropriate.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday Senator Watson asked me a question concerning the treatment of pre-malignant keratoses. The Minister for Community Services and Health has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question: Despite Senator Watson's attempts to claim the contrary, the cost of the treatment of pre-malignant keratoses, potentially cancerous skin lesions, is still covered by Medicare benefits. The difference since 1 August is that the specific items for the removal of warts and keratoses have been deleted from the Medicare schedule because of concern about the rapid increase in the utilisation of these services which could not be justified on either demographic or health grounds. Indeed, over the last two financial years the increase in utilisation of these items totalled 45 per cent. Now, just like many other minor services, the removal of warts and keratoses, including sunspots, are covered by Medicare fees and rebates for consultations, either at the general practitioner or specialist rate, which provides adequate and appropriate remuneration.

ANSWER.PARA: Sunspots and warts are not skin cancers, but in some cases should be removed as a preventive measure. Their removal was originally a time consuming and difficult task performed mainly by specialists. The fees were originally structured on this basis and, as with many other professional procedures, a consultation fee could not be charged. With the advent of liquid nitrogen removal and wart killing paints, three-quarters of these procedures are now being performed rapidly and painlessly by general practitioners in their surgeries.

The changes announced deal with particular concern that, because they were not permitted to charge for both the consultation and the removal procedure during the one visit, medical practitioners were asking patients to return so that they could claim for both items when in fact very often the removals could have been performed during the initial consultation. Thus the changes have eliminated scope for overservicing, while ensuring that medical practitioners are appropriately compensated through Medicare consultations for the cost of providing the service.

I should also stress that the items for the removal of skin cancers remain in place as the Government recognises the need for separate procedures to cover these services. As well, officers of the Department of Community Services and Health have, since the deletion of these items, met with representatives of the medical profession, including surgeons, dermatologists, obstetricians and gynaecologists. The Department is reviewing the special case that has been argued for anal and genital warts to be covered in the benefits schedule, as they usually require hospital admission and removal under anaesthetic.
