TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the answer.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, Senator MacGibbon asked me a question about the business migration program. I have the following answer for him: The figures for principal business migration applicants, spouses and accompanying minor children are as follows: 1982-83, 1,079; 1983-84, 1,472; 1984-85, 1,561; 1985-86, 1,649; and 1986-87, 3,535. According to a preliminary survey, the figure for the first quarter of 1987-88 will be 1,456. It should be noted that the various policy changes, particularly in 1983, to some extent may have distorted the 1983-84 and 1984-85 statistics; that is, some arrivals in this two-year period comprise a component of the previous policy.

ANSWER.PARA: The major safeguard in ensuring that business migration program migrants do not repatriate their moneys lies in good selection. As part of the recent upgrading and streamlining of the business migration program announced by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, the Government is taking the opportunity to implement measures to monitor the business activities of business migrants. The accreditation of qualified business migration consultants to assess applications and provide post-arrival services will further these objectives. In the meantime the Government has a general safeguard over the integrity of the immigration program through its re-entry policy. The policy is designed to ensure genuine settlement in Australia, but is flexible enough to allow newly arrived migrants to travel to settle family affairs and engage in business activity.

Persons who have been issued a residents visa and have travelled to Australia by the date specified on the visa may leave and return to Australia on any number of occasions within three years of that date, provided he or she has been physically present in Australia as a resident for a total of two out of the three years prior to the application for a re-entry visa. The Government does not wish to inhibit business initiatives or intervene in the business affairs of some Australian residents solely on the grounds that they are recent arrivals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Under the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 three major functions are identified for the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. The first of these functions is important-that is, that the Committee is to make recommendations to the Minister with respect to:
priorities and strategies for activities by the Commonwealth relating to soil conservation;
On page 4 of the report the Committee, in supporting the national soil conservation program, said:
Fragmentation of effort in the past has limited an effective attack on land degradation problems.

It is important that the Commonwealth, under the national soil conservation program, takes the lead in the co-ordination of programs and the promotion of community awareness programs so that the first goal of the national soil conservation program is met. That goal is that `all lands in Australia be used within their capability'. The Soil Conservation Advisory Committee also states that in attempting to establish how best the Commonwealth could contribute in the future `a significant step towards this end was the preparation, by the Committee, of a draft strategy for Commonwealth involvement in soil conservation'.

I welcome the draft national soil conservation strategy, which, to my consternation, was released somewhat quietly on 6 November. I found out about the release of that document by accident only yesterday when a rural journalist was speaking with me. That release took place only two days after I moved an urgency motion in this chamber which was supported by all parties. From inquiries I made yesterday after establishing that this draft had been released, I discovered that none of the senators' offices that I had contacted had received this draft. Very few offices of what I would consider to be interested departments and very few academics around Australia had received it either.

I make that comment because the document states that any comments, which are invited, should be directed in writing by 15 December. That is far too short a time-frame for comments on something as important as a national soil conservation strategy. I would suggest that half of Australia's farmers are involved in some kind of harvest program at this stage of the year. Academics who might be interested are probably involved in winding up the year's activities, if not marking papers and, in the case of the rest of the community, we are fast approaching the silly season-perhaps the silliest of all seasons in this place. So I have called upon the Minister for Resources, Mr Peter Morris, to extend the time for public comments until at least March next year.

I commend the very first point in the draft which states that `Australia's soils are a finite resource.' This is a very important fact which needs to be drawn to everybody's attention. The strategy draft goes on to state that `soils are formed slowly and must, therefore, be regarded as non-renewable.' I think we all need to take this point to heart and to think about it when we are making comments and suggestions in the soil conservation area.

While looking at this Advisory Committee report and the issue generally of soil conservation, I would like to comment on the recent restructuring of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy. There has been a consequent amalgamation of the former Bureau of Agricultural Economics and the Bureau of Resource Economics into the new Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics. I think it is reasonable to suggest that the national soil conservation strategy, which has been brought out by the Advisory Committee, in the light of that restructuring, could become part of a more integrated approach, perhaps through the new amalgamated bureau, to incorporating land, water, environmental considerations and management practices in much the same way as the new Murray-Darling Basin Commission will now do in respect of that area. The Government has accepted that the narrow, single issue approach to these problems in the River Murray area has failed. The Australian Democrats believe that the Government should also consider a more holistic approach in the area of soil degradation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —I welcome the 1986-87 annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee. The program under which this report is brought forward, as a result of the Soil Conservation (Financial Assistance) Act 1985, has its genesis going back to the program initiated in 1983 which, in turn, was very much the successor to the national soil conservation program introduced by the Fraser Liberal Government in 1980. It is a little difficult to analyse some of the issues in soil conservation without also relating them to the success, over a number of years, of the national tree program, which again goes back to a Fraser Government initiative in 1982.

SPEECH.PARA: We see from this annual report that since 1983 a considerable amount of attention has been paid to the problem of soil conservation in a more formal fashion than has been the case for many years. Since the introduction of the program in 1983 with the budgetary allocation of some $6m which is provided this year, there has been an expenditure in the order of $21m. It is perhaps interesting to note that that is slightly less than the money which the Government has put aside for the national rainforest conservation program in the course of the last year and a half and perhaps it is an indication of the relative importance which the Government has given to soil conservation issues as compared with the more politically attractive areas of rainforest conservation. Without in any sense trying to say that rainforest conservation is not a subject of immediate national importance, it is perhaps unfortunate that, when $22m can be found for that in the fairly short term, only $21m has been found for what is a far more serious problem going back over the life of this program.

If one goes back and looks at the report which was presented in April 1978 by the Research Directorate of the then Department of Environment, Housing and Community Development entitled Basis for Soil Conservation Policy in Australia, one can see that the study which was undertaken between 1975 and 1977 indicated that about 52 per cent of the land in use in Australia needed some form of treatment for land or vegetation degradation. It is true to say, for instance, that each centimetre of soil lost can reduce crop yields by up to 20 per cent. In Western Australia alone in recent years, more than $100m worth of production per annum has been lost as a result of the loss of 2,500 hectares per annum through salt and other forms of land degradation. It is probably not possible to make a calculation of the extent of productive loss and the impact, in terms not only of loss of soil but also of increasing salinity and degradation, throughout the whole community. The Senate had an excellent debate on 4 November this year on a motion initiated by Senator Powell, dealing with this very important question.

It is interesting that the major national projects dealt with in this report-the acidification of soils, the measurement of run-off and soils loss, the modelling techniques to be used for measuring and evaluating this problem, the economics of soil conservation and the revision of farming systems related to the protection of Australia's soils-will all make a major contribution to redressing this problem. I am happy to indicate that the Opposition has sought to give the very highest priority to this problem in the re-evaluation of its environment policy. This is probably the major single problem affecting Australia's environment. It needs to be dealt with on a national level and with a great deal more expenditure of public funds than has been the case in the past. I am glad to see that the limited resources made available at the moment to the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee appear to have been well used. We look forward to an expanded report in the next year given the slight increase in funds available in this Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support what Senator Puplick has just said regarding the annual report of the Soil Conservation Advisory Committee, especially what he said about the amount of money that has been allocated to the rainforest area. That is all very admirable but that amount of money is not being put into soil conservation which, of course, is also very valuable. It is a productive resource, not a resource from which all of the productivity can be taken away, as in the case of rainforests. I take the liberty of mentioning that the Committee's report states:

SPEECH.PARA: The National Soil Conservation Program . . . is directed at all sectors of the community with an interest in, and a concern for, land management.

Everyone in the community must become more aware of that. There is a peer group pressure situation, and if more people have an awareness of soil conservation we will be able to look after this very precious resource, the soil, much better. The part of the report that strikes me as being very important comes under the heading `States' Component Projects':
In New South Wales, the first of a series of group catchment schemes funded by the NSCP has been completed.

This is a wonderful achievement. I happen to be the chairman of the Yarraman catchment group in the north-west of New South Wales. We got together a group of landholders for a common purpose-to conserve the soil for future generations. That catchment also affected the railway lines and roads through the area, and the purity of the water received by the towns and villages further downstream. Without putting too fine a point on it, we spend a lot of time talking about the `greenie' movement but a lot of the time we should be thinking of the `brownie' movement because brown is the colour of the water that flows down to the sea and takes away our life blood, the soil. If we allow that to continue, in the future we will not have any of that productive resource.

I commend the report, and I commend what previous speakers have said about it. If this country and this Government do not wake up very quickly and decide to spend money on this most vital resource, in the future everyone will damn us for neglecting it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I want to emphasise the importance of roads to all Australians. Some of us, particularly politicians, regularly use planes. Perhaps we do not get on the roads as often as people say we ought to. I know that that happens in my electorate at times. People sometimes say that if their member were on the roads a little more often they might have better roads. Many people use trains as a means of transport around the cities, but with the extensive use of cars we all want and need good roads. Having worked in the Main Roads Department for 14 years before I got married I can speak with a lot of authority on this report on the assessment of the Australian road system.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is only a few years ago.

—I thank Senator Button. It is only a few years ago-but we will not count them up. I ended up working for the Main Roads Commissioner. Councils were always wanting more money for roads, and the story is still the same.

SPEECH.PARA: In conjunction with this Federal Bureau of Transport Economics report on the assessment of the Australian road system for 1987 a report by the National Association of Australian State Road Authorities called the Australian Roads Outlook Report is being released this week. That report, as I understand it, has certainly made a point of the fact that the roads are aging-a bit like some of us, I suppose. The population of Australia is also aging. Fifty-five per cent of roads are already more than 20 years old. The amount of heavy road freight traffic is growing rapidly. Some 77 per cent of all freight goes by road these days, despite the train services available.

Over 80 per cent of all travellers throughout Australia use roads. That is sometimes hard to believe when one gets into an aeroplane and sees how many people are travelling that way. But that is the fact. It is quite correct. The commitment to the preservation of existing roads has to double. The unfortunate thing is that the level of funds being provided by the Federal Government is falling. The Cameron Independent Committee of Inquiry into the Distribution of Federal Road Grants, which is mentioned on page 59 of this report, is of very great significance to the road situation at the present time. If the Cameron principles were applied to all Federal road funding, Queensland's share would be cut from 21 per cent to 16 per cent, which would mean a loss of $34m per annum at the present funding level. Of course, that would be devastating.

We should remember that roads support the industries that generate our nation's wealth. Road funding should support industries generating this wealth and our export earnings. The tourism industry, particularly in Queensland, needs better roads for tourists. We need road infrastructure where major resorts are developed and general road infrastructure where cities, such as Cairns or those on the Gold Coast, grow from tourism. I suppose that there are many other examples. New gold mines are being served by deficient roads that need attention. There is inadequate road infrastructure in the coalfields and an inability to haul road trains carrying cattle in the far outback. Mr Acting Deputy President, you would know of the very narrow roads in the far outback. As a result, road trains find it hard to travel on them. We need money. We really need to think about this for a little longer than the five minutes we are given to speak about these reports. This is a very comprehensive and long report and one I recommend to all honourable senators.

DEBATE.TITLE: REVIEW OF TENDER PROCEDURES FOR THE COASTWATCH CONTRACT

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report brought down this morning is very important. Not all senators have had the opportunity of going through it in detail. A number of matters in it throw great doubt on earlier statements by Ministers and the Government in this place and in the House of Representatives concerning the progress and the procedures adopted concerning the letting of the contract to Amann Aviation Pty Ltd.

TALK.START.PARA: —Grossly improper.

—As Senator Baume has mentioned, a number of matters require further examination. I suppose we should be grateful that the Senate Standing Committee on Infrastructure currently has an inquiry before it into the whole question of how the contract came to be let to Amann. SPEECH.PARA: Let me point to just a few things that come out of the report-they virtually leap out at a reader-which indicate that the Government has a lot more to answer for than it has yet admitted in respect of this report. Firstly, let me quote from the findings set down by Mr Menzies on page 70 of the report where he refers, firstly, to the period available to the Department of Transport for processing tenders being `unduly compressed and this processing had to be carried out in too short a period.' Many of us have been saying that for a long time. The question unanswered is why the procedures were compressed into such a short time frame.

TALK.START.PARA: —Perhaps the Minister can tell us.

—The Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) has now arrived in the chamber. Perhaps he can tell us. We certainly need to have more answers on that point. Mr Menzies goes on later in the report to point out that that did not happen and that all the signs went up in such a clear way but the Government apparently ignored them and did not examine those points via its various officials working on this project. Later there is a reference to the fact that the Director of Supply and Services in the relevant section of the Department of Transport and Communications, who was a member of the Tender Acceptance Committee, was asked to carry out such an investigation and indeed the Director reported the result of his investigation to be satisfactory. SPEECH.PARA: If Amann's costings had been competently investigated, the result would have been to cast considerable doubt on Amann's financial and administrative competence.

That is a damning statement. The report contains other statements-there is not much time left-but I make the point that these statements lead us to conclude that many questions are yet to be answered. Quite clearly, answers given in this place and in other places need further examination and for that reason I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join in expressing my concern about this matter not only in terms of the findings in this report but also because of some other matters which were not dealt with. I would like to stress that the conclusions of the Review of Tender Procedures for the Coastwatch Contract report are greatly damning of the incompetence within the Department of Transport and Communications, particularly after it became evident in mid-January 1987 to the Tender Assessment Committee-that is, the body comprising representatives of interested departments charged with assessing tenders-that there were some problems. SPEECH.PARA: If Amann's costings had been competently investigated, the result would have been to cast considerable doubt on Amann's financial and administrative competence.

What concerns me is not only those issues-and I have not time to discuss much more of them-but also an extraordinary exchange that took place in April of this year at a Senate Estimates committee after it had become evident in January that there were some problems. The section I want to deal with is the extraordinary exchange that took place between Senator Gietzelt and me over one additional question and that is whether or not the granting of this tender to Amann Aviation Ltd involved the unnecessary expenditure of funds overseas at a time when we were entering-and we are still in it-a very serious balance of payments problem which has now developed into perhaps an even greater crisis. TALK.START.PARA: —What will be the final, all-up cost of importing these aircraft?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The appalling thing about today's reports that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) steelworks at Port Kembla could close down because of continuing industrial unrest is not simply that that industrial unrest has continued in defiance of the steel industry plan to which the Government has allocated $100m by way of bounty-that is, taxpayers' money-on the basis of undertakings from steel workers, or that the company has spent $800m of shareholders' funds on an undertaking from the unions that they would behave responsibly; that is bad enough. The most serious point is that the Government has shown no will whatsoever to require the unions to keep their part of this tripartite bargain. It is not as if something has suddenly blown up. The Government knew about this months ago. I quote what Senator Button said in March this year. Of course, he did nothing, but this is what he said:

SPEECH.PARA: I agree entirely that it is an absurd dispute-
referring to industrial disputes at Port Kembla; I agree it is an absurd dispute--

that it is a threat to Australia's reputation as a supplier of raw materials and manufactured goods, and that it is at odds with the best endeavours that this country should be making in industrial relations.

That was said in March. What did this Minister do about it? Exactly nothing. In May it was reported that the BHP steelworks at Port Kembla had been forced to withdraw from valuable export markets in the Philippines, Korea, the United States, China and New Zealand because of the crippling industrial campaign by south coast unions, described by the New South Wales Industrial Commissioner, Justice William Fisher, as `industrial anarchy'. What did this dynamic Minister, who is supposed to be in charge of the steel industry plan, do about it? Absolutely nothing. As a result, there is the prospect that the steelworks could be closed. In May, the Sydney Morning Herald editorial read:

. . . Senator Button, the architect of the steel plan, spelled all this out to deaf ears some days ago. Wollongong, he said, could not afford the `luxury' of returning to the days when industrial disputation forced BHP to be unprofitable and countries like China to refuse long-term contracts because it was unsure of supply. The warning was ignored in favour of the old tactics of relying on industrial muscle rather than reason and research.

Of course, what did Senator Button do? He, with extraordinary enthusiasm and at great personal risk to every unionist, wagged his little finger at them. Nothing was done. We now have a situation in which BHP has been forced to abandon, hopefully only for the time being, its plans to replace its No. 4 blast furnace. Something like $200m worth of investment has already been cancelled in Wollongong because of industrial disruption, but this Government is continuing to do nothing. Why will not this Minister do something about the matter?

During the Senate Estimates committee hearings I asked what sanctions were available to the Minister. He said that there were none. Without being unfair and abbreviating his response, he did not think it was appropriate that any sanctions that could be imposed on a union which rats on a deal such as this one should be available to a government. The third part of this deal, which involved multi-millions of dollars of taxpayers' and shareholders' money, was co- operation from the trade union movement, co-operation which had been denied. The Minister can come into this place and say, `That is just all too bad. There is nothing I can do about it'. He waves his finger, speaks, but does nothing. This situation is an absolute disgrace. The Steel Industry Authority annual report we are debating today reveals the extent of that disaster. It warns of the threat to this industry as a whole. We are now seeing, from what is happening this week in BHP discussions, that the threats outlined by the Steel Industry Authority, the risks of the industry being shattered, are not just idle threats. Unfortunately, they now have every prospect of coming to fruition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak briefly on the Steel Industry Authority and the steel plan. Let me state at the outset, as I did previously when I spoke on this matter, that there is nothing wrong inherently with the steel plan. It is a good plan, but it is like a tripod. One leg of the tripod is Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd which, of course, has maximum financial exposure of something over $800m. I believe that this figure is heading towards $1.2 billion. The second leg of the tripod is the Government, which has a commitment of the order of $100m of taxpayers' money. The third leg of the tripod is the unions, which have a commitment that they will go through the proper process before they do anything that will put the jobs of their members in jeopardy. In any tripod situation, if one leg fails the whole thing comes cascading down and that is what has happened in this case.

SPEECH.PARA: I was absolutely appalled during Question Time at the off-handed way in which the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, who was the author of this plan-and I have said it is inherently a good plan-answered questions that were asked by Senator Lewis and Senator Chaney. He was more inclined to sit on his hands and do nothing. If my memory is correct, he said in answer to one of those questions that the Steel Industry Authority had called a meeting in October and that he did not intend to do much else about the matter. He also said that the record had been pretty good, so why get too fussed.

Let us look very quickly at that record. In the six months to June 1984 alone something like 62,950 man hours were lost. In six months to December 1984 56,000 man hours were lost; in the six months to June 1985 56,000; in the six months to December 1985 45,000; in the six months to June 1986 166,000; and in the six months to December 1986 67,000. In the six months to June 1987 a record 359,000 man hours were lost. Senator Button considers that a pretty good industrial record. The industry was on its knees and very serious decisions had to be made as to whether it would even continue in Australia. For many reasons, not least the strategic reason, we need a steel industry in Australia. So every effort had to be made by the three parties involved to do something about the matter.

What I found appalling was the fact that Senator Button said that he intended to do nothing else and that there was no role for the Government. At no time did he indicate why this industrial disputation occurred. Noises were made about better communications between management and the workers. The reason massive industrial disputation occurred in June had nothing to do with any industrial matter. It was simply that the South Coast Labour Council of New South Wales was on strike because it opposed changes to workers compensation by the New South Wales Labor Government. So, for straight political reasons a militant union leadership is doing its damnedest to torpedo what I have mentioned a number of times is a first class plan.

It is interesting to note comments made by the Caucus industry committee chairman, Mr Stephen Martin, whose electorate covers this area. He must have tried to cover up the position with tongue in cheek because he would be very much aware of the real situation. All he could say was that the company had spoken-he was not prepared to do it himself-of the appalling industrial relations record in the year to 31 June but that there had been a significant improvement since then. I am not sure what a `significant improvement' is. Something like 60,000 man hours being lost in a quarter does not seem to be a recipe for improvement.

Senator Button also said that this matter should not be aired publicly. I have not heard anything more ridiculous in my life. What on earth are we supposed to do? Are we supposed to keep it hidden under wraps like all of the other restrictive work practices? These matters must be aired publicly so the public knows where its money is being spent and whether it is being spent wisely. I cannot understand Senator Button's position on the matter because, after all, the Labor Government in this place is the political arm of the trade union movement.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Steel Industry Authority's 1986-87 annual report is the latest of a series of reports which have indicated very serious trouble with the Government's steel industry plan. This report warrants careful consideration by the Senate as the plan and the industry are of great importance to Australia. In announcing the plan in December 1983, Senator Ryan, on behalf of the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, said that the plan is seen by the Government, the industry and the union movement as being essential to reverse the decline in the industry's fortunes and that it represents a new approach to industry policy in Australia. The fact that we have not seen over the last two years a reversal of decline but a return to decline is a matter of very great concern to the Opposition and we challenge the approach to industry policy which has been adopted by the present Government and the Minister, Senator Button. In a statement of 8 December the Government says that the plan has been developed as a co-operative effort involving undertakings from all parties with an interest in the development of the industry, including the steel producers, the steel unions and the Commonwealth Government. The statement goes on to say that the plan seeks to overcome the underlying problems confronting the industry and its success will depend upon the various undertakings being adhered to.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the undertakings which was entered into by the trade union movement was adherence to dispute settling procedures. Quite clearly, union adherence to the plan has been seriously at fault not just in recent months but also over a period of some years. The Minister has shown an extraordinary incapacity to come to grips with the problems which have been emerging over this time and a great unwillingness to address himself to these matters in this chamber, although from time to time he has allowed himself to criticise union activity. I remind the Senate that the Steel Industry Authority annual report for 1985-86 stated:

If this pattern of industrial disputation continues, it does not augur well for the success of the industry over the remainder of the Plan and, consequently, for the longer-term security of employment.

It ill becomes the Minister to say that all of these matters should be dealt with confidentially, quietly and that he does not want to comment, when the Steel Industry Authority reported on the year 1985-86 in those terms. A dramatic worsening of the situation is portrayed in the 1986-87 annual report which we are now debating. It also sits ill in the Minister's mouth to be seeking to excuse the emerging failure of the steel plan on the admitted difficulties that have occurred with respect to some of the new capital investment. I want to draw the attention of the Senate to the fact that while Senator Button has been careful to draw attention to the difficulties with respect to capital investment, that matter is specifically dealt within the report that the Steel Industry Authority has put before us. On page 3, the report says:

While recognising the significance of capital investment to the long-term viability of the domestic steel industry, it is the management of the industry's labour resources that is of the greatest immediate concern to the Authority.

Why should that be the greatest area of concern? It is straightforward, and clear from the evidence in the report. There has been a 100 per cent increase in industrial disputes over the previous year, when the previous year was already regarded as a situation that warranted the concern of the Steel Industry Authority. The problem is clearly centred on Port Kembla, and a major national interest is being put at risk by a minority of trade unionists who are not prepared to join their fellow workmates in establishing the security that this industry requires.

I hope that there will be another opportunity to debate this report. The Government's refusal to face up to its responsibilities in industrial relations is being made quite apparent. I, for one, am sick of the claims being made by the Government that it has a special relationship with the trade unions, a special relationship that is certainly not reflected in any capacity of the Government to deal with this significant problem.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government is on its knees to the unions.

—As Senator Stone points out, the special relationship is that the Government is on its knees to the trade union group, and that seems to me to be a fair assessment of the situation. Australia is suffering here. The steel industry, which is so fundamentally important to Australia, is being put at risk by irresponsible trade union action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —At an earlier time we were discussing this report--

—I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy President. Senator Messner spoke for five minutes earlier today on this subject. I do not want to inhibit his freedom of speech and ability to wax lyrical on this subject, but I do not think that he is entitled to have another go.
—There is no substance to the point of order. The matter was adjourned earlier to be considered under General Business. It is now General Business, and Senator Messner is entitled to speak again.
—Thank you, Mr Deputy President. I hope that that will not come out of my time.
—I rise on a further point of order. Senator Messner did not seek leave to continue his remarks.

—What happens under the system, which is in a sessional order that I think you are the author of, Senator Evans, is that if a matter is adjourned under consideration of Government Papers, it comes up again under General Business and senators may speak again, regardless of what has happened before. It was properly put on the General Business section of the Notice Paper.
—I apologise to the Chair and to Senator Messner.

—I hope that all that did not come out of my time, either. This report is sprinkled with various statements, a few of which I shall quote to give the flavour of the report. The findings include such statements as:

SPEECH.PARA: Officers concerned in assessing the tenders appeared to have proceeded under a basic misconception.
Here is another beauty:
. . . a full and competent evaluation of matters other than technical compliance of tenders does not appear to have been undertaken.
Here is another:
Senior management of the D.O.T. did not exercise sufficient supervision of the matter.
Another is:
. . . confusion between D.O.T. and D.O.A. as to the role of the representatives of the latter Department on the T.A.C.-

that is, the Tender Acceptance Committee. We go on with many such references in the findings of the inquiry by Mr Menzies, which leads one only to the conclusion that the Government has an absolute shambles on its hands in this regard. Perhaps the most important statement of all appears in the body of the report, on page 10. Here, Mr Menzies, among other things, when talking about financial matters and managerial questions in the relevant Departments and questioning the capacity and competence of the tenderer to undertake the process, says:
Recognised risk analysis techniques are available, but in the ultimate, it falls to the decision maker to decide what is an acceptable risk to the Commonwealth.

It seems to me that that opens the very matter that we have been seeking to pursue in the Senate and the House of Representatives over several months, and that is that, in the end, it is the Minister who is responsible for the decision as to whether any contract of this kind should be granted. That matter is plainly before us now, and the report highlights it.

Let us leave aside that most important point and turn to the Press statement made by the Minister for Transport and Communications (Senator Gareth Evans) today as he put this report into the Senate. In the second paragraph on page 2 of the statement he says:

The report does not recognise disciplinary action against any staff. However, relevant staff, including senior managers, will be counselled concerning the deficiencies noted in the report, and appropriate training will be arranged.

This comes after having read to the Senate several of the bald statements from the report made by Mr Menzies which clearly call into question the competence and capacity of the members of the staff of the department concerned with this matter. Now the Minister seeks to say, `All we need do with these chaps, who have made a gross mistake, is give them some kind of training and counselling'. I think that that is absurd. Clearly, issues need to be examined by the Minister and he needs to take the matter a great deal more seriously than his Press statement would indicate. Surely, given the need for basic competence and financial capacity on the part of people putting in tenders, there is a greater need for financial examinations and/or other action to be taken by the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking about this earlier, I mentioned that in the Estimates committee hearings Senator Gietzelt had tried to stop public servants responding on the matter of whether or not the balance of payments considerations should have been an element in consideration of this tender. When Senator Gietzelt intervened and said it was not a matter for the public servant, I asked Senator Gietzelt, as the Minister, the following question:

SPEECH.PARA: Were any balance of payments implications taken into account by the Government in the granting of this contract?
Senator Gietzelt replied:
I am not aware of any, and I do not think it was necessary to do so.
I then asked:

Is it possible, within the need for confidentiality, for the Senate to be given an indication of the balance of payments costs of the decision to award this contract, which involves the purchase of totally new equipment from overseas at a time when our balance of payments is in crisis?
Senator Gietzelt replied in a particularly arrogant way by saying:
I will refer that question to the Minister, but my advice to him would be not to respond.
The Senate will not be surprised to hear that I have had no reply. I went on to ask:
Would any of the other tenderers have been obliged to purchase new equipment, new aircraft from overseas to fulfil the contract?
Dr Kay replied:

I really cannot answer that. The tender required that they nominate aircraft, and they do that by tail number. No check on any of the other tenderers was done to determine whether they would need to buy aircraft in Australia or overseas.
Senator Vanstone, who took a prominent role in this matter and who should be congratulated on her cross-examination of the public servants involved back in April, then asked:

Do I understand, from what you have said and without taking time to search through the tender, that there is no `buy Australian' requirement for any proportion of equipment to be purchased in the tender?
Dr Kay replied:
That is my understanding.

It seems absolutely incredible that this Government, which takes empty postures about the need for people to do what they can to assist Australia in this time of trade crisis, did not even have the administrative procedures available to consider whether or not it was ludicrous to accept a tender which involved the total purchase of new equipment from overseas. There was no interdepartmental discussion and no concern. The Minister in charge of the Senate Estimates committee debate did what he could to block discussion of that issue in the committee. He did what he could to ensure that no response came to me from the Minister in the other place because he said that he would advise him to that effect. That is an absolute disgrace, but it is in keeping with this Government's arrogant approach to the whole tender process, to the whole Amann Aviation Ltd scandal. Let us recognise that the meetings were held in April. In mid-January 1987, the report reveals, it was apparent to the Government that Amann had little relevant experience in the aviation industry. The report states:
while he had plans for a future organization to work under the contract, he had no organization in place other than a family partnership; and
had no aircraft suitable for operation under the contract.
The report concludes:
These facts called for at least a particularly rigorous examination of Amann's capacity, financial and otherwise, and competence to perform the contract for its full life.

The report also makes the point that the Department and the Government should have been put on alert that Amann's stated profit of one to 2 per cent on turnover at the end of the project-I might say that that was a very thin margin-should have indicated a need for particularly close scrutiny to assess quality and reliability of the proposed service. Yet no skilled financial examination was undertaken by the Department. The report outlines how ludicrous it was that no skilled inquiry took place and that no one was asked to undertake such a task. The investigation failed to bring to notice errors and other deficiencies in the financial statements submitted in support of the tender. I believe it is a disgrace that this Government quite happily presided over this matter when there was a total failure by the officers in charge of the Department involved to act appropriately, and although the Minister was aware of the concerns in mid-January 1987, which are revealed in the report, he took no action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate is of the opinion that in view of the predicted and observed changes to the Earth's ozone layer which will cause damage to many terrestrial and aquatic life forms, including increased human disease, the Government should urgently introduce legislation to prevent the release of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) to the atmosphere by requiring that-
(a) use of CFCs be no longer allowed in any pressure pack preparations;

(b) all new refrigerators and airconditioners be fitted with pipe work so designed that CFCs can be readily removed, condensed and recycled and that there be a mandatory requirement to do so whenever equipment of this type needs regassing;
(c) where CFCs are used as foam expanders or solvents, these operations be carried out in closed systems, the CFC gas being pumped out, condensed and recycled;
(d) when equipment containing CFCs is scrapped, the contained CFCs be removed, condensed and recycled;
(e) motor vehicle airconditioners meet stringent standards with regard to CFC containment; and
(f) any other steps designed to prevent the release of CFCs to the atmosphere be taken.

This motion addresses what I believe is one of the most important problems ever to face mankind. It is a very large and general problem to do with the progressive deterioration of the global environment, including the loss of species, the loss of diversity of experience and the permanent-I repeat, permanent-fouling of the human nest with pollutants that the natural environment simply cannot handle. The problem originates in an attitude which has characteristically developed among European-derived societies, including our own Australian society, and it is an attitude which treats all non-self items, whether they be animals, plants or other people, as objects for exploitation. I would contrast that attitude fundamentally with that of most indigenous people, including the Australian Aboriginal people, who have adopted a more animist and celebratory approach to the natural environment. It is one which, in the year leading up to the Bicentenary, we would do well to adopt.

The European exploitative approach has been strongly buttressed in the last two centuries, and particularly in the last half-century, by an economic model which ignores the limits of the natural world-the ability of the natural world to provide the resources which our industrial society demands and the ability of the natural world to cope with the increasing level of pollution which the industrial society is heaping on it. This economic model teaches that endless economic growth is both desirable and sustainable. This is the economic model which is espoused by both the Labor Government and the Opposition parties. As I have shown elsewhere, this type of economy is neither desirable nor sustainable. It is this which makes the Australian Democrats separate from all other political parties in this place.

The human economy is a subset of the global ecology, and the former-the human economy-can expand only at the expense of the latter. That is something which this and previous governments have failed to recognise. The one thing that growth of gross national product measures accurately is increasing damage to the natural environment. The Australian Democrats espouse a sustainable steady-state economic model. The growth which the pro-growth parties are attempting is exponential. Therefore, it is not surprising to find that damage to the global atmosphere, which we are discussing this afternoon, is escalating rapidly and its consequences will persist for many years, even after effective remedial action has been taken.

A reality easy to lose sight of, especially in the hurly-burly of political life, is that, from a biological point of view, homo sapiens is a very young animal indeed. We probably separated from our last common ancestor as little as six million years ago and in that time we have gone through about 240,000 generations. We went through those generations before the agricultural revolution, which was nearly 10,000 years or approximately 400 generations ago. Some of us on this planet have lived an industrial lifestyle for about eight generations. A few people arrogantly assume that this tiny fragment of our human history is the normal human state and can be extrapolated into the distant future.

Cosmologists indicate that the human animal may have a further 500 million years life left on this planet provided that it does not continue to foul its nest and that we look after its environment. This we are not doing and we must change our practices pretty damned quickly. We are changing the environment at a prodigious rate and nowhere is that more apparent than in the atmosphere. The rate of atmospheric change is more rapid than at any period in the earth's long history. Going back 10,000 million years, long before humankind ever appeared on the face of the planet, we see that the atmosphere is now changing more rapidly than at any stage in that long period, and it has been caused by human industrial developments.

The burning of fossil fuel returns carbon to the atmosphere at an incredible rate. It is returning this carbon in the form of carbon dioxide. This carbon dioxide was removed from the primitive and reducing early atmosphere when primitive plants had evolved to the stage of developing photosynthesis-that is, the ability to remove carbon dioxide from the atmosphere, to fix the carbon into living tissues and to return the oxygen to the atmosphere using sunlight as the energy source. Some of this fixed carbon became locked away in fossil deposits of coal and oil.

Each year we return to the atmosphere an amount of carbon, as carbon dioxide, which took nature about one million years to lay down as coal or oil deposits. Last year the Department of Resources and Energy, under the then Minister, Senator Evans, published 10 small volumes on energy policy in which the words `carbon dioxide' appeared once. Such is the level of ignorance and disregard for environmental constraints of this Labor Government, which pushes its economic policy of pressing for more and more economic growth.

Carbon dioxide is the principal but not the only gas leading to what has been called the greenhouse effect. In 40 to 50 years greenhouse warming will lead to a rise in global temperature of between 1.5 and 4.5 degrees centigrade, with major changes in the pattern of weather, agriculture and food production. It is expected that sea levels will rise by about one metre, with a loss of many, possibly most, urban beaches in Australian cities and the flooding of many low lying areas. These are not wild and unsubstantiated claims. They have been made by the International Council of Scientific Unions, the World Meteorological Office, the United Nations Environment Program and the United States Environment Protection Agency.

Of course, the sea level rise will not stop there, even if by then we have learned not to mess with the atmosphere-the atmosphere in which we all evolved and to which all terrestrial plants and animals are adapted. The system will take quite a lot longer to come into equilibrium with that temperature rise. That equilibrium in fact will correspond to a sea level rise of between five metres and seven metres-much higher than now-and, of course, will lead to the flooding of most of the major cities of the world, including those of Australia. These changes and the further changes which I will shortly describe, will occur within the lifetime of our children and our grandchildren; that is within the lifetime of people whom we will know and whom we will cherish. It is within our lifetimes. However, as a society it appears that we pay no heed to those things we are now doing and which are bringing these incredibly rapid changes about.

It is important to set the context for this afternoon's debate. Industrial practice is bringing about unprecedented and rapid change to the global atmosphere in many ways, and through a number of processes which are intimately interwoven through the texture of our industrial society. Damage to the ozone layer, with consequent increase in short wave ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth's surface, happens just to be the most imminently threatening and therefore is the aspect which this motion seeks to tackle. However, honourable senators must remember that these ozone and ultraviolet changes are going on against a background of accelerating other changes which are equally disturbing, but perhaps over a longer time frame.

As I have indicated already, ozone, or 03, did not always provide a shield against lethal short wave ultraviolet radiation from the sun. Indeed, in the primitive earth there was probably a reducing atmosphere which was very rich in gases such as carbon dioxide and methane. Oxygen probably appeared in abundance in the earth's atmosphere only as a consequence of photosynthesis. Only after the ozone shield was in place could extensive colonisation of the land by plants and animals take place. Those who support the Gaia concept see this photosynthesis oxygen ozone ultraviolet protection sequence as one of the biosphere's self-protective homeostatic mechanisms. It is that mechanism which we are very rapidly destroying. Ozone is the principal protection against short wave ultraviolet B and ultraviolet C, which are lethal to terrestrial life.

Reduction in ozone differentially increases the shorter wave ultraviolet radiation reaching the earth. It is this short wave ultraviolet radiation which is the most damaging to living cells. Proteins and DNA are the two essential building blocks of all living things-proteins, in their functioning as enzymes and DNA as the material which carries the genetic message from one generation to the next. Both these chemicals absorb ultraviolet radiation in the short wave band region. Proteins absorb it at about 280 nanometres and DNA absorbs it at 260 nanometres. Of course, these are the wave lengths which are most damaging to these substances which are vital to living tissues.

A 10 per cent reduction in stratospheric ozone will cause a 20 per cent increase in ultraviolet at less than 304 nanometres, a 250 per cent increase in ultraviolet below 290 nanometres and a 500 per cent increase in ultraviolet below 287 nanometres-precisely in the area in which most damage will occur. Therefore, there is a preferential and enormous enhancement of the lethal ultraviolet which reaches the earth's surface. The most careful and the most recent estimates, published only a few months ago in the journal Science, indicate that there has been a reduction of between one per cent and 3 per cent in the earth's ozone layer in the last 10 years.

Ozone is not evenly distributed throughout the earth's atmosphere. The changes also will not be uniformly distributed. Ninety per cent of the ozone occurs in the stratosphere with a maximum concentration at about 25 kilometres above the surface of the earth. Changes brought about by freons or the chlorofluorocarbons released will be greatest at high latitude and least at the equator. Over the last decade ozone levels in the Antarctic in the spring time have decreased by as much as 50 per cent.

Direct human health effects resulting from increased ultraviolet B are increased skin cancers and cataracts and damage to the immune system and its responses. It is estimated that for every one per cent shift in ultraviolet B exposure there will be a 2 per cent increase in skin cancers. In Question Time this afternoon we heard that there has been a substantial increase necessary in the treatment of skin cancers in Australia. However, the indirect effects on humans through damage to the biosphere generally are likely to be far more serious than these.

Many plants are damaged by increases in ultraviolet B. These effects are not uniform so that in a crop of useful plants one might find that the useful plants are more extensively damaged, for instance, than the weeds. I ask honourable senators to remember that these changes are not going on by themselves but against substantial other changes which are generally known under the rubric of the greenhouse effect. Agriculture is likely to be seriously disrupted. Reliable computer modelling shows that marginal agriculture-that is descriptive of most agriculture in Australia-is likely to be most severely affected. Agricultural practices in some areas will require total change. However, beyond that many of the microscopic life forms which form the base of the aquatic food chain, in lakes, rivers and oceans, spend part of their juvenile life cycle in the top millimetre or so of water where they are exposed to intense ultraviolet radiation, to which they are exquisitely sensitive. Already there are quite high naturally occurring death rates among the small phytoplankton and zooplankton in the oceans. It is thought that quite small increases in ultraviolet B could substantially reduce the population of this critical part of ocean life.

The human population obtains something like 100 million tonnes of high quality protein each year from the ocean. This source of food is jeopardised by freon-caused ozone depletion. Concern about atmospheric ozone began in 1974 when Dr Sherwood Rowland and Dr Mario Molina, chemists from the University of California at Irvine, posed the question: What is happening to the tons of freons being released into the atmosphere? Freons or chlorofluorocarbons, also called CFCs, were first synthesised in 1928 by chemists from the General Motors company searching for a less toxic and non-flammable refrigerant gas. It is interesting that it took from 1928 until 1974 before anybody posed the question as to whether these substances were dangerous to the environment. That says something about the way our society regards the human environment as a sink for pollutants. Since 1928 freons have come into general use, principally as refrigerant gases in refrigerators and air conditioners. However from the 1950s they found increasing use as pressure pack propellants and expanding gases in the manufacture of plastic foams such as polystyrene and polyurethane foams. More recently a new freon, freon 113, has been used extensively as a solvent in the electronics industry, particularly for cleaning microchips.

Drs Rowland and Molina realised that the CFCs were gases that were both very stable and not water soluble. They simply asked the question: `Where the hell are they going?' They argued that, as they could not find any sink for them, their concentration in the lower atmosphere must be increasing and that therefore they would slowly rise through the atmosphere into the stratosphere, where the intense ultraviolet light would photodegrade them, releasing atomic chlorine. They realised immediately that this atomic chlorine would catalyse the conversion of ozone to oxygen. This reaction has since been identified and is now well characterised. It is a truly catalytic reaction in that one atom of chlorine is able to destroy many thousands of molecules of ozone until it is washed out of the atmosphere as hydrochloric acid. I think, as honourable senators will realise, the amount of moisture in the atmosphere at an altitude of 25 kilometres is very small and that is why these substances persist for a very long time.

This initially theoretical prediction that the stratosphere provided the only sink for the freons and that their breakdown in the stratosphere would result in ozone destruction was made in 1974 in an article in Nature and to a meeting of the American Chemical Society. Rowland and Molina even then predicted that, if nothing was done to restrict the use of freons within 10 years, ozone destruction would continue throughout much of the twenty-first century. Although strongly resisted by the freon manufacturers, notably Du Pont, the theoretical prediction was confirmed by the United States Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), the United States Food and Drug Administration, the United States National Academy of Science and the United States National Aeronautics and Space Administration. A ban on the use of freons as aerosol propellants was imposed by the United States in 1978.

Intense research was then begun into what was happening to ozone world-wide. Only Sweden, Canada and Norway joined the United States in legislating to restrict the releases of freons from pressure packs. From that time in Australia reliance has been placed on a voluntary withdrawal of freons from pressure packs, but by 1985 25 per cent of pressure packs still contained freon propellants. Pressure packs containing CFCs are, even now, widely available in Australian shops and Australia is responsible for adding 2,000 tonnes of CFCs to the atmosphere from pressure packs each year.

Since 1974, understanding of the chemistry of ozone interaction with atmospheric pollutants has grown, as has the understanding of global air circulation and climate. The incorporation of new knowledge into computer models has caused predictions of the rate, extent and distribution of ozone depletions to vary widely. It is now known that a number of other pollutant gases participate in the ozone balance, but, in general, the observed ozone depletion has considerably exceeded that which computer models predicted. For instance, the Antarctic ozone hole was not predicted nor satisfactorily explained until quite recently.

It takes about five years for CFCs released at the surface of the earth to rise through the atmosphere into the stratosphere, where they begin to catalyse ozone depletion. Ozone reductions seen so far are therefore the result of activities of all freons released up to five years ago-1982. We are yet to see the result of the freons which have been released in the last five years. They have not yet got to the stratosphere. But that is not the only lag in this system. Freons 11 and 12, the two freons in most common use, have residence times in the stratosphere of between 75 and 150 years. For this reason, freezing freon production or even modest reductions in production will make no significant change to this situation and it will continue to worsen at least until the end of the twenty-first century. Indeed, John Hoffman of the United States EPA has shown that to hold ozone damage constant-that is, that there be no more damage beyond that already caused-global release of freons would have to be cut by 85 per cent immediately and then held at or below this new level. Against this calculation the recent decisions at Montreal are seen to be far too little too late. Hoffman points out that there is an element of irreversibility about the processes which have already been set in train. He says:
Irreversibility is important because if one cannot go backwards, momentum threatens to take one forever beyond the point one wishes to go.

Let me say several other things about the Montreal agreement. Some may argue that in absolute amounts Australia's use of CFCs is not large and, therefore, what we do is not so very important. I believe this is wrong for several reasons. Firstly, Australia's per capita use of CFCs is five times the world average. Therefore, each Australian contributes five times as much to ozone damage as the average world citizen. In this global problem we must behave as responsible global citizens. Secondly, the Montreal agreement recommends certain reductions but does not suggest how these reductions may be brought about. My motion shows how these and greater reductions may be achieved. Moreover, the Montreal treaty is in danger of falling apart on this very point. Thirdly, the technical changes suggested in my motion are relatively simple. Mastery of them by Australia could provide a technology which could be exported. There are examples of other polluting industries being controlled by legislative requirements to recycle pollutants becoming even more efficient with lowering of prices and improvements in overall production. Fourthly, as a member of the human tribe and one with an advanced industrial economy, I believe we have a responsibility to use our position to act as a model for those nations not so well endowed.

Turning specifically to the motion, I point out that again there is no inconsistency between what I am proposing and the Montreal treaty. It simply provides a mechanism for achieving not only the reduction sought by the treaty, but the much greater reductions in freon release which, clearly, must be quickly brought about. Moreover, it seeks to address the real problem, which is not freon manufacture but freon release. When freon is contained it causes no problems.

Finally, it does not demand substantial changes in technology with associated long lead times. If alternative refrigerant gases are to be used, then substantial redesign of refrigeration units is likely to be required and this is not likely to be done in the time available. However, one must agree that in the longer term it is clearly desirable that freons be phased out altogether.

Paragraph 1 of my motion quite simply asks the Government to legislate to ban the use of freons in pressure packs. As already explained, this was done some years ago in the United States, Canada, Sweden and Norway, and those countries do not seem to have been severely inhibited industrially or economically by this action. Compared with the damage which freons are causing, the claim for continued use of pressure packs is trivial and without any real force. Alternative methods of application of those substances which are now applied by pressure packs are readily available. I point out again that this would save some 2,000 tonnes of freons going into the atmosphere each year, which is about a quarter of one per cent of world release.

The other parts of the motion relate to the use of freons in situations where they could well be confined. At present if a refrigerator or an airconditioner leaks and requires replacement of the freon gas, the technician who carries out that work simply comes along, bleeds the remaining freon to atmosphere, checks the unit for leaks and then attaches a unit containing a measured amount of freon and regases the refrigerator. It is relatively simple that refrigerators and airconditioners be equipped with flanged and threaded joints so that when some gas has been lost it is possible to pump the remaining gas out, to condense that gas and, if required, to redistil it to separate any oil or water which may be mixed with it, and return it so that it can be recycled, and that freon never gets to the atmosphere at all. That is certainly possible with both refrigerators and air-conditioners. I have had advice from people who work in this industry, both at the practical level and at the manufacturing level, and I have been informed that these suggestions are both practical and simple and would not present any great difficulty in terms of tooling up.

The use of CFCs as foam expanders is something which has been increasing in recent years. In most cases-in the manufacturer of things such as foam surfboards, plates, and cups-it would be relatively simple to carry out these operations in closed systems. After the foam has expanded, the gas can be simply pumped out with a vacuum pump and the freon can be condensed and recycled into the system. As I have already indicated, it may well be that by doing that these industries will become more competitive, more economic and far more efficient.

One area which causes some considerable concern relates to motor vehicle air conditioners. These units are notable for the number of times they leak freons into the atmosphere. Indeed, as long ago as 1976, the United States National Academy of Science suggested that it may be necessary to phase out of existence altogether the use of car air conditioners. However, I have been told that there are car air conditioners on the market which are sealed units not subject to such leaking. I have suggested, therefore, under paragraph 5, that there be a requirement that air conditioners in motor vehicles be made to meet stringent standards. Those stringent standards would relate to the ability of those units to hold their gas and not leak every few months. For those reasons I have moved the motion which is standing in my name and I commend it to the Senate as a way of extending practically the terms of the recently concluded Montreal treaty.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Puplick Sen C.J.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it an opportunity to discuss a very significant matter regarding the protection of the earth and, in particular, the question of the protection of the earth's atmosphere. The earth is surrounded by an atmosphere which consists principally of nitrogen, oxygen, argon and water vapour and a small quantity of carbon dioxide and trace amounts of ozone, carbon monoxide and methane. The importance of a small concentration of ozone in the upper levels of the earth's atmosphere lies in its ability to absorb ultraviolet radiation from the sun. The ozone, therefore, provides the earth with an effective shield and influences the thermal structure of the stratosphere. The majority of ozone is located in the stratosphere-that is to say, a region of the atmosphere lying between 10 and 50 kilometres above the surface of the earth. The concentration of ozone in that part of the atmosphere never reaches more than one-thousandth of one per cent and is determined by a balance between photochemical processes that produce it and other processes which destroy it. It is one of the processes of the destruction of that ozone layer in the earth's atmosphere that is the subject of today's debate.

SPEECH.PARA: As Senator Coulter has pointed out, the principal pollutant which causes the breakdown of the ozone in the earth's atmosphere is the chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs); in particular, two of those chlorofluorocarbons, namely, trichlorofluoromethane and dischlorodifluoromethane, commonly known as CFC11 and CFC12. The principal uses of these substances are to be found as propellants and solvents used in aerosol sprays, fluids in refrigeration and airconditioning equipment, foam blowing agents in plastic foam production and solvents used mainly in the electronics industry. The characteristics of the chlorofluorocarbons which have caused their use to be promoted are that they are of low toxicity, they are non-flammable, they have the ability to produce a fine spray, they have a very low odour, they are flexible in their formulations and they are relatively stable in storage.

The whole issue of the management of the earth's atmosphere is an extremely difficult one. Senator Coulter has mentioned a couple of things today, including the Gaia hypothesis and the greenhouse theory. The Gaia hypothesis generally commends itself to my understanding of the earth's environmental dynamics. The greenhouse theory is an interesting one for colleagues in the Australian Democrats to raise since the primary cause of the warming of the earth's atmosphere is the burning of fossil fuels. It is very interesting that that party, which makes such a great deal about the non-use or prohibition of nuclear energy-the alternative to which, of course, is the continued use of fossil fuels to produce our energy-should at the same time have so much to say about this subject. It is a mark of the general inconsistency of the approach taken to these issues by the Australian Democrats that allows them, on the one hand, to demand that we do something about the greenhouse effect and, on the other hand, to be so savage in their attacks upon the nuclear power industry, the consequence of which is to cause greater burning of fossil fuels and, therefore, a greater concentration of the greenhouse effect.

It is not that the greenhouse effect is without its critics. If one looks at the article by Broecker in the 9 July 1987 edition of Nature, one can see that a number of criticisms are raised. In particular, the evidence which he brings forward indicates that the changes in the earth's climate may be sudden rather than gradual. Therefore, some of the assumptions about the greenhouse effect may not be as sustainable as they were once thought to be. Indeed, this process of seeing changes in the environment and in nature as a more sudden rather than more gradual approach is not confined to discussions of atmospheric physics or atmospheric management. People will undoubtedly be aware that the theory of punctuated evolution put forward by Mayr, and more recently advanced by Gould, deals with the question of whether changes in the evolutionary processes are more rapid than we have been led to believe.
It is interesting that even in today's Australian newspaper there is an article under the heading `Greenhouse theory challenged', from which I quote in part:
The popularly accepted `greenhouse effect' climatic scenario, which predicts dramatic global changes for the earth, has been challenged by an Australian academic.

The article goes on to detail the work done by Dr Edward Bryant at the University of Wollongong, recently published in the Australian Geographer, which claims that the changes which are taking place in the atmosphere are natural rather than man made. The article continues:
But Dr Bryant says his analysis of world sea level records reveal that, in many places, sea levels actually have fallen.
And in areas where levels have risen, there are usually explanations.
For example, Dr Bryant says the sea level on one side of Japan's coast has risen by 24mm a year and on the other side it has fallen by 6mm.
The explanation is that mountain building is in process deep in the earth's crust.

I do not want to go on at length about Dr Bryant's work, but I simply say that the assumption that all these things are caused by man's impact upon the atmosphere is not something which can simply be asserted without a clear analysis of the evidence which needs to be put forward to sustain that hypothesis.

Yesterday I spoke to the motion to take note of certain treaty instruments which were before the Senate, including the provision which indicated Australia's adherence to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. It is certainly true that, since Rowland and Molina first discussed this phenomenon in 1974, this subject has been given an increasing degree of attention. The work that Rowland and Molina pioneered eventually led to the conclusion, under the auspices of the United Nations environment program, of the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone layer. I quote from that convention which provides in Article 2, sub-paragraph (b), that treaty parties should:

Adopt appropriate legislative or administrative measures and co-operate in harmonising appropriate policies to control, limit, reduce or prevent human activities under their jurisdiction or control should it be found that these activities have or are likely to have adverse effects resulting from modification or likely modification of the ozone layer.

The steps which were taken subsequent to the adoption of the Vienna Convention led to the adoption of the Montreal Protocol of 1987, to which I wish to come in a couple of minutes. As I said, measurements of the earth's ozone levels have produced a great deal of very startling information. World ozone levels are estimated, for instance, to have dropped by between 3 and 7 per cent in the past several decades. It has been drawn to our attention that every one per cent drop in the level of the earth's ozone layer is likely to lead to a 2 per cent increase in non-melanoma skin cancers. As I pointed out in my speech yesterday, Australia has probably the world's worst record as far as skin cancers are concerned.

In an article by Farmer and his colleagues, which appeared in the 10 September 1987 edition of the journal Nature, and entitled `Stratospheric trace gases in the spring 1986 Antarctic atmosphere', again we can see this matter discusses at some considerable length. It has been asserted that the measurements recently taken of ozone layers over the Antarctic are now the lowest they have ever been under any types of conditions. A great deal of very interesting work is being done in terms of the history of the earth's atmosphere. For instance, the other day on the Science Show it was reported that experiments in the United States have been undertaken using the bubbles of air trapped in amber, which is millions of years old. It has the capacity to release that air, within a vacuum, to allow us to measure the concentration of oxygen which may have been in the earth's atmosphere many millions of years ago. The data obtained from those experiments suggests that the proportion of oxygen in the earth's atmosphere has declined over several million years from something in the order of 33 per cent to a general level of 21 per cent these days. The exact nature of that over a prolonged period, which one measures from such things as bubbles of air trapped in amber or from ice cores taken from the Antarctic, has not entirely been satisfactorily analysed and explained.

Nevertheless, these concerns to which I have referred led to the adoption in Montreal of a protocol relating to the Vienna Convention. That Montreal Protocol provided in part for early action to limit the consumption of CFCs in each participating country to last year's level and to achieve a reduction of 20 per cent in 1993-94 and a further 30 per cent reduction in 1998-99. So the consumption of halons will be frozen at 1986 levels, within several years. In the Governor-General's speech opening this Parliament the Government mentioned the fact that it was its intention to proceed to ratification and take action arising from its adherence to the Montreal Protocol. It is interesting to note that the countries that have already indicated that they are signatories to the Montreal Protocol include the United States, all members of the European Community-except Greece and Spain-and countries generally of the industrialised world.

The industry about which we are talking is very important in the economic sense. The value of CFC production is estimated to be in the order of $US2 billion a year; so we are not talking about a small industry but one of some significance. It is important to understand that Australia has not been laggard in its approach to this problem. In 1983, the Australian Environment Council and the National Health and Medical Research Council (NHMRC) produced a report entitled Environmental Health and Economic Implications of the Use of Chlorofluorocarbons as Aerosol Propellants and Possible Substitutes. It drew attention to a number of facts which are worth putting on the record. The first is that the release of chlorofluorocarbons from aerosols in Australia has already been reduced by approximately 35 per cent from the peak year of 1974.

It is also important to note that the areas in which there tend to be the highest concentration of the use of chlorofluorocarbons in Australia include the personal care area; that is, such things as hair sprays, colognes, perfumes, deodorants and insect sprays. So when Senator Coulter comments on the excessive use of chlorofluorocarbons, saying that somehow we are responsible for five times the amount of world per capita discharge of chlorofluorocarbons into the atmosphere, that is a slightly disingenuous comment taken on its own without considering, for instance, that if one were measuring the use of insect repellents in Sweden or Finland, compared with the use in Australia, it would hardly be surprising for there to be a greater discharge of those products in Australia. I forebear from commenting on the relative contribution arising from the use of perfumes and deodorants. I simply say that these figures, taken in a purely raw form, tend to be somewhat misleading.

It is certainly true that two-thirds of the CFC discharges in Australia are the result of aerosol use. I am a person who tries to read the labels on products which I buy in the supermarket. I pay attention to those which have chlorofluorocarbons in them, as distinct from those which use hydrocarbon as an alternative propellant. The fact is that the hydrocarbon products tend to be the generic brands put out in Woolworths and Target and places where I usually shop.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't go to Target, do you?
—I certainly do. That perhaps is an added inducement.
—A house brand deodorant?
—No, I go there not for hair spray and deodorant, but for starch for my shirts and all the other things to which I have to pay attention.
—Do you do your own ironing as well?
—Absolutely.
—Order! The honourable senator will get back to the debate.
