—I am being assaulted by Senator McKiernan on the basis that I happen to be single and have to pay attention to such things as who irons my shirts.
—Some good woman is missing out.

—I do not concede that I am missing out. I just said I happen to be single. The other matter which I think is of particular relevance in Australia clearly is that the hole in the earth's ozone layer has been detected particularly over the Antarctic. It does appear that that hole is moving northwards and spreading towards the Equator. From a purely geographic and meteorological point of view, Australia is likely to be particularly at risk.

SPEECH.PARA: In South Australia an attempt has been made to pioneer some legislation. In April this year a Bill was put before the South Australian Parliament to ban the sale and manufacture in South Australia of aerosol containers containing chlorofluorocarbons. That came under attack by the Association of Fluorocarbon Consumers and Manufacturers and various vested interests concerned to see that that legislation did not pass. I have no sympathy with the attempt to prevent that legislation when the matter is capable of being considered within a legislative framework. After all, the use of CFCs and aerosols has been banned in the United States, Canada, Sweden, Norway and Denmark. Action has been taken in a number of other countries to achieve very significant reductions in the use of CFCs. The level of their use has also been regulated quite substantially in Denmark, Germany, Japan, the Netherlands, New Zealand and Switzerland. A number of companies have already sought to discharge their responsibilities voluntarily. In my speech yesterday I mentioned the McDonalds Corporation. I am a great frequenter of McDonalds establishments. McDonalds has taken positive steps by announcing that it will change from the foam packaging of its fast foods to a material that is not suspected of damaging the earth's ozone layer, a process which occurs as the packaging decays. I understand that whilst that has not yet been put into action in Australia it has nevertheless been adopted as a strategy by the Australian subsidiary of the McDonalds Corporation.

We do face a significant difficulty in dealing with Senator Coulter's motion. For good and proper reasons we were not aware until this morning that this motion was to be the matter for debate in General Business today. As a result, it has simply not been possible for this matter to be considered by the Opposition parties. I have not had the opportunity, as the shadow Minister for the environment, to take the policy recommendations contained within this motion to my shadow Cabinet colleagues or to my Party room. I have no doubt that Government members find themselves in exactly the same position. This motion, by being specific, by requiring, for instance, in sub-paragraph (a) of the motion before us that the use of CFCs be no longer allowed in any pressure pack preparation, requires us to consider some of the significant consequences of adopting it as a matter of public policy.

It may well be that that is the correct stand to take. It may well be that after consideration the Government and Opposition parties would be prepared to take that policy decision. What we are not prepared to do is take it on the run this afternoon. Therefore, I make an appeal to Senator Coulter that if he is serious about this matter-I accept that he is-he should not seek to press this matter to a vote this afternoon because in those circumstances, and for that reason only, the Opposition would not be able to vote for the motion. He should allow the debate to be adjourned and to be resumed after I have had an opportunity to raise this matter with the Opposition parties, and after Senator Richardson has had an opportunity to raise the matter in Caucus or in Cabinet for the matter to be determined. Then, hopefully, we would be able to get a unanimous resolution of the Senate dealing with an issue which we all accept to be of great significance.

Whether the Australian Democrats insist upon a vote on this motion will be a test not so much of the bona fides of the Opposition and the Government on this matter but a test of the bona fides of the Australian Democrats. Whilst they can get seven people together and make a decision fairly quickly within their party structure, it is not possible for the major parties to address such matters within the sort of time frame which has been put to us. Therefore, I hope that in the interests of getting this matter resolved in not a tripartisan way, as I was going to say, but by taking a multipartisan approach, Senator Coulter will allow the debate to be adjourned after Senator Collins has concluded his remarks and enable us to come back to it at some stage after the Government and Opposition parties have had an opportunity to discuss the precise terms of Senator Coulter's motion.

Nevertheless, I say that the underlying principle of the motion has our support. The issue is important and deserves to be aired, I suppose I should say, in parliamentary debate. It deserves to be discussed. I do not think any honourable senator would have any difficulty in saying that it is a matter on which urgent action needs to be taken. When the Government proceeds to the ratification of the Montreal Protocol, having already announced its adherence to the original Vienna Convention, we will be able to discuss this matter. If Senator Coulter-I believe this is his intention-brings forward a Bill for us to debate in precise terms, we will then be able to address the matter more specifically. Therefore, I conclude my remarks by explaining why, if the vote is taken, we will vote in the way in which I have indicated. The whole tenor of my speech I think makes it perfectly clear that the Opposition is concerned about the issue raised and we would be happy to support action after we have had an opportunity to consider the precise terms of the motion before us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Coulter for bringing this matter of chlorofluorocarbons, or CFCs, before the Senate. Indeed, it is timely that he has done so. As Senator Puplick has already said, we on this side of the House find ourselves in precisely the same position as he does in that we have had very little notice of this matter. Our Party has an extremely democratic way of dealing with issues of substance and importance such as this, but we have not had the time to consider, as we should consider, the very detailed implications of the motion currently before the Senate. I understand-I have obviously sought advice on this-that it is Senator Coulter's intention to proceed to a vote. Should that be the case, very regretfully and for precisely the same reasons as Senator Puplick has just enunciated and which I have just supported, we will be forced for those reasons only, to vote against it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is one other matter that I wish to discuss. I have some good news for Senator Coulter in this regard and in respect of the detail of the motion as well, which I will cover shortly. Senator Coulter will be pleased to know-and I am sure he does know-that the Government's response to this has been prompt, as already outlined by Senator Puplick when he mentioned the reference to this in the Governor-General's Speech, and the progress the Government has made, particularly this year, has been considerable. I will recount some of that shortly. I hope that both Senator Puplick and Senator Coulter will forgive me if I refer to the subject of this debate as CFCs rather than go through an extraordinarily tongue-tying exercise which is designed purely and simply to impress other members of this chamber.

TALK.START.PARA: —It seems to have worked.

—I will not get into it myself. The reason that CFCs have become so widely used, as Senator Puplick has already said, is that until we discovered the extremely bad effects that CFCs appear to be having on the ozone layer-and it was a British scientist, Joe Farmer, who discovered the hole in the ozone layer-they appeared to be a highly desirable agent to use, for all of the reasons that Senator Puplick enumerated. They are not toxic and they are not flammable; they are highly desirable for use as propellants in a spray can as they have the ability to produce a fine spray and so on. As Senator Coulter is aware, some of the substitutes which are currently around which could feasibly replace CFCs do suffer from the highly undesirable property of being flammable. Indeed, if agents such as this were used in products such as hair sprays and so on the problems of CFCs in the ozone layer and cigarette smoking would be simultaneously solved in that the user would self-immolate upon using the products.

SPEECH.PARA: Australia has not only an international responsibility in dealing with this matter but also a very particular regional and national concern because, again as Senator Puplick has said, we have the highest rate of skin cancers in the world. When those cancers become malignant melanomas, as they unfortunately can, they become fatal. The problem of cancers and the difficulty with the greenhouse effect that has already been mentioned make this problem a serious one. The facts are that scientific studies indicate that continued growth in the emissions of these products-indeed, it is not just CFCs that are the criminals; there are other agents as well that are a problem-depletes the small amounts of ozone gas that are present in the earth's stratosphere which, of course, reduces the ability of the stratosphere to filter out ultraviolet (UV) radiation.

There is, of course, strong evidence of a causal relationship between exposure to ultraviolet radiation and the occurrence of skin cancer in all its various forms. Indeed, the Government is concentrating at the moment on national campaigns on trying to alert the public to the great difficulties and dangers of skin cancer. In an era when a great deal of attention is paid to personal appearance, when a palely loitering expression is no longer considered to be fashionable and tans are in to the point where people become besotted about obtaining a tan, people overlook the fact that they could be killing themselves in the process. As I said before, in this respect the Australian population is particularly at risk-probably not simply because of our geographic location, but because of our outdoor lifestyle, our concentration on beaches, and so on, we have the highest incidence of skin cancer in the world.

Ultraviolet radiation has other health effects-for example, the induction of cataracts in the eye and effects on the body's immune system. Indeed, some very interesting research-and, I guess, some potentially scary research-is being done on the effects of ultraviolet radiation on the body's immune system, so the problem is not simply one of skin cancer. The increased exposure of the Earth to harmful UV radiation would also affect the growth of plants and organisms living near the surface of water. The radiation is also destructive of some man-made materials, such as plastics and paint. Of course, that is far less of a problem.

Within the last 10 years or so there has been increasing scientific concern that a class of chemicals, referred to already as CFCs, when released to the atmosphere cause a depletion of the ozone layer of the earth. However, as I have already mentioned, another class of chemicals, the halon group, is also implicated. CFCs and halons are extremely stable chemicals which, of course, is one of their desirable properties. Once released to the atmosphere, they remain virtually unchanged for up to a century. Over time, they drift up to the stratosphere, where they play a part in complex chemical reactions which result-and I think this is generally accepted now-in destruction of the ozone molecules in the stratosphere.

A recent meeting of the world's top scientists in the field predicted that continued growth in emissions of the ozone depleting gases would produce a reduction of ozone of about 10 per cent within 60 years, with this depletion accelerating. To contain emissions of gases throughout the world at current levels would limit ozone depletion to perhaps 2 per cent, but the extent of damage to the ozone layer would vary significantly according to latitude and season. Mention has been made, of course, of the Montreal Protocol to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer, to which Australia is a party. Senator Coulter has already mentioned that there is some controversy about the meeting that determined the Protocol; indeed, that is so. I would like to quote from a statement made recently by a scientist who is pre-eminent in his field-the British scientist, Joe Farmer, who was responsible for discovering the hole in the ozone layer. With regard to the Montreal decision, he said:

Basically, we're just putting in the substance which the atmosphere doesn't like, and if we have any sense we ought to stop. And we ought to stop as quickly as possible. One of the dreadful things about this is that people seem to think that capping CFC production at current levels is to be cautious. It's not, it's to proceed along the motorway in the fog at the same old speed. Any cautious man should turn round.

I think it is reasonable to say that there is no difference of opinion between Senator Puplick, Senator Coulter or me that this is the situation. One of the difficulties, of course, is that-and I have no problems in asserting it-the Montreal Protocol was determined on the very best scientific evidence available in the world. One of the problems that I point out in passing is that in any measures the Australian Government takes-Senator Coulter has already referred to the relatively small role that Australia plays in the worldwide emission or release of this group of chemicals-we are very much tied in, of necessity, to what is happening internationally, which is why it is so important that Australia continues to pursue what I and, indeed, the Government, consider to be the responsible course, which is pursuing international protocols and treaties. That is what the Government is doing, with some considerable success.

Under the guidance of the United Nations environment program an international treaty, to which I have already referred, known as the Vienna Convention for Protection of the Ozone Layer, was concluded in 1985. The Convention provides a general framework for action by countries but does not set down specific control strategies. I will speak about that shortly, because, as Senator Coulter obviously knows, although the Montreal Protocol to the Convention lays down the standards, it does not indicate in any detail how the countries will achieve those levels of reduction.

Australia became a party to the Vienna Convention in September. In recent months the Vienna Convention has been highlighted in regard to the Protocol, which was finalised at the conference in Montreal on 14 to 16 September. The Protocol provides for a freeze on emissions of certain halons at 1986 levels, the freeze coming into effect in 1992; a freeze on the use of certain CFCs at 1986 levels; the freeze probably coming into effect in 1989-90; a 20 per cent cutback in the use of CFCs as from 1993-94; and a possible further cutback by 30 per cent-that is, a total reduction of 50 per cent on the 1986 level-as from 1998-99. It might be useful for honourable senators if I were to quote one section of the Protocol. I certainly will not quote any more than that, because it is lengthy. If honourable senators wish to refer to the relevant section, article 2 of the Protocol contains the guidelines laid down. Section one reads:

1. Each Party shall ensure that for the twelve-month period commencing on the first day of the seventh month following the date of the entry into force of this Protocol, and in each twelve-month period thereafter, its calculated level of consumption of the controlled substances in Group 1 of Annex A does not exceed its calculated level of consumption in 1986. By the end of the same period, each Party producing one or more of these substances shall ensure that its calculated level of production of the substances does not exceed its calculated level of production in 1986, except that such level may have increased by no more than ten per cent based on the 1986 level. Such increase shall be permitted only so as to satisfy the basic domestic needs of the Parties operating under Article 5 and for the purposes of industrial rationalization between Parties.

The Protocol then goes through various stages, laying out the percentage reductions in the use of CFCs that I have described. The Commonwealth Government has already consulted extensively with interested parties to the Protocol, particularly industry, the conservation movement and the various States in Australia, in preparation for becoming a party to the Protocol. Indeed, as the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has stated, it is the intention of the Government to give very early consideration to becoming a signatory.

I have some good news for the honourable senator in this regard. There has been considerable progress in the voluntary response of industry to the problem. I will cite some figures which seem to be at variance with the figures from another document cited earlier by Senator Puplick. The figures concern the use of CFCs in Australia by tonnage. The annual figure for aerosols for 1974 was 13,000 tonnes. I refer particularly to aerosols which, I think everyone agrees, and Senator Coulter has certainly said, is the obvious measure that has to be taken very quickly. The 1985 usage rate-I understand it has pegged out at this rate-is 4,000 tonnes. That represents a very considerable reduction indeed and it is clearly a response by industry which would be prompted as much by commercial realities as environmental realities. Industry is aware that government must continue to move even more firmly to ensure that the damage to the ozone layer is contained and that no further damage is done.
On 18 September 1987 the Minister issued a Press release in respect of the Montreal Protocol. The final paragraph of the Minister's Press release stated:

`The Commonwealth Government will make a formal decision as soon as possible on becoming party to the protocol', Senator Richardson said, `giving particular consideration to the need for legislation'. There would be further consultation with State Governments and industry.

Both of the previous speakers in this debate have covered the technical matters in detail-particularly Senator Coulter because, obviously, we are debating his motion; he owed us that much and he has delivered it. Therefore, there is no need for me to waste the time of the Senate any further in going over those matters again.

To sum up, there is no question but that the Government attaches great importance to the protection of the ozone layer, particularly insofar as it screens out the effects of harmful ultraviolet radiation. As I have said, Australia is already a party to the Vienna Convention for the Protection of the Ozone Layer. A protocol to this Convention, which was finalised in Montreal in September, specifies controls on emissions of chemicals known to deplete ozone levels.

The Government supports the protocol. As I have said, the Minister has already given a commitment that the Government will give early consideration to Australia becoming a signatory to that protocol. Once this happens, Australia will be required initially to freeze consumption of CFCs to 1986 levels, and then successfully to halve the levels by 1988-89. These limits reflect the current international scientific consensus on action needed to protect the ozone layer. However, if it is determined that further reductions are needed to protect the ozone layer, the Government will look at implementing those reductions. Senator Richardson is quite forthright in his view that if the Government, by aggressive action in this regard, can exceed the provisions of the Montreal Protocol, it will do so.

For the benefit of Senator Coulter, I say that it is intended that legislation be introduced. I understand it is the intention of the Minister at this stage to try to get it in place during the autumn sittings of this Parliament in order to implement the provisions of the Montreal Protocol. I think I have indicated only too clearly that the Government supports-and has supported in all of the actions it has taken, particularly over the last 12 months-the sentiments expressed in the motion as it is currently drafted. There are concerns about simply moving unilaterally in the manner suggested by Senator Coulter. The difficulty is that it would be impossible to move effectively without full consultation. Indeed, if consultation were carried out in that manner, I am sure that the Government would have the full co-operation of Australian industry in this regard. I do not think even Senator Coulter would suggest that a coercive role by the Government, considering the very impressive strides that the industry has made voluntarily over the last 10 years, is the way to go. If at all possible the way to go is to get the co-operation of industry rather than to force it into taking action.

Not only is it the intention of the Minister to proceed at the earliest possible stage to get approval for legislation that can be introduced in the next few months-hopefully it will be introduced in the autumn sittings-but next week he will convene a major conference of all of the representatives of the Australian industries which use CFCs and will be affected by such legislation. It is clear from what I have said that the strong sentiment of this Government is to support the text of the motion. However, the Government does not believe that it is appropriate simply to move unilaterally in this direction at this time because, as I have said before-I do not imagine that Senator Coulter would be in possession of the information-it is the intention of the Government to introduce legislation at the earliest possible moment. Plans are already in place for a major meeting of all of the relevant industry groups which will be convened next week by the Minister to discuss this matter. I join Senator Puplick in asking Senator Coulter, even at this late stage, to consider adjourning the debate rather than proceeding to a vote.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in this debate because I consider this matter to be one of the most significant issues that have ever been before the Senate. It is certainly the most significant issue that has been before it this session. I rise with some consternation because, given that this debate is a very important one-both speakers of the Opposition and the Government agree-and in spite of the time available to debate this matter, the Opposition and the Government were able to come up with only one speaker each and both of those speakers have complained that they had insufficient time to prepare for the debate before us today. That is quite amazing, since this matter has been on notice since 1974 at least with the Molina and Rowland suggestion that chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) might be a problem in regard to depletion of the stratospheric ozone layer. Certainly one would imagine that this issue, particularly in recent times, ought to be at the very top of our agenda.

SPEECH.PARA: In September this year the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) announced the agreement reached on international controls. He noted that the Government was giving particular consideration to the need for legislation. I do not think the revelations that Senator Collins has just made are quite as fresh as he imagines they are. Certainly the Government has given notice of its concern and we welcome that. However, we do not believe that this motion is at odds with the Government's moves in terms of the international protocol or with moves it proposes to make. I am sure honourable senators realise that a notice of motion moved in the Senate is an expression of opinion by the Senate. If in raising awareness and in moving public opinion, business opinion, business attitudes, and industry attitudes, an opinion of the Senate is not considered to be an important part of that process, I am not quite sure what we are all doing here.

The Australian Democrats believe that it is important from time to time that an expression of opinion by the Senate, particularly if it is an expression of some unanimity, has a very positive influence, particularly on these sorts of issues, issues on which public opinion is moving and about which the Senate can make a positive contribution. As I have said, it is not intended that this motion should cut across any of the moves which are being made. What this motion does is bring forward options which are available when addressing this major issue. We should be very grateful that we now have in the Senate someone of Senator Coulter's standing and expertise in this area. It is quite clear that we need to look at a range of options, that it will not be sufficient to take just one or two measures.

From the Press release of the Minister in relation to the international accord I note that the protocol gives industry time to take steps to reduce emissions of ozone depleting substances and to bring into use alternative gases or new technologies. Importantly, it also provides for revision of the specified control actions in the light of further developments of scientific knowledge.

It seems to me that the motion brings forward suggestions that are not of high technological intricacy. The first point of the motion talks about the banning of pressure packs. This is something which, as Senator Coulter has already said, was done in the United States as far back as 1978, and it has been done in a number of other comparable countries. It should not be something beyond Australia's power to do now. However, the proposal raised in the second point of the motion, to fit refrigerators and airconditioners with pipework so designed that CFCs can be removed, condensed and recycled, is of such enormous practicality and simplicity that it should be happening. As I understand it, when refrigeration was a much newer phenomenon in our society, such a process was followed. I cannot help thinking that, as our throw-away society has developed over the past few decades, we have been throwing away our whole future by the throwing away of these gases. If it is possible to recycle them in any way, I cannot see why they should not be. Other parts of the motion, particularly paragraphs (c) and (d), show what can be achieved by way of recycling.

Recycling in industrial processes generally, not just in this area, is a very firm policy of the Australian Democrats. We have a good record in other areas of recycling. The Government of Senator Coulter's State has a fine record in this regard. If we take anything from this debate, it should be a renewed enthusiasm for recycling in many areas, particularly in this one where we are dealing with substances which, as has been clearly outlined in the debate already, are of enormous danger to us, to our environment and to our future.

A couple of months ago, when the `Access Age' column in the Age newspaper was opened up to children, I read a small comment which I thought demonstrated the wisdom of the young. I cannot quote directly, but the point made by the child contributor, I think aged about 12, was that cigarettes are too cheap and sunburn creams are too expensive and that there should be a swapping around of the prices. Even young people are concerned and understand the nature of this problem and other problems. That was an interesting and wise suggestion.

As I have already said, the United States banned the use of CFCs in pressure packs as far back as 1978. But we know that, despite that ban, CFCs have continued to accumulate. Aerosol use had dropped by half by 1983, but non-aerosol use climbed by almost as much and releases remained constant. It is obvious that we need to go beyond that first suggestion, but Australia should make that move at the very least. I have often spoken in the chamber about other bans-in particular about dieldrin and DDT-that Australia has not introduced following action by other similar countries. It is time that we became a little more progressive than we are with such exercises. Senator Collins said that we are a small country making a small contribution, and sometimes we use that as an excuse not to do anything. We should take the example of New Zealand on nuclear issues. It is small, but it has chosen to set an example, and Australia should do that far more often. In this case, even if banning a few pressure packs seems to be a small contribution, it is still a significant one. If we are talking about developing our exports and industries, surely, if we can come up with technologies in recycling, that would be to our economic advantage.

Senator Puplick seemed to think that there was some conflict in the Australian Democrats expressing enormous concern on this issue. He seemed to think that we did not have too strong an argument because of our attitude to the burning of fossil fuels, which is a major problem, and our record as a party that has rejected nuclear fuels. If you will excuse the metaphor in a debate such as this, Mr Acting Deputy President, I would say that that is getting out of the frying pan and into the fire. The nuclear option as opposed to the ozone depletion option could scarcely be seen as anything other than that. We need energy conservation and options in respect of renewable energy resources. The Australian Democrats have always taken a strong stand on this. Recently, in Time magazine, there was a comprehensive article on the issue that we are debating today. I was interested, speaking about Democrat policies, to note a strong point made in that article that a major step in combating severe effects of the diminution of the ozone layer is to protect our tropical rainforests, because deep green foliage absorbs solar radiation, as does the blue sea, and that is buying us some time. Again, `interconnectiveness' in the policy areas have brought us to this motion before us today.

We must reflect, often and deeply, on what this means to us. As senators have said in the debate, we already have a high rate of cancer in Australia. When anti-cancer week comes along, we dig deep in our pockets to help scientific and medical research. In this debate, we are saying that research into the recycling of CFCs would be a major contribution in the battle against cancer. We should not forget this `interconnectiveness'. I am not sure how much the Anti-Cancer Council gives to such research, but we must understand that that is important.

As the rural spokesman for the Democrats, I have been concerned about our resources base in Australia and in particular our agricultural resource base. The debate in which we are engaged seems to pale into insignificance when we imagine what will happen to the agricultural areas of the world if this practice continues. It has only to continue at a very minimal rate for our fears to be realised. In a sense, we have already gone too far. We will have dust bowls and climatic changes which will be dramatic, and we shall be looking at much more destructive issues than those which we have been discussing in Australia recently.

It is disappointing that, on an issue as important and critical as this, neither the Opposition nor the Government can see that the intention of this motion is to push the issue further, be constructive and provide an incentive to government, industry and the community, to take positive actions on this most horrific issue. It is one about which, to give them credit, both the Opposition and the Government are concerned. It is just unfortunate that they are not prepared to support this motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-I am disappointed that, although the importance of this issue was first raised in 1974 and, as has been pointed out, four nations moved to ban the use of freons in pressure packs as early as 1978, and although the Opposition and the Government recognise the importance of this issue, they have not decided where they stand. I reiterate what Senator Powell has just said-that is, this motion calls on the Government to do certain things; it is not a piece of legislation. I would have thought that the Government and the Opposition, given their expressed good intention, could have supported the motion. I can state now that I intend to bring forward a Bill, which I hope will be ready for introduction in this session, which will set out essentially the same points. I give the Government and the Opposition notice that they will have a month or so to consider the points. I hope that they will then be in a position to say precisely whether they support them or not.

SPEECH.PARA: I was rather surprised to hear Senator Collins say that the Government was pursuing this issue with some vigour and, in support of that, that it was going ahead and would give effect to the Montreal agreements. We have already recognised that the Montreal agreements were too little too late. Clearly, the world needs to move beyond that. I see no reason why Australia should simply rest on its laurels in saying that, in supporting those agreements, it is doing a good thing, because quite clearly it is not. Senator Collins said that any cautious man would turn around, given the evidence that is now before us.

TALK.START.PARA: —No, I did not.
—Senator Collins was quoting.
—They weren't my words. I was quoting someone else.

—Senator Collins was quoting someone very approvingly. I was pleased to hear him say that. He said also that those nations meeting in Montreal had the best scientific advice. I do not doubt that the best scientific advice was available, but what comes out of such international agreements is based on far more than simply the scientific advice. It also looks at the political reality of the situation. The political reality in Montreal was that certain nations-notably, the United Kingdom, to some extent West Germany and even to some extent the United States-were not particularly happy with the advice they were getting from their scientific advisers. What came out was not simply a result of the best scientific advice; it was a result of the best scientific advice having been diluted by those who had other items on the agenda. Even the best scientific advice is being proved wrong and has been proved significantly wrong over the years. I wish to quote a short piece which came from a combined United Nations environment program-United States Environmental Protection Agency conference in June 1986. A paper presented to that conference by Stordal and Isaksen stated:

SPEECH.PARA: . . . if the relevant trace gases grow at recent levels, global average ozone depletion by 2030 would be 6.5%. The reduction would be greater at high latitudes reaching 16% at latitude 60 degrees in springtime. Even with constant CFC emissions the global average depletion would reach 2% by 2030 but be 8% in high latitudes.

It is a matter of record that the ozone depletion has already reached about 2 per cent and, over the Antarctic, 50 per cent. The best scientific advice has been showing consistently that every estimate of the damage has subsequently proved to be a gross underestimate. The situation is much more serious than scientific modelling of the atmosphere has led us to believe. Senator Collins also mentioned McDonalds and laid some stress on the desirability of getting private industry to do the job.

TALK.START.PARA: —That was Senator Puplick.

—I thought that Senator Collins also picked that up. He certainly mentioned that he hoped one could rely substantially on private industry to get the work done. I agree that it was Senator Puplick who specifically mentioned McDonalds. I saw a news item several weeks ago which said that McDonalds in the United States intended to use a hydrocarbon gas as the expanding gas for the small containers that it uses for hamburgers and so on. I would have thought that legislating for such a requirement would have put McDonalds in an advantageous position vis-a-vis its competitors and that McDonalds would not be concerned in any way about such legislation and, in fact, would welcome it. One of the peculiar things is that many people who seem to want to rely on conscience do not recognise that those who have a conscience in a competitive industrial society-we are told all the time that that is the sort of society in which we live-are put at a competitive disadvantage. What the legislation should be doing all the time is giving an advantage to those who express a conscience. If McDonalds has chosen to move in this direction we should be backing it up by legislating and mandating for that sort of material to be made in that way.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Puplick made several other points. Initially, he seemed to be trying to cast some doubt on the recognised scientific evidence which I have put before the Senate in relation to the greenhouse effect. He referred repeatedly to the greenhouse theory. The fact of the matter is that we know that the carbon dioxide content in the atmosphere at the start of the industrial era was 270 parts per million. It is now about 340 parts per million and is rising by about half a per cent a year. If one does the calculations-they are not very difficult to do-it becomes clear that that carbon is coming from the burning of fossil fuel. There is no doubt about the origins of the greenhouse effect in relation to carbon dioxide. To attempt simply to disparage concerns in that way by saying that some people raise doubts about it does not do Senator Puplick any justice at all. I simply make the point that if homo sapien have evolved in an atmosphere of about 270 parts per million of carbon dioxide and about 21 per cent of oxygen, and if we significantly alter those percentages, in believing that we can in some way do better with a different composition in the atmosphere, we do so at our peril.

I now turn to Senator Puplick's claim that the oxygen levels measured in bubbles in amber which were measured at 33 per cent are now 21 per cent and, therefore, somehow or other the concentration of oxygen in the atmosphere has fallen. That is an absolute nonsense. I ask Senator Puplick to reflect just for a moment on where that extra oxygen would have gone. There would have had to have been an enormously different level of carbon dioxide in the atmosphere which we know was not present.

Senator Puplick attempted to mount an argument about my point that Australia is using five times as much freon as the world average, on a per capita basis. He attempted to disparage my point by saying that we may need to use more insect repellents than those who live in Sweden. Sweden suffers from a very severe mosquito problem in the summer. It is probably far worse than in many parts of Australia. However, leaving that matter aside, Senator Puplick seems to be ignoring the fact that there are plenty of other propellants available if one chooses to use sprays as an insect control. The figure of five times which I cited is, of course, a very good measure of the extent to which individual Australians are responsible for the damage being done to the ozone layer. It is a measure of our responsibility to do something about it.

The point I would like to pick up in a little more detail relates to the rather outrageous claim made by Senator Puplick in regard to the Australian Democrats' attitude to nuclear energy. I am rather surprised that Senator Puplick made that claim because in many other respects he shows a certain amount of erudition in debating these issues. I am surprised that he simply seems to have gone totally off the rails in regard to this issue. In relation to the expressed concern about a decline in energy supplies, and this is the context in which nuclear energy is normally considered, it would seem to me to be absolutely clear to anybody who looks at the situation for even a moment that the need for energy lies in the area of liquid fuels for transport. That is the area in which there is a pressing and imminent need for substitution. Nuclear energy can make no contribution to that energy need whatsoever. That is the first point. The issue of nuclear energy versus other forms of energy does not address the essential problem of energy supply.

I am disappointed that Senator Puplick is not here to hear this next point. One of the other gases which bears greatly upon the greenhouse effect and the increase in global temperature, and also damage to the ozone layer, is nitrous oxide. Nitrous oxide is being released from fossil fuels, certainly, but one of its other principal sources results from the clear felling of tropical rainforests. The decay of the nitrogen-containing components over these vast areas is putting huge amounts of nitrous oxide into the atmosphere, as a result of denitrifying bacteria. Although it is a one-off phenomenon, it is a significant contributor to the greenhouse effect. Nitrous oxide also is a gas which depletes the ozone layer and which has a residence time in the stratosphere similar to that of the freons, of around 100 years. Incidentally, the concentration of nitrous oxide is increasing in the atmosphere at about 0.6 per cent per year, which is faster than the rate of carbon dioxide increase.

That brings me to the third point in relation to Senator Puplick's outrageous claim about our anti-nuclear stance. I am surprised that he does not know that only half the greenhouse effect arises from carbon dioxide. A number of other gases are contributing to the greenhouse phenomenon. These include not only nitrous oxide, which I have just mentioned, but also methane, which is increasing at 1.1 per cent per year; the freons, which are increasing at 5 per cent and 7 per cent for freon 11 and freon 12 respectively; water vapour; and ozone itself, which is of course a greenhouse gas.

I mentioned that fact because although one might think that the ozone is decreasing the significant phenomenon here is that ozone in the troposphere, the lower part of the atmosphere, is actually increasing. It is that which is helping to blanket the earth and which is adding to the greenhouse effect. Therefore simply taking the carbon component out of the greenhouse gases does not solve the greenhouse problem; it is far more complicated than that.

Finally in relation to nuclear energy, if Senator Puplick had read the sixth United Kingdom report on environmental pollution, which goes under the name of the Flowers report, he would have found that that committee, when investigating these questions, came to the conclusion that the advent of and movement into nuclear energy would in fact increase the demand for fossil fuel and not decrease it. This comes about for a number of reasons. For example, the large capital cost of nuclear power stations means that one has to accumulate capital to go down the nuclear road. This means an industrial, economic base which is using large amounts of fossil fuel. It also means that the demand for nuclear energy for more electricity is predicated very largely on the use of that electricity in factories. Of course, that brings us back to the issue of how we get the resources out of the ground, how we smelt them, how we transport them to the factories and process them and how we transport the products away. All those processes are dependent on the use of fossil fuels. For all these reasons the Flowers committee came to the conclusion that the advent of nuclear energy would in fact increase the use of fossil fuels, so the position which the Democrats take in opposing both those industrial processes which increase greenhouse gases and nuclear energy is perfectly consistent.

Senator Puplick made a point in relation to legislation in South Australia. He said that the Democrats in South Australia had attempted to introduce legislation which had been severely criticised by industry. Of course, one of the reasons for attempting to use the Federal area for legislation of this sort is that it avoids the necessity for lengthy and delaying consultation between the States and the Federal Government through such organisations as the Australian Environment Council. That process would be tedious and would involve the long delay of decisions. It would result in the final decision being that decision most acceptable to the least caring State. I believe that section 51 (xx) of the Constitution, referring to corporation powers, would allow the Commonwealth to go forward with the sort of legislation that I am here proposing, to achieve that in short order and to achieve significant reductions in the release of chlorofluorocarbons into the atmosphere while still having the advantage of their use. As I have pointed out, the technological changes in refrigerators, air conditioners and the like which would be consequent upon using different gases would be considerable. I do not believe that such changes can be made in the sort of time frame that the Montreal Protocol on the Vienna Convention suggests.

In conclusion, I repeat that I am disappointed that with such an important issue as this and its long history, as we are now 13 years down the track from Rowland and Molina's initial concern-concern which was taken up quite quickly by the United States National Academy of Science and a number of very significant bodies-neither the Government nor the Opposition sees fit to support the motion today. However, the Australian Democrats certainly intend to proceed and to bring this matter to a vote.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Coulter's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

That, unless otherwise ordered, consideration of General Business pursuant to sessional order be not further proceeded with this day.

DEBATE.TITLE: BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1987RADIO LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987TELEVISION LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bills received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Reynolds) agreed to:
That the Bills may proceed without formalities, may be considered together and be now read a first time.
Bills read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bills be now read a second time.
I table a revised explanatory memorandum to the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) and seek leave to have the second reading speeches incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speeches read as follows-
BROADCASTING AMENDMENT BILL (No. 4) 1987

The last year has seen unprecedented change in Australia's media. We have witnessed a substantial restructuring of commercial television, radio and print ownership, the development of truly national commercial television networks, the beginning of the introduction of new commercial television and FM radio services to country audiences too long deprived of the services available in the major cities, and the continuing expansion of public radio and the two national broadcasters, the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Special Broadcasting Service.
These events mark this as a dynamic and exciting period for an industry which plays so central a role in our society, our culture, our economy, and our politics.

Some of the changes have been prompted by economic imperatives in domestic and international markets. Many, however, are directly attributable to the Government's policy initiatives, particularly the major legislative packages introduced by my predecessor, Michael Duffy, and passed by this Parliament in the last sittings. In pursuing these initiatives, this Government has shown itself sensitive to the changing commercial, technical and social environment in which the various media operate, and prepared to adapt policy to suit new circumstances. But it has not been afraid to itself motivate change in the directions it believes appropriate to serve the needs and interests of Australians.

This Bill represents a further significant step in the Government's reform of the media industry in this country. It provides for the introduction of an establishment fee payable on the grant of new commercial radio licences, and for a prohibition on the transfer of control of a commercial licence within two years of its initial grant. The associated Licence Fees Bills, which will receive their second readings following this speech, will provide for a fee to be payable on conversion of a non-metropolitan commercial radio licence from broadcasting on an AM frequency to a higher quality FM frequency following the grant of a new licence in the service area in question. These Bills also provide for increases in the licence fees paid by commercial broadcasters. Some of these decisions were announced in the Budget.

As a package, these Bills are designed to ensure that the revenue from the commercial use of those parts of the radio frequency spectrum available for broadcasting better reflects their true commercial value. We are seeking to ensure that the interests of all Australians in deriving a reasonable return from the exploitation of a public resource, the airwaves, are more equitably balanced against the legitimate commercial interests of those licensed to provide commercial radio services.

This economic reform will be achieved while preserving the place of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal in the licensing process. The Tribunal will continue to select the successful applicant for a new licence on the grounds of relative suitability so that competition for the new licence will be based only on the quality of services proposed by the applicants. The prohibition on quick disposal of a new licence will enhance the integrity of the licensing process.
Establishment Fee

In the Budget, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced that a tender system would apply to the grant of new commercial licences, with the licences being awarded to the highest bidding applicant whom the Tribunal determined to be suitable to hold the proposed licence.

The Government decided not to proceed with that approach. I had discussions with a wide range of groups and individuals from the public and the broadcasting industry, many of whom have expressed concern about the effect of a tender system on a licensing process founded upon very significant questions of public interest. The Government also reassessed likely revenue gains from the tender system in the light of necessary adjustments to the machinery of the scheme that have emerged during the consultation process, and the likely impact of recent stock market developments.

On balance, the Government decided that the gains in economic efficiency from a licensing process which allowed the market to determine the value of new broadcasting licences are outweighed by the desirability of retaining a process where applicants for new licences compete only through the quality of the service they will provide.
Application

In doing so, we decided that the new establishment fee should only cover commercial radio licences at this stage. The method of calculating the new fee for radio licences would not be as readily applicable to other forms of licence as was the tender system. In particular, since the Government has no immediate plans to call applications for new commercial television licences it would be inappropriate for any decision on the most appropriate way to allocate any such licences to be made at this stage.

The new fee will apply to all markets where new licences are being granted under the Government's regional commercial FM radio planning program including those for Geelong, Shepparton, Gosford and the Gold Coast, for which applications have already been called but the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is still some way from making decisions on the successful applicants. This is essential to ensure equitable treatment of all new licensees and markets receiving licences under the Government's new planning program.

The fee will not apply to the grant of the new Newcastle licence, where the Tribunal has already made a decision on the most suitable applicant but that decision has been successfully challenged in the Federal Court and is currently being reconsidered.

The Tribunal has an existing discretion to permit the lodgment of further submissions if this is necessary for applicants for licences already called to reflect the new arrangements in their proposed services.
Calculation of Fee

In most markets where a new commercial service is currently proposed, the new licensee will be placed in direct competition with an existing solus operator with substantially the same service area. In these situations, the new licensee will be charged the incumbent licensee's gross earnings for licence fee purposes assessed in the most recent accounting period before the issue of the notice inviting applications for the new licence.

Thus a new licensee in the Gold Coast could be expected to pay about $4m and a new licensee in Gosford about $3m. If there is more than one incumbent licensee with substantially the same service area as the proposed new licence, the fee will be the average of their earnings. Thus a third licensee in Hobart, were a licence to be invited today, would pay about $1.6m.

The establishment fee is twice the fee which will be charged to the incumbent if it requests conversion from an AM to an FM frequency, under the new arrangements provided for in the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The higher fee for the new licensee reflects the fact that the new licensee is acquiring a new right to broadcast in addition to the new FM frequency. The incumbent is only supplementing an existing right to broadcast with a new FM frequency.

Where the new licence is being introduced in an area which is not substantially the same as the service area of an existing commercial radio licence, the fee will be calculated in one of two ways. Where more than 70 per cent of the population of the proposed service area at the most recent census is already served by at least one commercial radio service, the fee will be the gross earnings of that existing licence, or those existing licences, in the proposed service area in the most recent accounting period. The earnings of the existing licence or licences in the proposed service area will be assumed to bear the same proportion to the total earnings of the existing licensee(s) as does the population of the relevant part of the proposed service area to the total population served by the existing licensee(s).

Thus, in the case of Ipswich, where a new licence is to be invited shortly, the fee will be based on the gross earnings of the existing Brisbane licensees to the extent that they were earned within the service area of the proposed Ipswich service. On this basis the new Ipswich licensee could be expected to pay about $1.8m.

Where less than 70 per cent of the population of the proposed service area is currently served by at least one commercial radio service, a fee calculated in this way is likely to understate the true value of the new licence. In these circumstances, the fee will be set at $15 per head of population in the proposed service area. This reflects the per capita earnings of regional commercial radio licensees in 1985-86, the most recent year for which data is available.

These three different methods of calculating the fee are intended to employ the most useful data which is available for particular markets. Where there is already a licensee operating within substantially the same service area, that licensee's revenue will be the best guide to the revenue a competitor could expect. Where there is no direct competition but other overlapping licensees who have been broadcasting to most of the proposed new market, the revenue of these licensees will be the best guide. Where a substantial proportion of the proposed market currently is not served by commercial radio, the earnings of other licensees in similar service areas provides the most helpful reference point.

If the fee is not paid within 60 days of the Tribunal's decision or within 30 days of the final resolution of any legal proceedings arising out of the Tribunal's decision, the Tribunal will treat the most suitable applicant as having withdrawn his or her application, and re-open its inquiry to determine the next most suitable applicant. The 60-day period gives the successful applicant 32 days after the deadline for lodging of applications for review of the Tribunal's decisions under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act. Similarly where legal proceedings are commenced, the successful applicant will have 30 days after the deadlines for the lodgment of appeals from decisions in those proceedings.

If there is no next most suitable applicant, the Minister will be empowered to extend the time for payment and charge a late payment fee similar to that applying to late payments of existing licence fees, and to re-invite applications for the proposed licence if the fee is not paid within the extended time. Alternatively, the Minister may immediately re-invite applications.
Prohibition on Re-Transfer

The recent change in control of the company which had been granted the third Perth commercial licence before the new service went to air highlighted a significant shortcoming in the existing licensing process. In deciding to preserve that process, the Government has also decided that its integrity will be enhanced by imposing a prohibition on the transfer of control of a licence within two years of its initial grant.

The prohibition on retransfer will operate by preventing the Tribunal approving a transfer of a licence within two years of its grant, and making void any transaction within two years of the initial grant which the Tribunal finds to constitute a transfer of control of the licence. The provision refers to `provisional approval' which implies that a transaction may be approved for the purposes of the two-year rule, but subsequently be disapproved because it constitutes a breach of other rules such as cross-media or total numbers of licences.

Transactions need not be share transactions but only `transactions in respect of shares'. Thus other forms of transaction which give rise to beneficial interests in shares will also be subject to the prohibition. The provision is intended to give the Tribunal a broad discretion to prevent any transfer of control within two years of a commercial licence grant.

The sanction of making any offending transaction void is different from the Tribunal's existing sanctions for breaches of the ownership and control of rules. The existing sanctions of fining contravening licensee once the Tribunal finds a breach to have occurred, apply only after a six-month period of grace during which the contravention can be remedied. The only way a purchaser within two years of a licence grant could `remedy' the situation would be to re-sell to the original vendor or re-sell to another purchaser. The former would amount to the Tribunal compelling a commercial purchase, while the latter would cause a still further transfer of control contrary to the basic policy.

The Tribunal will have a discretion to approve a transaction otherwise contrary to the prohibition where it finds that, by reason of exceptional circumstances such as death or bankruptcy, the transaction would be in the public interest. Where the Tribunal is satisfied that, although circumstances such as death or bankruptcy exist, the transaction is not in the public interest, it may still refuse approval.
Financial Implications

The Bill has no direct financial implications. While it covers procedural aspects and the method of calculating the establishment fee for new commercial radio licences, the related Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 makes the amendment to the new Radio Licence Fees Act which formally creates the obligation to pay the fee. The Bill will create some additional work for the Tribunal through monitoring the prohibition on transfer of control of a new licence.
Commercial Radio Ownership

The amendments made by this Bill are part of an overall reform not only of the current arrangements under which broadcasting licensees pay revenue to the Commonwealth, but of the whole commercial radio industry. A new scheme which will affect the financial capacity of applicants and their rights once granted a licence, is inextricably linked to other structural aspects of the industry.

The changes to the existing ownership and control rules in the radio industry, which I announced on 28 October, are closely related to the financial and other reforms introduced in this package of legislation. Together, they will ensure maximum diversity of ownership of all media consistent with quality services and a more reasonable public return from the commercial use of a public resource. Most importantly, they are an important part of this Government's commitment to the quick introduction of the best possible new broadcasting services to all Australians. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
RADIO LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

This Bill is part of a package of Budget measures aimed at reforming the current arrangements under which broadcasting licensees pay revenue to the Commonwealth. The related Bills are the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987 and the Television Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 3) 1987.

This Bill requires successful applicants for new commercial radio licences to pay an establishment fee which will be set out in the notice inviting applications for the licences. The procedural aspects of this fee and the method of calculating it will be incorporated into the Broadcasting Act, and are described in my second reading Speech for the related Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987. Only the formal provision imposing the obligation to pay the amount so calculated is included in this Bill.

Other provisions of this Bill require the payment of a fee on conversion of a commercial radio licence from broadcasting on an AM frequency to broadcasting on a higher quality FM frequency, and provide for increases in licence fees.
Conversion Fee

While there was initially considerable scepticism about the prospects for FM broadcasting in Australia, the success of the commercial FM radio licences granted in the metropolitan cities in 1980 has led to considerable pressure on the Government to allow existing AM licences to convert to FM.

The Government previously has indicated that it is prepared to consider conversion, at this stage in limited circumstances. It has been decided that conversion will be considered where an existing solus AM operator is facing competition from one of the new FM services being introduced under the Government's Regional Commercial FM Radio Planning Program. In such circumstances, the incumbent's isolation on the AM band could be a serious commercial disadvantage. In any case, there seems to be no reason to deny conversion to those who desire it-provided certain conditions are met.

The Bill makes the fee payable on conversion from AM to FM of a non-metropolitan commercial radio licence where the Minister has issued a notice under section 82 of the Broadcasting Act inviting applications for a new commercial radio licence serving substantially the same service area. The fee does not apply to conversion in other circumstances at this stage since the Government has not yet settled its policy.

The conversion fee will apply to all markets where new licences are being granted under the Government's regional commercial FM radio planning program including those for Geelong, Shepparton, Gosford and the Gold Coast for which applications have already been called, but where the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal is still some way from making decisions on the successful applicants. This is essential to ensure equitable treatment of all new licensees and markets receiving licences under the Government's new planning program.

The following conditions will have to apply before I consider conversion. Firstly, FM frequencies and sites will have to be available, given the requirements of other planned broadcasting services. Secondly, there will have to be direct competition between the converting service and the new service. This will require the incumbent service area to be substantially the same as that of the proposed new licensee. Thirdly, there will have to be no loss of service to people who formerly received the AM service, reflecting the different transmission characteristics of AM and FM signals.

These amendments thus do not give any licensee a right to convert. The decision on conversion and its timing remains one for me as the Minister, to be made in accordance with my general powers under the Broadcasting Act to plan the development of broadcasting services in Australia. I would propose to convert the incumbent licensee at a time as near as practicable to the date on which the new licensee will commence transmission. No converted service will be able to commence before the commencement of the new service in the area. If there are limited FM frequencies, the new rather than the converting service will have priority. The new fee also does not oblige anyone to request conversion if they meet the Government's criteria but would prefer to stay on an AM frequency.

The fee will be calculated as 50 per cent of the incumbent licensee's gross earnings for licence fee purposes assessed in the most recent accounting period before the issue of the notice inviting applications for the new licence. This is half the fee which will be charged to the new licensee, reflecting the fact that the new licensee is acquiring a new right to broadcast in addition to the new FM frequency. The incumbent is only supplementing an existing right to broadcast with a new FM frequency. Payment of the fee will be required before the technical conditions of the licence warrant are varied to authorise use of the new FM frequency.
Licence Fee Increases

Commercial radio licensees currently pay licence fees assessed as a proportion of their gross earnings each year. The fee scale is progressive with rates increasing from 3.5 per cent on gross earnings of $5m to a maximum of 5.5 per cent on gross earnings of $11.8m and above.

The Bill introduces new rates for larger stations ranging from 4.4 per cent on gross earnings of $6m, 5.3 per cent on gross earnings of $7m, 6.2 per cent on gross earnings of $10m, to a maximum of 6.5 per cent on gross earnings of $12.7m and above. The new fee scale will apply to all payments of fees due on or after 1 January 1988. The scale was last increased in 1983.
Financial Impact
Establishment and Conversion Fee

Successful applicants for new licences to be granted in this financial year are expected to pay around $11m under the establishment fee scheme. Incumbent regional commercial licensees converting are expected to pay around $5.5m under the conversion fee scheme. The precise financial implications in future years will depend on progress with the planning timetable and Tribunal inquiries. As explained earlier, the amounts paid by converting licensees will always be half those paid by the corresponding new licensees.
Licence Fee Increases

These measures are expected to raise $1.0m in the current financial year, $1.2m in 1988-89 and $1.3m in 1989-90. Total revenue from radio licence fees is estimated at $11.7m in 1987-88, an increase of 31.2 per cent on 1986-87. Most of the increase reflects assumed increases in stations' earnings. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
TELEVISION LICENCE FEES AMENDMENT BILL (No. 3) 1987

This Bill is part of a package of Budget measures aimed at reforming the current arrangements under which broadcasting licensees pay revenue to the Commonwealth. The related Bills are the Broadcasting Amendment Bill (No. 4) 1987 and the Radio Licence Fees Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987.

Commercial television licensees currently pay licence fees assessed as a proportion of their gross earnings each year. The fee scale is progressive, with rates increasing from 3.5 per cent on gross earnings of $5m to a maximum of 8 per cent on gross earnings of $48m and above. This Bill amends the fee scale for licensees currently paying that maximum rate of 8 per cent. The new scale will continue to apply a fee of 8 per cent on gross earnings of $48m, but will increase to 8.8 per cent on earnings of $75m and to a maximum of 9 per cent on earnings of $100m or more.

The new scale will apply to all payments of fees due on or after 1 January 1988. They are only expected to effect major metropolitan licenses during the current Forward Estimates period. Increases have not been applied at lower levels of gross earnings since to do so would place further financial obligations on regional licensees currently planning major capital expenditure programs for equalisation. Assessments of financial viability of licensees under equalisation, which formed an important part of the planning process, were based on the existing fee scale. The fee scale was last increased in 1983.
Financial Impact

These measures are expected to raise $4.8m in the current financial year, $5.7m in 1988-89 and $6.4m in 1989-90. Total revenue from television licence fees is estimated at $79.5m in 1987-88 an increase of 17.1 per cent on 1986-87. Most of the increase reflects assumed increases in stations' earnings. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Knowles) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The Bill before the Senate makes a number of changes to the National Health Act and the Health Insurance Act to take account of changes to the Social Security Act introduced in the Budget and the May Economic Statement. Two of the three changes in this Bill are consequential amendments to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987.

All three changes relate to the operation of the pharmaceutical benefits scheme. The first change inserts in the Health Insurance Act a set amount of allowable income in respect of each eligible dependent child to be included in the income test for the Health Care Card for disadvantaged families. This obviates the need to refer to the Social Security Act to determine the appropriate amount. The second change will enable persons receiving a job search allowance to receive free or concessional pharmaceutical benefit items. The third change will temporarily restore eligibility for free pharmaceutical benefit items to certain former Class A widow pensioners and supporting parent beneficiaries who lost their pension or benefit as a result of recent changes to Social Security legislation.

The Health Insurance Act specifies the income test for the health care card, which allows disadvantaged persons to qualify for concessional pharmaceutical benefits. To be declared as disadvantaged a person's allowable income must be less than an amount determined under the income test provisions of the Act. In determining this amount the Health Insurance Act currently refers to the level of additional benefit payable to each dependent child. With the implementation of the Government's family package there will be different rates of additional benefit for dependent children, depending on their age. A technical amendment is therefore required to make it clear that existing entitlements to the health care card will be retained. The Bill would therefore amend the Health Insurance Act to substitute a dollar amount of $34 per week for each dependent child in lieu of the current formula based on the additional benefit for children. The amount has been chosen to maintain the current level of additional income for children under the income test for the health care card. The Bill allows for subsequent increases in this amount by regulation. There are considerable advantages, in terms of administrative efficiency and ease of understanding, in retaining an income test based on a single amount allowable per child, rather than introduce an income test defined on the basis of differential amounts according to the age of dependent children.

Clause 8 of the Bill in part relates to the job search allowance for 16- to 17-year-olds. The allowance, to come into effect from 1 January 1988, necessitates amending the National Health Act to include those persons in its definition of pensioner and concessional beneficiary. The amendment enables recipients of a job search allowance to receive prescription pharmaceuticals at the concessional rate of $2.50 while medically fit to search for work and at not charge when the recipient is sick and unable to seek work. These provisions would effectively leave unchanged the pharmaceutical entitlements available to people aged 16 and 17 who currently qualify for unemployment or sickness benefits.

A further amendment to the National Health Act will restore, until the end of 1988, eligibility for pensioner health benefit cards and thus free pharmaceutical benefits for those persons whose entitlement to Class A widows pension or supporting parents benefit ceased, between 1 September 1987 and 31 December 1987, as a result of changes announced in the May Economic Statement restricting such payments to those with children under 16. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
