STATES GRANTS (EDUCATION ASSISTANCE-PARTICIPATION AND EQUITY) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Act 1983 to adjust for cost movements the grants available to government and non-government education authorities in the States and the Northern Territory to conduct projects and programs under the Participation and Equity Program for 1987. The Bill provides new schedules for 1987 showing the allocation of funds to the States and the Northern Territory, and to the education sectors.

The cost adjustments proposed are in accord with the Government's undertaking to provide retrospective cost adjustment for this program. They are consistent with adjustments being made to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) and State Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bills which are also before the Senate today.
The financial impact of this Bill will be to provide an additional $109 000 in 1987. Total provision for the Participation and Equity Program is $45 928 000 in 1987.
STATES GRANTS (SCHOOLS ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The main purposes of this Bill are to amend the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Act 1984 to implement decisions in the recent Budget on Commonwealth programs for schools in 1988 and to supplement for cost increases grants already appropriated for schools programs.

There are detailed appropriations in the Bill for specific purpose and capital programs for government and non-government schools in each State and the Northern Territory. The Principal Act already contains the per capita grants under the general recurrent program for government and non-government schools for the period 1985-88. This comprehensive long-term program continues to provide authorities with stability and security in the planning of school operations.

Most programs are being maintained at the same real level as in 1987 while a few will increase in real terms. The General Recurrent Grants Program will increase by an estimated 4.8 per cent in real terms to $1339m. The per capita amount for the new arrivals element of the English as a Second Language Program has been doubled and the Special Education Program will receive an additional $0.7 million in 1988 for the support services element. Funding of the Participation and Equity Program and Basic Learning in Primary Schools Program will not continue beyond the end of 1987 in accordance with the period set for those programs.

The Bill also provides for the full implementation of block grant funding arrangements under the non-government schools element of the Capital Grants Program. The legislation was amended earlier this year to provide for the approval of block grant authorities. These amendments will enable capital grants for non government schools in 1988 and subsequent years to be allocated as a block grant for distribution by approved block grant authorities. Block grant arrangements, by providing greater involvement by school authorities in the delivery of the Capital Grants Program, offer an enhanced capacity for the achievement of Commonwealth objectives. The Government is not, however, forcing schools to join block grant authorities. Non-government schools which do not wish to participate in block funding arrangements will be able to compete for funds from a national pool in a similar way to existing arrangements.
There are also several amendments of a minor nature.

Firstly benefits under the English as a Second Language Program and Ethnic Schools Program are being restricted to students having permanent resident status. Established administrative practice has restricted benefits in that way but an amendment is required to put beyond doubt the authority for doing so.

Secondly, an amendment provides for the inclusion in the Act of a definition of a ``full fee paying private overseas secondary student'' that had been made by Regulation. Definition by Regulation was an interim arrangement pending full incorporation in the Act.
The financial impact of this Bill will be to appropriate an estimated $1739m for 1988 programs and an additional $9m for 1987 programs.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) BILL 1987

On 22 September 1987 the Minister for Employment, Education and Training released the Guidelines to the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission for 1988. The Commission responded with detailed recommendations in its Report ``Higher Education Recommendations for 1988'' which has already been tabled.

The States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 has been prepared following consideration of the Commission's recommendations. It also gives effect to the Government's budget decisions on Commonwealth assistance for TAFE in 1988.

The purpose of the Bill is to provide the legislative basis for the distribution of Commonwealth funds for tertiary education in the States and the Northern Territory for 1988. A total of $2708.1 million will be legislated for.

As the Minister explained to the House when he delivered his statement on higher education on 22 September, the Government is treating 1988 as a year outside the normal funding process. This deferment of the next funding triennium will enable the Government to reassess the overall direction of higher education policy, and to develop new funding programs to take effect from the beginning of the 1989 academic year.

The Bill provides $2423.8 million for the higher education sector for 1988. This represents an increase of 2.0% in real terms on the previous year. The allocation of additional resources reflects the Government's resolve to increase participation, particularly among young people, and to make the higher education system more responsive to the needs of the national economy.

The Government has accepted the Commission's recommendations on the detailed allocation of student places and financial resources with one exception. The Commission had recommended that planning funds be provided in 1988 for the proposed relocation of the Sydney college of the Arts and the rationalisation of facilities at the Western Australian College of Advanced Education and University of Western Australia. However, this recommendation made no provision for a firm forward commitment of funds against these projects.

The Government agrees that these projects should proceed and they will be supported with the future Commonwealth capital programs. In these circumstances, the $500,000 ``planning'' funds recommended by CTEC will not be required and will be used to support a student residence project at the Darling Downs Institute of Advanced Education, which is important for future student growth.
Key features of the allocation of higher education funds for 1988 are:
An additional 23 million in general recurrent grants to fund an extra 3500 to 4000 intakes for school leavers;
An increase in capital grants of $12 million to allow for the continuation of 35 projects and the commencement of 13 new major works projects;
An additional $3 million in equipment grants;

The redirection of $5 million from general recurrent grants to universities to fund an expansion of Special Research Centres and Key Centres of Teaching and Research as well as targeted research activities in the advanced education sector;
Unallocated amounts totalling $42.7 million for equity projects, superannuation and the Special Assistance Scheme for students to be distributed after further advice from CTEC.

In arriving at its funding decisions for 1988 the Government has been conscious also of the need for effective forward planning of physical facilities to support expected future growth in enrolments. Accordingly, since the Budget, it has examined further the likely capital needs of higher education over the next few years, and decided that the higher level of capital funding approved for 1988 should be maintained into 1989 and 1990. This measure will not only add significantly to the funds available for new capital projects in 1989 and 1990, but should also assist institutions in the longer-term planning of their future capital programs.

Subject to appropriate agreements with the States concerned, the two projects deferred from the 1988 capital program recommended by CTEC will have first call upon the additional capital funds to be made available in 1989. Further commitments against these funds will be made during 1988 following completion of the Government's Policy Discussion Paper on Higher Education and the satisfactory resolution of the issues raised in the Paper.

The Bill also provides $284.3 million for expenditure on TAFE programs. As announced in ``Skills for Australia'', the Government believes that considerable restructuring of Commonwealth grants for TAFE is required to meet a number of objectives, including:
Further increases in vocational education and training and an expansion of total training capacity;
Improvements in the relevance of TAFE provision;
Productivity improvements and efficiency gains in the use of existing resources;
Greater industry involvement in TAFE;
An enhancement of the labour market prospects of the unemployed and other disadvantaged groups, especially among the young.

Under new funding arrangements set out in this Bill to apply from 1 January 1988 the Government will continue to place a strong emphasis on the national development of TAFE, through both an Infrastructure and a General Recurrent Program.

The existing Capital Grants, Special Equipment and Minor Works and Equipment for Traineeships Programs will be combined into a single TAFE Infrastructure program. An amount of $174.8 million is provided for this purpose in 1988.
The existing Fees Reimbursement and Designated Purpose Recurrent Grants are largely replaced by a General Recurrent Program which will be subject to resource agreements with the States covering:
A commitment to pursue improvements in productivity in 1988;
Agreed target growth rates in designated courses of high priority to meet skill shortages, equity objectives, or of strategic importance to future economic development;
Changes in administrative arrangements to enable TAFE colleges to retain revenues from entrepreneurial effort.

An amount of $103.1 million is provided under this program in 1988. Achievements against program objectives will be subject to regular monitoring and evaluation. The level of funds to be provided to the States for TAFE in 1989 and future years under the General Recurrent Program will be dependent on achievements in 1988 particularly in relation to productivity.
Three existing special purpose programs for which funds are currently available under the Designated Grants program are to be maintained:
Grants for advanced English language courses for migrants will continue to be administered by the Commonwealth, as will the allowance paid to participants in such courses;
Grants for adult literacy and for non-government adult education will be maintained and rolled in with funding to be allocated under the National Language Policy for adult literacy purposes.

A total of $6.4 million is provided for these programs in 1988. The processes of allocating these grants will be reviewed during the year. The Bill also provides for continuing Commonwealth assistance to non-government business colleges.

This Bill gives effect to the Government's decision to permit a limited relaxation of the prohibition on fees in higher education and TAFE from 1988. Higher education institutions will be able to seek the Minister's approval to charge fees for specialised postgraduate award courses catering for students already in employment who are seeking to upgrade their vocational skills and income. The Government's decisions have been taken in response to requests from sections of the higher education community itself, and there will be no compulsion on institutions to charge fees for these courses. The revenue raised by this measure will be retained by the institutions concerned, and the Commonwealth will not reduce its grants on account of revenue generated from fees. Institutions will also be able to exempt certain students or categories of student from payment of fees.

Similarly the relaxation of the TAFE fees prohibition is not intended to affect the great majority of TAFE courses which involve the initial acquisition of skills by young people. It is intended to apply to courses undertaken for the purpose of upgrading skills and income by students well established in employment. The aim of this new provision is to provide a further basis for industry and individual contributions without threat to the public financing of TAFE. The Government will not reduce the level of the General Recurrent Grant on account of any fees revenue generated under these arrangements.

Incorporated in the Bill are the changes made to the Higher Education Administration Charge which were announced in the Budget. The categories of needy students exempt from the charge have been extended. These further exemptions cover almost 9000 students, which will bring to around 139,000 or 35% the number of students who will be exempt from, or reimbursed for, the charge in 1988. The Bill has been tightened to make students withdrawing from a course after teaching has commenced liable for the charge. In line with the Government's commitment not to increase the charge beyond the effects of inflation the charge will rise from $250 to $263 in 1988.

In its latest report CTEC has reiterated its views on a number of topical issues in higher education, including those publicised in its recent press release on portfolio advisory arrangements and structures. The Government's position on these issues was set out in the Minister's statement of 15 October 1987 announcing the findings of the Task Force chaired by Mr Charles Halton. As foreshadowed at that time, an extensive process of consultation is now under way with interested parties, and the Minister expects to announce final decisions on the new advisory framework towards the end of the year. The Government welcomes the very positive reaction to its proposals to date, and notes that the views expressed in the CTEC report are sharply at odds with majority opinion. I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STATES GRANTS (TERTIARY EDUCATION ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Act 1984 to adjust for cost movements in tertiary education grants to the States and the Northern Territory. The Principal Act provides grants to the States and the Northern Territory for tertiary institutions for the 1985-87 triennium.

The Bill will adjust recurrent grants from preliminary end March 1987 prices for university academic salaries and actual and March 1987 cost levels for the advanced education and TAFE sectors to the end of June quarter 1987 prices in accordance with the Government's agreed procedures to make retrospective adjustments for cost variations.

The total amount of supplementation to be provided by this Bill is $3.0 million, made up of increases of $4.1 million in grants for universities and intersectoral purposes in higher education, offset by reductions totalling $1.1 million in grants for advanced education and TAFE. The latter reductions result from the final non-salaries index for 1987 being lower than the preliminary index used when the relevant grants were last supplemented.

The Bill also accommodates changes necessary to transfer responsibility for administration of the Act from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
STUDENT ASSISTANCE AMENDMENT BILL 1987

This Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 seeks to amend the Student Assistance Act 1973 which is the legislative basis for the provision of student assistance under AUSTUDY and for the grant of post-graduate awards.

The proposed amendment to section 10 of the Act relates to the range of institutions at which courses are approved for AUSTUDY. Approved institutions currently include secondary schools, TAFE colleges, colleges of advanced education, universities and a limited number of tertiary institutions in the private sector providing courses funded by the Commonwealth. These private tertiary institutions mainly comprise denominational teacher-training colleges and certain business colleges.

The Bill responds to a decision of the Federal Court in Darwin earlier this year, in the O. Gipalis and NT Attorney-General v. Karen Schnierer case, which established that students attending the University College of the Northern Territory could be regarded, for AUSTUDY purposes, as undertaking study at the University of Queensland-by virtue of an agreement between the two institutions under which the University, for a fee, allows the College to teach the University's courses.

The amendment is needed because the wide interpretation the Court has given to section 10 opens the way to a range of wholly private institutions-including private universities, academies of Dance and Art, cooking schools, Chiropractic colleges, receptionist and beauty colleges and non-approved business colleges-to gain access to AUSTUDY contractually, by-passing Ministerial screening. The decision also enables those private-sector institutions that have gained AUSTUDY approval for certain of their courses to expand their AUSTUDY offering.

Section 10 allows the Minister discretion to approve or revoke approval of courses. The proposed amendment will allow a further discretion to determine that particular institutions in the private sector are not appropriate institutions for AUSTUDY purposes. The discretion would be exercised where institutions that have made contractual arrangements seek AUSTUDY approval of a course.

It is not intended that this discretion should be exercised so as to deny AUSTUDY to students who currently benefit under contractual arrangements. Students at the University College of the Northern Territory will not be affected. An amendment is being sought to the Student Assistance Regulations to classify the College as a `university' for the purposes of the Act, thus allowing the College equal standing with universities in the States, and the right to seek AUSTUDY approval of any course that it may wish to offer independent of the University of Queensland.

Where teaching arrangements are shared between public-funded and private institutions, it will continue to be possible for the courses concerned to be considered for AUSTUDY assistance. Non-government secondary schools will not be affected, since those that currently have State or Territory teaching certification are, and will continue to be, approved for AUSTUDY in their own right.

As the law now stands, an ever-increasing flow of AUSTUDY funds into private-sector tertiary institutions must be expected. Although the financial implications for the Commonwealth are not at this stage quantifiable, they will become significant. The proposed amendment is needed to restore to the Commonwealth the right to determine those institutions where AUSTUDY should be provided and to maintain existing AUSTUDY policy that limits the provision of AUSTUDY to students undertaking courses that are wholly or substantially funded from public sources, whether Commonwealth, State or Territory.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
MARITIME COLLEGE AMENDMENT BILL 1987

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Maritime College Act 1978 to enable the College to operate on an equal footing with institutions in the States consequent upon the proposed changes under the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987.

This Bill will enable the Maritime College to apply for a limited relaxation of the prohibition on fees for specialised postgraduate award courses catering for students already in employment who are seeking to upgrade their vocational skills and income.

The Bill will also permit the introduction of changes to the Higher Education Administration Charge. From 1988 the categories of students exempt from the charge will be extended and students withdrawing from a course after teaching has commenced will be liable for the charge. In line with the Government's commitment not to increase the charge beyond the effects of inflation the charge will rise from $250 to $263 in 1988.
I commend this Bill to the Senate.
