DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS, DEFENCE AND TRADE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I present the report of the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade on references not disposed of by the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence during the Thirty-fourth Parliament, together with the transcript of evidence.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be adopted.

When the Senate passed the motion establishing the legislative and general purpose standing committees on 22 September last, several matters which had been referred to the former Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, and which had not been disposed of before the dissolution of the Thirty-fourth Parliament, were referred to the new Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade. One of those matters was a reference given the Committee on 3 May 1984, on Australia's relations with Papua New Guinea, with particular reference to: firstly, Australia's contribution to the economic development of Papua New Guinea; and, secondly, the significance of Papua New Guinea within Australia's regional defence responsibilities.

The reference was a response to the report of the Jackson Committee to review the Australian Overseas Aid Program, the Irian Jaya situation and, indirectly, law and order in Papua New Guinea. These issues were then receiving considerable Press coverage in Australia. After the 1984 elections, the Committee decided to continue with the reference, though active consideration was deferred pending completion of the examination of the Jackson report by the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The Senate Committee also took into account that it had considered the significance of Papua New Guinea within Australia's regional defence responsibilities in its October 1984 report entitled Australia's defence Co-operation with its Neighbours in the Asian-Pacific region.

The Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence presented its examination of the Jackson report on Australia's overseas aid program in May 1985. Chapter 5 of the Joint Committee's report discusses Australia's contribution to the economic development of Papua New Guinea. The Senate Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade has considered the events since May 1984, when the reference on papua New Guinea was given to the former Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, and the fact that the subject of the reference has been substantially dealt with in the two reports from the Senate and Joint Committees which I have mentioned. The Senate Committee, therefore, proposes to take no further action on the reference.

We have also considered another reference not disposed of by the former Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence-namely, the United Nations Educational, Scientific and Cultural Organisation (UNESCO). This reference was given on 26 March 1985. One public hearing was held on this matter, and I table the transcript of evidence today. The Committee has noted that a new Director-General of UNESCO has been appointed and we propose to take no further action on the reference.

The former Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence tabled its first report on Land Acquisition in New South Wales by the Australian Army on 30 May 1986. This report fulfilled the requirements of clauses (1) and (2) of terms of reference given on 9 October 1985. The third clause of the terms of reference was:

To investigate the adequacy and appropriateness of current procedures in protecting the rights of individual landholders and communities in areas where acquisition is contemplated, in providing for fair and prompt cooperation, and in providing for appeal procedures.

Consideration of clause (3) of the terms of reference was deferred because the legal basis for the Commonwealth's authority to acquire land, the Land Acquisitions Act 1955, was in the process of being amended following the publication of Law Reform Commission report No. 14, entitled Lands Acquisition and Compensation. Clause (3) of the terms of reference pertains to matters of a legal and constitutional nature. Any action which may be required would appear to fall within the area of responsibility of another standing committee, and the Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade does not propose to take further action on this reference.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: APPROPRIATION (PARLIAMENTARY DEPARTMENTS) BILL 1987-88[COGNATE BILLS:APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 1) 1987-88APPROPRIATION BILL (No. 2) 1987-88]

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I was saying before the suspension of the sitting for lunch, the Queensland Government's affirmation of the reopening of the underground Boggo Road prison cells will lead to inhumane and degrading treatment in store for troublemakers during World Expo 88. The Queensland Government must be made aware that Australia is watching with disgust and, with Expo and the Bicentenary close at hand, so will the world be watching. It is my hope that a reappraisal of attitudes will take place in this country next year. Instead of giving ourselves a big party we should be opening our hearts to the disadvantaged members of our community. There are plenty of individuals and groups who do not generally share a sense of well-being in this very affluent country.

SPEECH.PARA: Those honourable senators who were privileged to hear Justice Einfeld deliver the first Alan Missen Memorial Lecture last night will understand that very many violations of human rights are taking place in our communities under our very noses right now. His speech, delivered to the parliamentary Amnesty International group, will be circulated to all members and senators. I commend it to all. It was the finest speech I have heard in this Parliament House. It was a heartfelt plea for compassion and justice.

A large part of the problem is our consumer orientation in this country. We are a society based on satisfaction of material needs. We need to look beyond material concerns and attend to our spiritual welfare also. This means considering all people everywhere as our brothers and sisters and sharing our resources with them. It is only the creative power of love and non-violence which can transform our society. We must stop exploiting people and the environment in quest of the almighty dollar. The recent fluctuations of the international stock market show just how fickle can be our faith in finances.

Part of the reason for the current recession is the huge United States spending on weapons. As Chris Gregory pointed out in the Canberra Times last Saturday, this problem was identified by United States Treasury Secretary, John Connolly, as early as 1971. He said:

I find it an impressive fact, and a depressing fact, that the persistent underlying balance of payments deficit which causes such concern is more than covered, year in and year out, by our net military expenditures abroad, over and above amounts received for foreign military purchases in the United States. . . We spend 9 per cent of our gross national product on defence-nearly five billion dollars of that overseas.

The staggering increase in United States military expenditure is one factor that appears to have been overlooked by analysts commenting on the recent Wall Street-led stock market crash. My comments are backed up by research published by the Council on Economic Priorities-an impartial public service research organisation based in the United States. In its publication entitled Military Expansion and Economic Decline, the Council makes the point that United States military expenditure is largely responsible for the massive deficit the United States faces. Its research links the higher military expenditure to poorer economic performance and argues that, despite what some analysts say, military expenditure is far from the most effective way to create employment.

The Reagan Administration's military build-up is the largest in America's peacetime history. The United States should take some tips from Japan, which has succeeded in keeping its deficit down partly through keeping defence spending down. The United States could lead the way and reduce its current budget deficit, which stands at $148 billion, by reducing military expenditure.

There have been many revelations in the past about wasteful Pentagon defence procurement practices which result from the fact that defence supplies do not have to follow the usual tendering practices. This leads to highly inflated defence purchase prices. However, all nations that keep us on the brink of war through increasing military build-up, and not just the United States, need to look at non-military means of achieving security. A diversion of resources from the military would go an enormous way towards meeting the challenges of unemployment and poverty and reducing national deficits. We must stop feeding the arms race and start feeding people. Australia can have a vital role to play in the necessary attitudinal changes towards that humanitarian goal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Burns Sen B.R

TALK.START.PARA: —We have had presented to this nation an excellent Budget which was lauded by the media as both surprising and satisfactory, a Budget about which most Australians could feel satisfied and look to the future with growing confidence. The criticisms from those on the other side must be examined and judged within the framework of their performance in government compared with the record of the Australian Labor Party Government. For that purpose, I will concentrate on a particular aspect of the Budget-industrial relations and its effect on productivity and related matters.

SPEECH.PARA: If one looks at the laws brought in by the Liberal-National Party Government prior to the election of a Labor government in 1983, one finds bodies such as the Industrial Relations Bureau forced penalties and archaic laws upon workers. Matters pursued in this way through the industrial courts were counter-productive and led to the loss of many man hours.

Senator Sheil made some remarks this afternoon in which he indicated his feelings. He talked with some concern about strikes. The National-Liberal Party-I am sorry that I put that the wrong way around as one Party is more senior than the other-has no concern about strikes in Poland. It thinks it is all right if people strike against authority in Poland. But if people in Australia strike for better wages and conditions they are considered to be very bad. If the doctors go on strike and put people's lives at risk, where other workers put only profits at risk, it considers that that is a moral action.

Senator Sheil made the point that he was nervous about industrial democracy. I hope that the quotations that I will make a little later in my speech will put his mind at ease. He also spoke about the undesirability of occupational superannuation funds. I must point out that such funds have grown on the basis of the understanding of the trade union movement that in years down the track it will be almost impos- sible, if not impossible, for any government to provide the sorts of retirement salaries that will be needed. Also, we have to take into account that those funds provide investment in productive and useful commodity industries. All of the people who are trustees of those funds have a responsibility in law to maximise returns to their members. I believe it is important that people should be convinced that it is desirable that those funds invest in productive and useful commodity industries.

Senator Panizza indicated some concern about work practices. His interpretation of the meaning of work practices was a situation in which two people on the job carry out the tasks normally done by one person. I must assure him that that is not the meaning. Work practices are the way certain tasks are carried out. Historically, they are rooted in old-fashioned attitudes put into place by employers. I suppose we could go back as far as the guilds which trained people who paid for that service. Those people acquired skills and knowledge. Workers have gone along with these practices which are based on past technological requirements and which certainly have given job security. The honourable senator also mentioned that management wanted only to get in and get the job done, as though people in the work force and the community do not have similar views. They do, but with certain qualifications as to what the result may mean to them. I assure him that workers and trade unionists have the same view about productivity.

I was pleased to hear Senator Panizza say that there should be government intervention. I agree wholeheartedly. He was right on the spot when he made that point. The Australian Labor Party, in its time in office, and even prior to coming to government, has been creative and has worked towards increasing productivity in the interests of the community. It has done so on the basis of seeking assistance from the trade union movement. It reached an agreement with the Australian Council of Trade Unions in the form of the prices and incomes accord. It did so out of its concern for the community which, as I have said before in this place, comprises many people in the trade union movement. The Government also has concern for the future of this country and all its citizens.

The accord and the co-operation between unions and the Government go to a number of matters such as education, industrial development, trade, foreign affairs and affirmative action. Of course, the community is concerned about industry development, and correctly so, because if we do not develop industry which has the ability to create wealth, all those other things that draw on the wealth of this country will draw from a very empty bucket.

I can make the statements which I have made and suggest that everyone should accept them. But in support of what I am saying I will quote from a book called Structured Chaos, with articles from Richard Blandy, Peter Dawkins, Kenneth Gannicott, Peter Kain, Wolfgang Kasper and Roy Kriegler. There are a number of interesting quotes in that book. Let me remind honourable senators that none of these people is radical, left wing or a socialist trade union official. The book quotes the following from Peters and Waterman, 1983, page 238:

. . . Treat people as adults. Treat them as partners; treat them with dignity; treat them with respect. Treat them-not capital spending and automation-as the primary source of productivity gains. These are fundamental lessons learned from the excellent companies research . . .
Again, the book quotes Richard Nelson, 1981, page 1036, where he argues:

The social system of work sets norms, enforces them, and resists pressures or commands from management that are inconsistent with those norms . . . How workers feel about their job, about fellow workers, about management, and about the organisation, may be more important in influencing productivity than is the particular way they are instructed to do their work, the formal organisational structure, or even financial incentives . . .

These things appear to be forgotten by a lot of people when they argue about productivity and the role of people in it. Rather, they seem to want to talk more about costs in terms of wages and conditions that have been won by workers at the work place. The book quotes Rosow, 1979, page 29, where he says:

Ask any businessman what the key factors are in productivity. The answer without exception is: capital, technology and manpower. That is what they say. Their actions, however, reveal their true concerns: capital and technology, period. Manpower drops out of the equation . . . Catch a businessman in an unguarded moment and enquire what-if anything-he plans to do about productivity growth. If he mentions seeking increased co-operation from his workforce, you have found a pearl-bearing oyster . . . The role of labour in productivity growth is so fundamental, so obvious, that managers stare right past it.
I think it is important that these quotes go into the Hansard because they show that people who have given a lot of thought to this matter are concerned about workers as people.
Sitting suspended from 6.30 to 8 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will use a further quote from the same publication to demonstrate my argument. Structured Chaos states:

SPEECH.PARA: As a result of their research, Burt and Masters (1974) drew up the following unflattering profile of Australian middle management:

Dependent on government; insular; lacking in boldness and initiative; dependent on overseas sources for capital, ideas and techniques; reasonably but not highly educated; masculine in fact and outlook; conservative; fearful of radicalism in economics and politics; egalitarian both socially and at the work place; practical and pragmatic; opportunists rather than planners, non-intellectual-some are anti-intellectual; interested in leisure, social activity and family; critical of politicians and the holders of formal authority; versatile; materialistic; non-aggressive; manipulative in managerial style; low in Machiavellian characteristics.

I do not think they have changed very much. Those people who had expressed those views about the way in which industrial relations worked and the participants also quoted Ralph Willis, who, as everybody in this chamber knows and understands, is a very fine Minister in a progressive Government. He had this to say:

For Australia to achieve sustained economic recovery and growth it is critical that the consensus and co-operation being developed at the national level be given practical expression at the work place.

Industrial democracy and employee participation have come to mean many things to many people. The essence of the issue is simply about employees at all levels in an organisation having greater influence and involvement in their work. Every employee has a right to a high quality of work life and to contribute to the effective operation of the organisation . . .

Those quotes show the clear difference in understanding of people who come from different areas in the political spectrum about the way in which we should operate. The Government developed Austrade so that it is now organisationally involved in seeking markets overseas and in seeking to help people in terms of managerial skill or to make up for the lack of it or to compensate for inadequacies. This is part of industrial development. The Government has put forward and has had accepted enthusiastically the heavy engineering package and the steel industry package, which has seen the production of steel go from 150 tonnes per man a year to 260 tonnes. There has been a massive reduction in employees in the clothing and footwear industry but the industry has been put on a proper basis and it will give some security of employment to those people who are still in the industry and to some extent will make it more competitive. The car industry package is another example of the involvement of the Government in industry in a meaningful and constructive way.

The unions' role in this is criticised by many people but those people who criticise the unions' role are those who do not understand its intention or the way in which the unions go about carrying out those intentions. Any trade union official who did not understand this and did not want to see the most jobs possible in the community to reduce and eliminate unemployment would be quite wrong and should be criticised by all. But trade union officials understand this. That is their position. After all, the unions cannot operate without membership. The unions came into being as a result of the needs of the working class of this country and other countries because the workers were being exploited. They were not being considered as people but only as part of the productive process. Of course, at one stage unions were defensive but now they are very aggressive in looking at their educative role. At seminars people discuss issues, and explanations are given by people from all walks of life about the current needs for developing production and the creation of wealth that this country needs. The unions debate the way in which these matters can be dealt with at federal union conferences where the maximum amount of democracy is involved, unlike the National-Liberal Party position. All the Opposition wants to do is rubbish people who do not agree with its philosophy.

I turn to the question of job training. For many many years the trade unions have sought a better method of job training. Those who have looked after the skilled areas have never said, for instance, that apprenticeships are sacrosanct, that the way in which we trained people for work over many years has to continue. They have looked at new roles. Currently in Victoria some work is being done in relation to this in terms of looking at a person's whole working life. One may be trained in certain areas, be creative and give service to the community in that particular role but then later on, using some of those skills, move into other areas where they can be of even more importance in terms of a career path for those people. No longer do we consider that if one has a particular calling that one follows as a young person to 25, 30 and 40 years of age one is stuck with that. People have other capacities to offer: they have other creativities that reside within them. The trade union movement is anxious to promote this with the various courses and various methods of training and education-through university-for industry as well as for life. They are concerned that there be the best possible opportunities which in turn will enrich the person and also enrich the community. There might be a situation in which these things occur but the economy might be declining. Ralph Willis addressed the Employers Federation of New South Wales and he pointed out the success of the Government in terms of advancing in regard to the economy. He talked about a 10 per cent decline in real unit labour costs which are statistically proven and a 7 per cent decline in the real value of wages. I think that is a fairly good contribution for the trade unions to have made.

After all, Professor Blandy, when he spoke in Adelaide the other day to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Technology and Science of which I am a member, made the point that wage costs or labour costs are not the only problem. In fact, they are much less a problem in terms of the importance of other matters in relation to the availability of finance and the way in which work is organised. He says in the book from which I have just quoted that it is not so much a question of wages overhang, but production underhang. He talks about the failed ability of employers to organise industry in such a way that it benefits the whole community.

Ralph Willis's point is well made and, of course, the Government and the trade union movement are looking at those things very much on the basis of consensus. I think it behoves people in the community who do not know very much about the way in which the trade unions and certain employer organisations operate and the importance of people in the process of production to be circumspect about these matters. If they want to make a contribution to the debate they should refer to the positive things that can be achieved. They should remark on, for instance, the gains that have been made and the changes in attitude that have taken place.

We heard Senator Panizza talk about work practices. Indeed, trade unions have pointed out many cases of work practices which are wasteful and need to be changed. But they will not put out their hands to be handcuffed and say, `Whatever the employers want to do with us they can'. They are not prepared to give away their rights with the goal of the reorganisation of industry if the only objective is massive profits regardless of the unemployment that may result, regardless of the fact that the wealth that may be created cannot be distributed among the people in the community. Industrial democracy, which is not understood by many honourable senators opposite, is important. It means that people will begin to understand the way in which industries or particular enterprises go about producing a product or a service. They will begin to look at the enhancement of that product and that service. Of course, the Labor Government has been very constructive in that area. It has enabled people to receive a 150 per cent rebate on investment in research and development. That is something that the Liberal-National Party certainly did not allow. That has been welcomed by those people in industry who have enough intelligence to know where their interests lie.

The trade union movement and this Government have been able to go forward constructively and co-operatively, having in mind the interests of the whole community. I commend the Government for that. I intend to work for a future in which we can create additional wealth and redistribute that wealth among those people in the community who have every right to expect their share of it. I will not be negative, as are people on the other side. They want only to be critical of a slight increase in wages, when in fact real wages have fallen, as I have already demonstrated. I commend the Government for all of the measures that are contained in the Budget.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment to the motion for the second reading of Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1987-88 which has been foreshadowed by my colleague Senator Stone in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to project jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro-economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.

The amendment certainly covers the way the Opposition parties feel about this Government's Budget which, less than a week after it was brought down, was transformed by Senator Walsh's attack on it. The nonsense peddled by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and accepted by sycophantic journalists was that it was a balanced Budget, that it was an attempt to reduce the deficit and that it was a whole lot of things that it clearly was not. It is a Budget with an estimated deficit of about $2.5 billion. For how many years has this Government produced disastrous Budgets?

TALK.START.PARA: —Too many years.

—As my colleague Senator Boswell says, for far too many years. Australia is currently in an economic crisis. This is no longer being denied by the Government. Even the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), despite his constant attempts to push up this Government's performance, said last Saturday night at the Australian Export Awards:

SPEECH.PARA: The current account deficit is still unsustainably high and our overseas debt continues to mount.
The balance of payments constraint dominates our economic choices . . .

Of course it does. It did so before the stock market crash, but the stock market crash and the weaker Australian dollar have resulted in the Government finally facing the fundamental reality that members of the Liberal and National parties have been pointing to since early 1984; namely, that Australia is an over-borrowed country living beyond its means, in an increasingly harsh world.

When this Government came to office it criticised the Liberal Party for the deficit of 1982-83. We have to wear that deficit. With hindsight, clearly the Liberal-National Party Government of 1982 adopted a wrong Budget policy. There were excuses; there were explanations. Let us not forget that the world was in a state of recession, Australia was facing a very serious drought and there were major economic problems. In order to overcome those problems, the Liberal-National Party Government primed the economy, which is the standard economic solution to crises of such a nature. Nevertheless, by the time the March 1983 election was held, following which this Government came to office, it was clear that that policy had gone too far and that there was a desperate need to withdraw from a deficit Budget situation. Now, with hindsight, everyone is on that bandwagon. But by the time this Government came to office in 1983, a number of Liberal-National Party members of parliament pointed that out to the new Government, but it did not do anything about it. Instead, this Government immediately pumped up spending with two expansionary Budgets. The Budgets of 1983 and 1984, instead of being contractionary Budgets, were expansionary Budgets. Senator Walsh has now admitted that this was a mistake. I quote from a speech made by Senator Walsh on Friday, 7 August 1987 to the Conference on Australian Monetary Policy Post-Campbell delivered in Baxter, Victoria:

On 23 March 1983, in my first speech as a member of the Labor Government, I said this, `The state of our overseas current account is, like the impending domestic (Budget) deficit, one of the most serious problems facing the new Government.
Senator Walsh now acknowledges that as early as March 1983 he recognised the problem. In his speech of 7 August this year he continued:
I look back on that-
meaning he looks back on that statement-
with mixed feelings: satisfaction at having identified the nation's major problem; disappointment at having paid too little attention to it over the next 2 years.

As I said, too little attention was paid over the next two years. That is what we said. In speech after speech in this place following the Government's first Budget, we tried to point out that the Government was taking the wrong path. I see that Senator Robert Ray thinks that that is a joke, but that is the truth of the matter. We were constantly attacking the Government by saying, `You've gone down the wrong path'. The Whitlam Government, when it came to office in 1972-73, immediately went down the wrong path-an expansionary path. The time was not right for an expansionary Budget. This Labor Government went down the wrong path and we warned it that it had gone down the wrong path. All it could think of doing was criticising the Fraser Government for the Budget deficit that it had introduced the previous year. We acknowledge that in the circumstances, and with the benefit of hindsight, that may have been the wrong thing to do. This Government had an opportunity to correct the matter but it did not do anything about it even though Senator Walsh acknowledges that he recognised what the situation was in 1983.

Senator Walsh, in his speech to which I have referred, enters what he calls `several pleas in mitigation'. I do not accept those pleas in mitigation any more than he will accept my pleas in mitigation of the Fraser Government's deficit Budget of 1982-83. The truth of the situation is that when this Government came to office it criticised the Liberal Party for the deficit of 1982-83-as I have said we have to wear that-but this Government immediately pumped up spending with two expansionary Budgets. During 1985 and 1986 it simply turned away from making the tough decisions that it should have been making. It can turn away no longer. As a result of the stock market crash around the world the Government now has to face the reality that we have been talking about for the past four years.

This Government criticises the United States of America for not getting down its deficit and I agree with that criticism. I also criticise the United States for not getting down its deficit. But that cap certainly fits Australia. The current account deficit of this Government is $11.5 billion-4 per cent of gross domestic product. The net foreign debt of Australia is 32 per cent of gross domestic product. So the criticism of the United States for not getting down its deficit applies similarly to Australia. It is now time for Australia to get down its deficit.
Mr Hayden, in his Sir Edward Dunlop Oration on Monday, 16 November, talked down the economy when he stated:
. . . they threaten once again to plunge the world economy into another Dark Age of protectionism.

That was Mr Hayden, not some Liberal or National Party senator or member, talking down the economy. We reject any suggestions that it is the Opposition which is attempting to talk down the economy. Mr Hayden is finally saying to the people of Australia, `Look out. We are in trouble'. Senator Walsh said this immediately after Mr Keating brought down the Budget, in his now well-known `the IMF is knocking at the door' speech. He put it quite correctly when he said:
. . . a country which has a high level of foreign debt and a continuing large current account deficit is a country which has few options.

TALK.START.PARA: —Was he talking the dollar down?

—Senator Walsh was talking the Budget down because he knew that the nonsense euphoria in the media about a so-called balanced Budget would create expectations in the community which this Government could not deliver. Senator Walsh rightly recognised that the Government could not deliver and that the Budget would not deliver. He thought, `My God! I have to stop this' so he made that speech. He certainly stopped it because at last some of the more intelligent journalists in the gallery said, `Perhaps we had better look at the Budget. Perhaps Mr Keating has been conning us again as he has on so many other occasions'. What Senator Walsh said about this country having few options was said before the stock market crash. That is why I say that this Government has no options left and there is serious doubt about whether the Budget projections and the business goals can be met.

SPEECH.PARA: In Senator Walsh's speech, to which I referred earlier, made on 7 August to the Conference on Australian Monetary Policy Post-Campbell, in Baxter, Victoria, as part of his plea in mitigation of what this Government's economic policy had been, he said:
In mid 1985 that progress-
he claimed that progress had been made in a number of economic factors under this Government-
was halted and in some cases reversed by the collapse of export prices . . .

Honourable senators will recall that from mid-1985 onwards Senator Walsh started to talk about the downturn in the terms of trade. This poor Hawke-Keating Government was facing a terrible situation because there was a downturn in the terms of trade. It was creating great problems for the nation; it was creating great problems for Senator Walsh. But what is the truth? I do not deny that there was a very substantial downturn in the terms of trade. I have calculated from the recent Industries Assistance Commission report, which provides the figures, that over the period mid-1985 until early this year there was a downturn of about 18 per cent in the terms of trade. That is a very substantial downturn.

What Senator Walsh has never admitted or been prepared to acknowledge is that from 1974 until 1978-in other words, this commenced under the Whitlam Government and the Fraser Government was lumbered with it for over two years of its government-the Fraser Government was also lumbered with a massive downturn in the terms of trade which was 22.7 per cent. Under the Fraser Government the downturn in the terms of trade was nearly 5 per cent greater than that suffered by the Labor Government and Senator Walsh has repeatedly attempted to excuse the Labor Government for its pathetic efforts to revitalise the economy of this nation.

Senator Walsh also claimed in his speech on 7 August that the collapse of export prices had precipitated a major depreciation of the Australian dollar, a blowout in the current account deficit, higher inflation, interest rates and unemployment. Real wages and per capita consumption fell further. In other words, this all followed as a result of a downturn in the terms of trade. Glory be! This is not the first time that this has happened in Australia. The terms of trade in Australia have repeatedly turned against us for something like 20-odd years. There was a much greater turndown in the terms of trade under the Fraser Government but no excuses were offered by the Labor side of politics for the Fraser Government's problems. We were expected to, and we did, overcome them during the terms of the Fraser Government. Yet Senator Walsh repeatedly uses this argument as some sort of excuse or explanation for this Government's pathetic performance.

This is not a time for pessimism; it is not a time for a negative response: it is a time for rebuilding this country on better foundations, foundations that can better weather future financial storms. This is a window of opportunity which this Government must not allow to close. This is a window of opportunity when industry might be prepared to take the actions which it needs to take, when managers might realise that if they are to succeed in this time of crisis they will have to work in close co-operation with their work force. They will have to combine with their work force to achieve a profit ratio which is acceptable to their shareholders, which is worth while in this community and which their bankers and creditors will allow them to get away with and will not send them to the wall. This is a time when this country must rely a great deal on managers facing up to their responsibilities and obligations. On the other hand, it is also a time when the work force of this nation must face up to the need to overcome some of the ridiculous work practices which this country has adopted during good times, when employers and companies have been able to pay wages and salaries and offer terms and conditions that are far beyond those which this country can afford to pay at this time of crisis, so well described by Mr Hayden.

Our rising foreign debt places us in a Third World category, as it requires more than a third of Australia's export earnings merely to service our national debt commitment, and a low dollar value is no solution. Mr Keating, from time to time, is inclined to make speeches implying that, in some way or another, the low value of the Australian dollar is some sort of marvellous economic solution which has come to his mind and which he has so cleverly introduced. Glory be! If that is a solution, then those South American countries whose currencies are practically worthless would have found a solution long ago to the problem that they face and we face. The low value of the dollar is no solution. It simply makes it harder for the country to meet the interest on our debt, let alone reduce our debt. If this Government is prepared to sell our land and buildings in Japan, instead of offsetting some part of our deficit those moneys should be used to reduce our large foreign debt. But no, the Government was claiming that this was going to be a balanced Budget by using such capital revenue for annual expenditure. Of course a low dollar value is no solution to our problems.

The fundamental difficulty that Australia faces is how on earth we shall overcome the problem of a dollar as low as it is against the American currency. We can only be grateful that the American economy is in such difficulties that the value of the American dollar is falling, and we have been able to hang on to its coat tails. In comparison with the trade weighted index, the Australian dollar has fallen disastrously. One has only to compare the value of our dollar with the yen, the pound or the mark to see the extent of that disaster.

One of the things that worries me about this Labor Government is not simply the comparison with South American countries and the value of our dollar. I remind the Chamber that those South American countries are full of excesses of wealth and poverty. In South America, the way to become wealthy is to be very friendly with the government and to have some in at the top. That is the way to get one's wealth in those South American countries-and is it not precisely what is happening in this country under a Federal Labor Government and four State Labor governments? The way that people are able to survive their economic problems in this country is to have mates in high places, and preferably in high political places. The way to become wealthy under this Labor Government is clearly to be associated with certain senior members of the Government. I will not name them because I can see that a senator on the Government benches will leap to his feet and say that I ought not to malign the Prime Minister in such a way. However, in this country, it is obvious that the way to become wealthy is to have an in with certain people who are at the top of their governments, both State and Federal. That seems to be the way that the Labor Party, in 1987, under Mr Hawke, Mr Burke, formerly under Mr Wran and now Mr Unsworth, and Bannon in South Australia wants to take it.

TALK.START.PARA: —And Cain.
—I had forgotten about the Victorian fellow. He is so hopeless and uninteresting that one would not remember him at all.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to work practices. As I said before, we are facing a window of opportunity which we may never face again. Now is the time for us to overcome some of the problems in the work force. I refer to the failure by certain craft unions to accept multi-skilling and broadband skills. I refer to restrictive work practices, and to featherbedding, which is endemic in shipping, transportation, mining, education and the public sector. They are all disincentives to investment and international competitiveness. It is essential that we take this opportunity to get the general environment right. If the environment is right, there will be no need for industry-specific programs. The right general environment will release dormant energies. The desire to make profits is still there-that is the driving force which releases energies. This is the time to do that. We should open the window of opportunity to enable us to restructure the work force and do away with restrictive work practices, and perhaps, in effect, to deregulate the labour market. I hope that the managers of our companies can put that opportunity for change in effect, because it will be up to them.

When I say that it is a window of opportunity which must not be missed, I refer to the window of opportunity that the Government had in relation to the tax summit. That was an opportunity to restructure our taxes in accordance with option A, but all we ended up with were the nasties in option C. The Labor Government allowed that window of opportunity to remain closed. I congratulate it on creating the window in the first place, but I condemn it for allowing it to remain closed. We may never again get the opportunity to restructure our taxes. One has only to look at the problems created during the last election campaign by attempts to talk about restructuring our taxes to see what a disaster it was that Mr Keating, Mr Hawke, Mr Crean and Mr Kelty overcame the sensible suggestions being made at the time of the tax summit to adopt option A.

If we open this window of opportunity, it will mean that all Australians, either individually or in organised groups, will not be able so readily to run to government to obtain some remedy or preferment. That will certainly be a major restructuring of this nation, because we will have changed the attitudes of Australians so that they no longer believe that governments can provide some milch cow of taxpayers' funds to solve their problems. To achieve the necessary economic climate, the Hawke Government must change direction and provide the right economic climate for foreign investment, preferably in industry. It should certainly not be attempting to block it off as Mr Keating has done in order to help Mr Unsworth in the next New South Wales election. We need a lower, more simple and durable tax regime, and one that encourages investment rather than consumption. We need a more flexible microeconomic environment and a flexible labour market. We need proposals like the second-tier wages proposal. The first-tier proposal was a nonsense. The Liberal Party is not opposed to wage increases, but the Labor Party constantly permits unnecessary wage rises.

TALK.START.PARA: —What a load of rubbish.

—Senator McKiernan may laugh and joke, but I was talking to a technical expert in the computer industry the other day and he said to me, ``Why don't I get paid as much as my mate who is a plumber?'' That is a fundamental question which Senator McKiernan's side of politics will not face up to. That is the fundamental problem of the centralised wage system which this Government continues to push. We need a more competitive and open environment for industry, with less government intervention. We need greater technology applied in a more commercial vein. We need improved efficiency in the transport and communications industries. I see that Senator Button has come into the chamber. I bet that he will not have the courage to deny that we need to improve our efficiency in the transport and communications industries; at least I would hope so. I would be terribly surprised if he approved of our transport and communications industries in their present form. We certainly need reductions in government regulations. I find it fascinating that this Government set up the Business Regulation Review Unit but gave it so few staff and resources that the Unit simply says, `We just cannot keep up with the current crop of regulations which this Government is pouring out, let alone apply our mind to some of the other regulations'.

SPEECH.PARA: I see that my time has just about expired. I repeat: to achieve this necessary economic climate, the Government needs to implement a more competitive, flexible and responsive system. We need to look at our education system and cost structures and we need to stop pussyfooting around. We have before us a window of opportunity, the likes of which we may never get again. I ask the Government to apply its mind as to how it can take advantage of that opportunity and move immediately-not next year, in a few months time or at the end of 1988 after the Bicentenary, but now-to do something which will benefit this nation and enable us to survive the current crisis which was so clearly pointed out by Mr Hayden in his Sir Edward Dunlop oration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am delighted to follow Senator Lewis in this debate. I am upset that his speech tonight was not broadcast because he gave a display-a vision splendid-of what commerce and industry will be like when he is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. I know that people in the small business community, the manufacturing industry and all the other industries would have been very encouraged to hear Senator Lewis's contribution tonight. He outlined where Australia should go and is not going at the moment. No doubt Senator Lewis will get his chance to fill a ministerial position in the very near future.

SPEECH.PARA: The debate on the Appropriation Bills gives the Senate a chance to discuss this nation's economy. Under any criteria, one would have to agree that this nation, under the present Government, is in dire straits. We have a foreign debt of $110 billion and a current account deficit of $1.3 billion, which the Government cannot get under control. I note that Senator Button is leaving the chamber. I know that he is embarrassed about these figures and does not like them to be repeated in the Senate. We have an inflation rate of 9 per cent, which is three times that of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development average. We have a dollar that has fallen by 10 per cent in the past two months and we have lost our AAA credit rating. It is no wonder Senator Button runs out of this chamber in disgrace. As No. 3 in the Government, he has to bear some responsibility for this Government's poor performance. Australia is in a crisis situation. If it were not for our agriculture and mining paving the way and earning 75 per cent of our foreign exchange-our primary industry accounts for 60 per cent of our export earnings-we would be in even greater dire straits, if that is possible.

Senator Stone, the Leader of the National Party of Australia in the Senate, often says in the Senate that the Government is sitting on its hands with its mind in neutral doing nothing. Unfortunately, I think that Senator Stone is being a little kind to the Government, because I do not believe that the Government is doing nothing; it is absolutely torpedoing our industries. It is destroying this nation's primary industries. It does not mind giving a bit of a hand to the steel industry, which is controlled by the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), the car industry-with a gentle shove from the ACTU-the coal industry or any other industry that employs ACTU unionists. The Government bends over backwards to help. That would not be so bad if the Government did not have two standards-one for the ACTU and one for primary industry.

We are in desperate times and we must work our way out of that situation. We should have a plan-an overall strategy. Tonight Senator Austin Lewis put down a strategy, which I welcome. But, unfortunately, we have two years to go before Senator Lewis becomes Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. We have to work with what we have. Like most plans, this one should be simple. I shall name three things that the Government should do to balance our current account deficit which, as I have said, is out of control: firstly, it should try to create every job that it is possible to create; secondly, it should earn as many export dollars as possible; and, thirdly, it should cut down imports as much as possible. On those three points the Government has failed Australia many times. It will never be able to get its economic house in order until it is prepared to face those three simple tests.

Let us look at what has happened in my State of Queensland. Shelburne Bay has been destroyed, sacrificed on the altar of the greenie vote. Eighty jobs, providing millions of dollars of export currency, have been wiped for a few lousy votes in Melbourne and Sydney. Senator Reynolds cannot deny that. She should do what Senator Button did and run out of this chamber in shame. If anybody should be defending north Queensland it is Senator Reynolds. She is the senator and Minister for north Queensland. While her Government is prepared to destroy jobs, opportunities and wealth creating export dollars, she sits there with a bland smile on her face and the economic future of Australia goes down the gurgler. Shelburne Bay has been torpedoed, but if there is one thing that has been absolutely sabotaged it is the World Heritage listing between Cooktown and Townsville with the loss of a $33m a year industry and the destruction of 3,000 jobs.

TALK.START.PARA: —Rubbish!

—It is not rubbish, Senator. Senator Reynolds is not prepared to stand up for north Queensland. If she had any decency at all she would stand up and disown the whole World Heritage planning. It might put her on the back bench for a term, but at least she would be representing the constituents who elected her and showing a rare display of honesty. However, she has sold out the people of north Queensland for a cosy front bench position. I do not want to turn this debate into a personal attack on Senator Reynolds because I am not the type of person who would set out to destroy a senator such as Senator Reynolds. But I can tell Senator Reynolds that the people of north Queensland are bitterly disappointed at her lack of action and representation. I know that a great many senators on this side of the House such as Senator Bjelke-Petersen and most other National Party of Australia senators and many Liberal Party of Australia senators have been up to north Queensland, visited the rainforest area and studied the situation at first hand. I do not know of any honourable senator opposite, except Senator Richardson, who has gone up into the rainforests.
—Look at the trouble he got into.

—Yes, look at the trouble he got into. I would like to point out to Senator Richardson, although he is not here at the moment, that in Question Time today I asked Senator Evans whether he condoned violence. He said that under extreme provocation he did. I say to honourable senators that if someone took their jobs and their livelihoods and destroyed the value of their houses and their town that would be extreme provocation. I do not condone what Senator Richardson copped. However, I can understand the frustration of the people of north Queensland when they see their way of life being destroyed to appease a few voters in the metropolitan areas of Melbourne and Sydney.

SPEECH.PARA: One of the most effective advertisements in the last election campaign was not an advertisement by the Labor Party, the National Party or the Liberal Party, but one that featured the sound of a chainsaw roaring in the forest with a tree crashing down and a voice coming over saying `Vote for the trees'. That vote was interpreted as a vote for the Australian Labor Party. People were sucked in because they do not understand what is happening in north Queensland. They do not understand that there are 877,000 hectares up there stretching from Cooktown to Townsville, some 450 square kilometres. Some 53 per cent of that is locked up in forestry reserves, never to be touched; 23 per cent is locked up in national parks, never to be touched; 5 per cent is personal property and freehold property; and 18 per cent is to be logged. That is 18 per cent of 877,000 hectares. That 18 per cent of 877,000 hectares can sustain an industry that will directly provide 750 timber jobs. Actually, I tell a lie, that is not correct. I have the latest list of figures that came through to me today. It cites the actual number of people employed in the timber industry.

That list shows that at present in the sawmill and plymill section of the industry, including administrative, sales and service personnel, 635 people are employed. Logging and hauling employs 80 people and there are some 50 people employed in marketing and in the Department of Forestry. The total employment therefore is 763. There are also 3,000 spin off jobs provided as a result of the timber industry. That will be destroyed. For what reason? It is for completely dishonest reasons that this Government will sacrifice on the altar of expediency those 3,000 jobs and a $33m industry.

I come back to my earlier point. I said that we have to create every possible job that we can in Australia. We have to reduce unemployment. We have to reduce our pay-outs on social services by providing real and lasting jobs. What do we do? I should say, `What does this Government do?' because I disassociate myself from the Government completely. We wipe out 3,000 jobs in north Queensland. We destroy an industry worth $33m. We destroy the towns, the councils, the homes and the livelihoods of people who are proud workers in the forestry industry. I refer to fourth generation workers. They are proud of the way they earn a living. What do we say? We say that we are going to provide jobs in the tourist industry. I tell Senator Reynolds that these people do not want to work in the tourist industry. They are proud bush men. They do not want to be carrying drinks for wealthy Japanese or American tourists. They want to do what they have been born and bred to do. They want to live the life they have been brought up to live. They get absolutely no assistance from this Government at all.

Let me say why I believe that this Government is being dishonest. Firstly it goes out and does a market survey. It finds that conservation is an issue. It then finds how it is going to win a lousy two per cent of the vote. It has no ethics and no morals, just the desire to win at all costs. It says, `We will not worry about the future. Let someone else worry about the future when we are in power'.

TALK.START.PARA: —When will that be?

—I can tell Senator Reynolds that it will not be long before we are in power if her Government governs this nation with regard only to pure expediency and the raw ambition to stay in power at any cost without worrying about Australia's future or the jobs of north Queenslanders. It will not be long. The Government can be expedient for a little while, but it will certainly catch up with it in the end. The dishonesty that Senator Reynolds's Government has exhibited in regard to the World Heritage listing has to be seen to be believed. In the Estimates Committee hearings I was told that eight consultants had been employed at a cost of $300,000. However, the Government has got only one report. Senator Richardson said at the Estimates Committee hearing that the Government had spent $300,000 on consultants and had only one report completed. I ask honourable senators to guess who that report came from.
—Who?

—Honourable senators will not believe this but it comes from Dr Keto. Who is Dr Keto? She is the president of the Rainforest Conservation Society of Queensland. She was paid $13,000 to make a report. Dr Keto's occupation is that of a biochemist. What she would know about rainforests we could write on the back of a threepenny stamp, and still have room left. She would not know one thing about rainforests, except that she has an overwhelming desire, that has become a personal ambition, to save the rainforests. She has no qualifications.

SPEECH.PARA: The other seven people to whom the Government paid the remainder of the $300,000 have not put in a report as yet. Despite this, the Government has drawn up the indicative boundaries of the proposed park and determined the number of jobs that will be lost. Although the Government has made a decision that it is going to list this great area of 877,000 hectares it has done so without listening to the seven consultants to whom it paid $300,000 to bring down reports. I suggest to the Government that it is wasting the taxpayers' money by spending $300,000 because it has decided that it will impound this great area just so it can pick up a lousy 2 per cent of the vote in Melbourne and Sydney.

The Government has destroyed the livelihoods, the jobs and the families of 3,000 people in north Queensland. How Senator Reynolds can go home to Townsville and face those people is beyond me. I said that the Government had employed eight consultants. The Government employed eight consultants and disregarded seven of them. It listened to Dr Keto who is in charge of the `Save the Rainforest' campaign. The Government did not listen to the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. It did not listen to the Queensland Department of Forestry. The Government did not listen to Professor Florence of the Australian National University. It has not listened to anyone, except the people who filled in a questionnaire and said that they were interested in conservation. The Government thought `Here are six or seven seats we can pick up in the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne'.

TALK.START.PARA: —Trendies.

—I would not say that they were trendies, but I would say that they are misguided. They do not understand what the Queensland Government has done. Let us look at what Senator Richardson said about the Queensland Government's proposals. To draw a red herring across the whole argument, Senator Richardson flooded the Press Gallery with Press releases saying that the Queensland timber industry is dead; it had lost jobs; it was finished; it had been destroyed-it was only a matter of time because it was on the ropes and it could not survive. But he did not say that the Queensland Government, of its own volition, reduced the timber take from 195,000 cubic metres per year to 60,000 cubic metres per year to bring the forestry harvest back to a figure that could be sustained on 18 per cent of the available rainforest. That is the honest approach that this Government should be looking at.

SPEECH.PARA: The Queensland Government's record on this matter is impeccable. We have been up there. I believe the Liberals have visited the rainforest, we have visited the forests, but where has Senator Reynolds been? Senator Lewis interrupted a very busy program to visit the rainforest. He knows it is most important to sustain this industry in order to provide jobs. We must provide every job that we can for the future of our sons and daughters. We must cut down on our imports into Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —What about the timber they are going to bring in?

—Senator Bjelke-Petersen has been into the rainforest. She understands too that the Government is going to cut $33m from the industry and that some other form of timber will have to be imported. That will lift our balance of payments deficit by another $33m a year. We are not only going to lose 2,000 jobs, but we are also going to have to import $33m worth of timber. Today I have been told that the firm of Touche Ross and Co., a group of public accountants with an international reputation, has done a study of the rainforests. A minimum payment of $60m in compensation will have to be made by this Government to the people in north Queensland. I am glad Senator Walsh is not in the chamber because his meal would certainly be spoilt if he knew that the Government will not only lose $33m but will also have to provide unemployment benefits for 3,000 people. On top of that, it will have to pay compensation of $60m to the timber industry. This has been worked out not by some little fly-by-night bush accountant in Ravenshoe, but by an accountancy firm with an international reputation.

SPEECH.PARA: The whole matter gets murkier and murkier. Senator Richardson says, `We will establish 840 direct jobs'. The Commonwealth's own consultant said that the Federal proposal for job creation in the timber plantations is 1,000. But let us just have a look at the real figures. A program involving 2,000 hectares per year for six years would employ only 84 people during the establishment phase, falling to 19 for the remainder of the cycle from seven years to 30 years. Then Senator Richardson says, `We will establish 12,000 hectares of plantations'. Again, no government land is available. The 12,000 hectares would have to be bought by the Federal Government. Senator Walsh--

TALK.START.PARA: —He's come rushing in!

—He has come rushing in. If I explain these figures to him he will be terribly worried. We are already up to $1 billion and we are only half way through. I will go through the figures again. There will be $60m in compensation required. Under Senator Richardson's plan the Government will have to purchase 12,000 hectares of prime land which is selling for about $1,000 a acre, probably $2,000 or $3,000 a hectare. The Government has lost taxation on a $33m a year industry and it will now have to pay unemployment benefits to 3,000 people. This World Heritage listing is a very sorry story for the Government's economic policy.
—Is it worth $60m to get those votes?

—The Government has paid $60m. In fact, it is more than $60m; it will probably take well over $1 billion to win six or seven marginal seats in the metropolitan areas of Sydney and Melbourne. I say to the people of Australia that it is a disgraceful exhibition of hunger for power. Absolutely no consideration has been given to the future of Australia or the taxpayers of this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALKER.NAME: Senator WALSH
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Finance)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not propose to delay the passage of the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The Bill.
Motion (by Senator Walsh) agreed to:
(1) That leave be given to Senators to move motions expressing opinions or making recommendations based on the Report of Estimates Committee A.
(2) That where more than one motion is proposed the motions may be debated together, but in all cases a motion or motions shall be disposed of before the question is put on the Vote before the Chair.
(3) That any Resolutions be reported when the Chairman reports to the President at the conclusion of proceedings in Committee of the Whole.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am concerned, and this concern was expressed in the report of Senate Estimates Committee A, that a Bill has not yet been presented to this Parliament to set the precincts of the new Parliament House. This matter was raised in the Estimates Committee. In response to a question from me the Department of the Senate has said:

SPEECH.PARA: In its report presented to the Parliament on 28 November 1985 the Joint Committee on the New Parliament House recommended that legislation be passed delineating the precincts of the new building, declaring that the Presiding Officers have the management and control of the precincts, and amongst other things, making provision to facilitate prosecutions for offences committed in the precincts. Mr President McClelland had a bill drafted to reflect the recommendations of the Committee, and on 19 March 1986-
I remind the Senate that that is 20 months or so ago-

forwarded the bill to the Prime Minister for the Government's consideration. The bill is still under consideration by the Government and the Presiding Officers have asked that that consideration be concluded as a matter of urgency so that the legislation may be passed before the new building is occupied.

I simply wonder whether the Government intends to deal with this as a matter of urgency and when we can expect to see the legislation before this Parliament. Of course, this has a particular problem relating to the prosecution of people for offences committed in or near the Parliament House. The Senate Estimates Committee A report to the Senate expressed concern over this matter, stating:
The Committee's primary concern is simply the security of the building.
The Committee noted:

. . . extensive consultation has taken place between the Parliamentary departments and the A.C.T. Administration on means of dealing with the graffiti vandalism to the New Parliament House, but notes also that the responsibility for the prosecution of offenders is to an extent unclear, pending a definition of the precincts of the New Parliament House.

I hope that the Government responds smartly to this matter because it seems to be taking an awful lot of time. I noted from the estimates that a significant amount of money has been set aside to cope with graffiti on the new Parliament House. As I recall it, about $50,000 is the amount set aside in the first year just in case people start scribbling on the walls of the new Parliament House. Of course, it also involved quite an expensive preparation of wall areas to limit the impact of such scribbling. I would be grateful if the Government could give an indication of when it will do something.

TALK.START.PARA: —As far as the precincts Bill is concerned, the final Cabinet discussion is under way at the moment. The Speaker and I spoke with the Minister for Administrative Services, Mr West, yesterday. We think that most of the difficulties that we had have been cleared up. We realise that this is a matter of urgency. We believe that the precincts Bill will be introduced into the House of Representatives next week and we hope that it will be dealt with by the Senate before it rises. It is extremely important that that happen.
—Into what is it going to fit?

—I realise that that is a problem. Hopefully, if there is agreement on all sides of the chamber, it will go through rather quickly. We have to deal with a number of the leases for the commercial properties that will be concerned with the new Parliament House. I am confident that, if we get the legislation into the House of Representatives next week, we can deal with it before we rise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the President for that answer. It is quite cheering to hear that he has managed to get the Government stirred up enough to do something about it. The other thing I would like to raise relates to Senate information systems. I quote from the report of Estimates Committee A, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee was highly critical of procedures of the then Department of the Special Minister of State (SMOS), in ensuring that an Australian-made system could be found which would ensure sufficient networking and compatibility between equipment in electorate offices and the new Parliament House. Of the failure of the SMOS to achieve the goals that had been set, the Committee had this to say in its Report of May 1987:

A situation has now developed which should never have arisen-two systems, with two training and support systems, two word processing software options, two different keyboards, duplication and waste in staffing, and so on.
The report continues:
The Committee notes that Estimates Committee F has expressed similar concerns to those of this Committee.

It seems extraordinary that this unsatisfactory performance was outlined then and the unsatisfactory performance of the equipment supplied by the initial contractors has gone on. The report continues:

The Committee notes the assurances given by officers of the Department of the Senate that compatibility of equipment is dependent only on some modest expenditure by the Department of Administrative Services to link electorate offices with the New Parliament House Network.

I believe that it is only right that we should get an assurance that that small amount of expenditure will be forthcoming to ensure that this equipment is compatible. I repeat that the report states: `is dependent only on some modest expenditure'. To what extent can we have an assurance from the Government that that modest expenditure, which will have an infinitely large marginal benefit, will be paid?

TALK.START.PARA: —I noticed that Senator Michael Baume was quoting from the Committee's report of May 1987. I believe that the problem has basically been solved, but if the honourable senator raises this matter when the Department of Administrative Services is dealt with, I think he will get a much more detailed answer.

—While we are on the subject of the computing system I would just like to point out that a number of people have come to me and said, `There is simply no good instruction booklet for the computing system'. There are the large instruction booklets for the DEC system and our Cleveland systems have a very confused instruction setup. I ask whoever is in charge-
—If anybody is in charge.

—If anyone is in charge of the computing system I ask that person to compile a concise, easy to read, short instruction manual for the computing system we have because we are wasting an awful lot of time trying to figure out how to use this equipment and the instruction manuals are simply not adequate at this time.

—Again, whilst we are in this area of word processors, computers and technology, where honourable senators are involved in committee work and where it is necessary for them to be engaged in a re-write of draft reports, it is most difficult and very frustrating when the software that is given to us on one make of computer is different from the make of computer that we have in our offices. It is hard enough to be studying the background of the report, concerning which one must attempt to formulate changes and amendments in a form that other members of the committee can understand, but to have this problem is quite unnecessary. In the case I am talking about, the Joint Select Committee on Video Material, for the work that is being done by the Senate staff-the stenographers on the ground floor and the systems people, Mark Goodall and others-I can only express my deep appreciation. But it is taking many days to do what would not have taken any time if, in the first place, we had compatible systems. I still have only up to chapter 3 of 15 chapters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sibraa Sen The Hon K.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is one of the occasions on which I wish that I could have one of the Senate officers who is sitting quite close to me made an honorary senator so that he could speak. I refer to Mr Wharton, who has done a tremendous amount of work on this subject, as I am sure all honourable senators know. I am very sympathetic to what Senator Harradine and Senator Sanders have said. I am sure all honourable senators realise that there has been a long history to this matter. I would like to point out that the Department of the Senate looks after only the equipment in Parliament House. The Cleveland system, which is in the electorate offices, has been looked after by the Department of Administrative Services. I am sure all honourable senators realise that. Again, if I can pass the ball, that perhaps is where questions ought to arise-in the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —As foreshadowed during my remarks in the second reading debate on the Appropriation Bills, I formally wish to move the amendment which was incorporated in my remarks at that time. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that:
(1) this Bill is part of a continuing pattern of failure by the Hawke Government to face up to the need for adequate and timely adjustment of the economy;
(2) this failure by the Hawke Government has heightened Australia's vulnerability to changes in world economic conditions at this time of crisis on world financial markets;

(3) because the Government has squandered time and resources while persistently running Australia into massive debt, our national economic options are now so narrowly limited as to largely deprive us of independent options; and

(4) the Government no longer has the scope to protect jobs, to stop the prospective rise in unemployment, to stem the continuing rise in numbers of Australians living in poverty or to protect the position of families more generally;

and therefore calls on the Government to revise its fiscal, labour market, taxation and other micro-economic policies with a view to providing a more appropriate economic framework to meet our current economic and social dangers''.
Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Stones's) be agreed to.
