INTERJECT.PARA: Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —During the hearings of Estimates Committee A on 6 October I asked a question relating to rebates of excise on diesel fuel used in forestry roads construction in Tasmania. We do not appear to have departmental representatives present.
—Ask your question, Senator Walters.
—I am not sure whether the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) will be able to answer this without some help.
—If you ask you will find out.

—The Deputy Comptroller-General of Customs promptly and correctly advised me that recent decisions overruling a 1982 amendment to the Customs Act and claiming repayments of previously granted rebates would be withdrawn. I would like to compliment him on his efficiency and the speed with which he was able to fix the problem for me. However, new information has come to light which highlights glaring inconsistencies in relation to diesel fuel rebates at some railheads in Tasmania, particularly at Maydena, Bridgewater, Parattah and Conara. Contractors using diesel powered equipment engage in offloading road trucks on to rail wagons. They have either had their rebate claims rejected or been told that they are ineligible for rebate. However, operators at Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd rail sidings and at least one other goods yard claim and receive the fuel rebate. Can the Minister explain to me the inconsistencies in this? The two issues raise doubts about the consistency of the application of the Customs Act.
—I cannot and I won't even try.
—Mr Temporary Chairman, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That progress be reported.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Walters's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister for Finance the same question: during the Estimates Committee A hearing on 6 October I asked a question relating to rebates of excise on diesel fuel used in forestry road construction in Tasmania. The Deputy Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service promptly and correctly advised me that the recent decision overruling a 1982 amendment to the Customs Act, claiming repayment of previously granted rebates, would be withdrawn. I compliment him on his efficiency and the speed with which this was carried out. New information has come to light which highlights glaring inconsistencies in relation to diesel fuel rebates at some railheads in Tasmania, particularly at Maydena, Bridgewater, Parattah and Conara. Contractors using diesel powered equipment, engaged in offloading road trucks on to rail wagons, have either had their rebate claims rejected or been told that they are ineligible for rebate. However, operators at the Associated Pulp and Paper Mills Ltd (APPM) rail sidings and other goods yards claim and receive the fuel rebate. These two issues raise serious doubts about the consistency of the application of the Customs Act in Tasmania. No doubt there are many more cases. Is the Minister aware of what is occurring? I notice that there has been a change of Minister. I compliment Senator Button on replacing the Minister so promptly. I now address my question to Senator Button.
—You silly old bag.
—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. That was an unparliamentary comment.
—Order! I understand the point of order. Senator Walsh will resume his proper seat and withdraw the remark.
—I withdraw.
—Thank you, Mr Chairman. I am pleased to see Senator Button in the chamber.
—Harpy!

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. There is an absolute limit to the sort of personal behaviour to be tolerated in this chamber. Senator Walsh clearly disregarded your previous ruling. His behaviour is clearly unacceptable to the chamber. There is a contingent notice of motion by the Leader of the Opposition to require the question to be put if the proper courtesies are not extended by Senator Walsh. He has behaved in a most unparliamentary fashion. He has now left the chamber. I believe the dignity of this chamber and the respect which is due to honourable senators is simply being affronted by Senator Walsh by this sort of behaviour. I give notice that this behaviour is quite unacceptable to the Opposition.
—I seek leave to withdraw on behalf of Senator Walsh.
—That is not good enough.
—Order! I do not need any more advice on this matter. The Black Rod will instruct Senator Walsh to return to the chamber and withdraw the remark that he made, which was quite unparliamentary.
—I would like to ask Senator Button a question that I put earlier to Senator Walsh regarding an Estimates committee hearing on 6 October. Did Senator Button hear my question?

—Mr Chairman, I raise a point of order. Is it proper that we proceed from one point to another without resolving the first matter-that is, that Senator Walsh be brought back by the Black Rod to apologise. At such time that matter can be resolved and then we can proceed in the normal course with the debate that is taking place.
—Order! There is no point of order. We may proceed. The matter concerning Senator Walsh will be dealt with when Senator Walsh returns. He has been sent for.
—I ask Senator Button whether he heard my question. If not, would he like me to repeat it?
—No, I did not.

—During the Estimates Committee A hearing on 6 October I asked a question relating to rebates of excise diesel fuel used in forest road construction in Tasmania. The Deputy Comptroller-General of the Australian Customs Service promptly and correctly advised me that the recent decisions overruling a 1982 amendment to the Customs Act, which claimed repayment of previously granted rebates, would be withdrawn. I compliment him on his efficiency and the speed with which that was carried out. New information has come to light which highlights glaring inconsistencies in relation to diesel fuel rebates at some railheads in Tasmania, particularly at Maydena, Bridgewater, Parattah and Conara. Contractors using diesel powered equipment, engaged in offloading road trucks on to rail wagons, have either had their rebate claims rejected or been told that they are ineligible for rebate. However, operators at APPM rail sidings and at other goods yards make claims and have received the fuel rebate. Can the Minister explain what has occurred and the inconsistencies?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I cannot explain what has occurred in relation to this matter. While I try to maintain a comprehensive view of my Department's activities, I am not totally familiar with the diesel fuel rebate insofar as it applies to a particular small town in Tasmania. On the last occasion Senator Walters had a request of this kind she received a letter from the Deputy Comptroller-General of Customs within two days. I offered her that facility in the course of the Estimates Committee. I offer it to her again. I am quite happy for the Comptroller-General to write to her in the next day or two and answer the question she has asked tonight. I undertake that that will be done.

—I ask the question of Senator Button: Inasmuch as I assume that the Government is of one view, why is it that he is able to answer the question in the way that he has and the Minister for Finance (Senator Walsh) answered it in the way that he did?

—Would Senator Button consider making some arrangement to report progress until we can resolve what has quite clearly become a matter of some crisis in the Chamber? Senator Button will appreciate that the decencies of this place have been seriously encroached upon by his ministerial colleague tonight. I ask Senator Button to apply his wise mind to resolving this problem. I can fill in by asking a number of questions which arise out of a departmental matter, and this might give Senator Button time to apply his mind. Instead of endeavouring just to fill in and waste the time of the Committee I would rather some attempt be made by the Government to bring this critical matter to some conclusion. Senator Walsh has now reappeared, so the problem may very well be resolved.
—Senator Walsh, before you left the chamber you were heard to make a distinctly unparliamentary remark, which you should now withdraw.
—What was it, Mr Chairman?
—I will not repeat it. You are perfectly well aware of what it was. You should withdraw.
—Somebody told me that I was alleged to have said, `You old harpy'. In fact I just said, `Harpy'.
—That should be withdrawn-now.
—I withdraw, in deference to you, Mr Chairman.
—Order! It must be an unconditional withdrawal, not one in deference to me.
—I withdraw.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I now direct a question to the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce.
—You have a real question?

—Yes, I have a real question and it is in relation to so-called corporate citizenship or some new-fangled name which the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce or the Minister has worked out about partnerships in progress, or some such thing. The Minister may not be aware that while he was overseas a number of Press releases were issued from either the Minister's office or his Department's office about a number of contracts which were apparently being entered into by the Government while the Minister was away. I refer to a contract with Digital Equipment Corporation (Aust.) Pty Ltd which was alleged to be valued at about $500m. Another contract which was announced, I think, today or yesterday was with NEC Information Systems Aust. Pty Ltd. In any event, a number of Press releases were issued about these contracts.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has been back from overseas for some time. I have endeavoured to allow him time to recover from the excesses or whatever of his trip, but I am wondering when the Minister will get around to explaining to the Parliament and to the public at large what the Government is on about with its corporate citizenship proposals. I am concerned, as was the Joint Committee of Public Accounts, that the offsets program should produce what I think the Committee called real product exports. In other words, it should not be a technical offset whereby some technology transfer appears to take place and one is unable to make a proper assessment of the value of that technology transfer, but we should be able to ascertain the real value of the export arising from the so-called corporate citizenship program, the partnership in progress or whatever the Government is calling it. Is the Minister able at this stage to give us some explanation as to what this matter is all about and what might have arisen as a result of his trip overseas.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Lewis said that he would like an explanation to be given to the public and to the Parliament. I do not think the public has too much difficulty understanding what this is all about but Senator Lewis clearly does, which does not entirely surprise me. I am not sure what this matter has to do with these appropriations but I do not want to avoid the question by saying that.
—I did ask you during the Estimates committee.

—I think it would be best if, at an appropriate time, which is not yet, I made a statement to the Senate about a whole number of arrangements that have been entered into by the Government in relation to what Senator Lewis calls corporate citizenship but what we call partnership agreements, and I will undertake to do that in due course. The offsets program is of only marginal relevance to the corporate partnership program, but it is of some relevance. In essence that program is about encouraging computer and communications equipment companies-companies involved in the so-called information industries-to do more research and development in Australia and to export.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not know whether Senator Lewis has had the advantage of reading a very full Press release which I put out about this issue perhaps five weeks ago. I thought I had made it available to him but if he has not seen it I can certainly give him an extra copy. It explains the purpose of the policy and, to some extent, it explains the likely achievements of the policy. Much of industry policy in the 1980s has to be about undoing what was done or doing what was not done in the 1960s and 1970s by the governments of the time. That means developing a manufacturing sector which has a sophisticated technological infrastructure. These matters were not attended to by government in the past but they will be by this Government.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister will recall that the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements recommended that there be a dual system of tendering for contracts where offsets are involved. This was a means whereby by paying higher prices for goods for the offsets program one could ascertain the contribution being made by the Federal Government. The Government rejected that recommendation of the Inglis Committee. My recollection is that the Government gave to the Bureau of Industry Economics the responsibility of supervising in some way or other the contracts being entered into so that the extra cost of the offsets requirement imposed on those tendering for government contracts could be ascertained. I have not been able to see any report from the Bureau of Industry Economics as to the nature of those costs. Is such a report available? Has the Government received such a report? Has it been made public and I have missed it, or has it not been made public? If not, when will it be made public? Alternatively, if the Government is reconsidering the recommendation of the Inglis Committee it might be wiser in the circumstances to insist upon dual tenders being sought-one with offsets and one without offsets.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —As a student of poetry, Senator Lewis will remember the line, `The moving finger moves, and, having writ, moves on.
—Get it right. It is: `The Moving Finger writes; and, having writ, moves on'.

—I am sorry. Senator Puplick will have understood my point. The offsets policy has gone through a number of developments and, if I might say so, those developments might be described as stages, A, B and C, and Senator Lewis's question suggests that he is locked into stage A, which was some time ago. Increasingly, offsets policy is not, and will not be, about the sort of large contracts that were entered into in the past, and which were rarely fulfilled, but it will be about a range of other issues, particularly technological transfer and, increasingly I suspect, agreements of the corporate partnership nature to which Senator Lewis referred in an earlier question. In so far as the Bureau of Industry Economics was requested by the Government to look at this matter, it was on an ongoing basis, not on the basis of producing a report. The Government has not reconsidered the recommendation of the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements on this issue and we regard it as an increasingly less relevant issue. That is the position.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —Surely the Minister will agree that in any offsets proposal, a tenderer is putting itself in a situation where it has some sort of commitment to spend money in Australia, and therefore, the probabilities are that it takes that cost into account in its tender price. Surely it is a question of public accountability of these tender prices. Surely, the people of Australia are entitled to know whether the nation might be better off without an offsets policy; whether, if the Government seeks some technology transfer, it might be better to purchase that technology transfer rather than to hide the purchase cost in some offsets policy.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister can make his remarks about whether I am in A, B or C phase, but nevertheless the truth of the matter is, as the Industries Assistance Commission will very soon expose even if the Government is not prepared to do so, that offsets are a cost burden, and there must be some built-in cost factor. The public is entitled to know what that cost factor is, so that it can make an assessment as to whether or not we would be better off not having that in-built cost factor in our offsets arrangements, and instead, if the Government wants some technology transfer, it should simply purchase it.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not disagree with the substance of the argument. That is precisely why the Government has been moving out of the sort of conventional offsets about which Senator Lewis is talking and into new arrangements. As I recall, even the Inglis Committee of Review on Government High Technology Purchasing Arrangements found that difficult to estimate. Some 60 countries operate offsets policies of one kind or another, and the suggestion that the Australian community was necessarily being discriminated against by international suppliers of large scale equipment is one that would be very difficult to substantiate. The Government did not accept that recommendation.

—On this technology transfer business, might I ask the Minister whether it will be possible, for example, for a major multinational company to task to its Australian subsidiary some technological question, while retaining the proprietary rights, the intellectual ownership of those rights in the multinational company. Can it then use Australian technicians to resolve the question, and then not only take back the entire advantage of that technological gain to the nation, but also claim the 150 per cent research and development taxation concession? These are the sorts of questions to which Parliament is waiting to hear the answers.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —The Parliament has been waiting avidly, if I might say so. It has been waiting for years. I shall deal with the question by referring to the last part first. We are anxious to attract--
—I apologise, Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I once again want to raise the issue of the steel industry plan, which is under this Department. This afternoon, in an unprecedented move, the General Manager of the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd steel plant in Port Kembla called a Press conference in which he announced that the company will not proceed with steel making at Port Kembla if the recent levels of industrial confrontation persist. I raise this matter because it is the strongest comment that has been made about this unfortunate situation. I welcomed the steel plan and I congratulated Senator Button on it at the time because I thought that it had within it the ingredients of success, and success was absolutely vital to the region from which I come because it depends so heavily on the Port Kembla steel works.

SPEECH.PARA: In the Senate Estimates Committee A meetings, I pressed Senator Button about the scope for sanctions to require the unions to fill their part of this tripartite arrangement. It is a system under which the company has contributed $800m and the taxpayer, through the Government, has contributed about $100m in bounties, but the union movement has contributed industrial unrest. I asked Senator Button what the Government intended to do about it and his view was then, and it has been repeated since in this chamber, that until the beginning of this year, the steel industry plan had resulted in a good level of industrial relations and that the problem only really emerged in the February to May period of 1987. When asked what he was going to do about the situation now and whether there was any cause for intervention, he said:
The Government does take a role through industrial relations policies of one kind or another.

All I can say is that Senator Button's `one kind or another' has ended up fairly unsatisfactory in terms of its outcome. His industrial relations policies have ended up with a threat to the major steel producer in this nation, the major provider of either import replacement or export product and certainly the major employer in the Illawarra region.

Can I deal with what seems to me-I presume it was by accident-to be Senator Button's misleading remark that this matter had only blown up this year? I remind him of the fact that in the June 1986 six months, the level of industrial disputation at Port Kembla represented 124,774 man hours lost, which was an increase of 684 per cent over the previous period. It represented a very substantial rise and one sufficiently large for the 1985-86 annual report to note:
It is disappointing to note that industrial disputation returned to high levels in the last six months of the year and that man-hours lost per employee continued to increase . . .

If this pattern of industrial disputation continues, it does not augur well for the success of the industry over the remainder of the Plan and, consequently, for the longer-term security of employment.

That is what the Steel Industry Authority warned the Government of over a year ago. As the only solution to this matter, we have Senator Button's various industrial relations programs, none of which appears to be capable of doing anything positive. This report for the previous year made this point:

When the Steel Industry Plan was being developed it was recognised by all parties that the high level of industrial disputation in the industry was having a detrimental effect on its overall performance. In the Accord between BHP and the Unions it was agreed that both parties would comply with established dispute settlement procedures to reduce the incidence of disruption leading to the loss of wages and production.
It concluded:
There is strong evidence to suggest that this part of the Accord has not been followed over the last six months of the year, particularly at Port Kembla.
In a quite interesting comment, the 1985-86 report said:

The Authority recognises that total manhours lost through industrial disputes is an imperfect measure of the industry's performance in industrial relations due to the significant fall in total employment that has occurred in the industry in recent years. Accordingly, the Authority has decided also to monitor manhours lost through industrial disputes per employee as a more accurate measure of industrial relations performance in the industry.

Table 8 shows what that record is. I raise this because, quaintly enough, in the latest annual report this more accurate measure does not appear. We are entitled to ask: Why on earth does it not appear in the latest annual report? Is it because of pressure that the union movement has brought to bear on the Authority? There were certainly complaints in Wollongong about the Parliament being given this report before the trade union movement. In fact, Mr Nando Lelli of the local ironworkers union regarded as disgraceful that `Baume should have been given access' to the report before the union was. That section of the Federated Ironworkers Association of Australia is the bad section of what is generally a very responsible union in Australia. Mr Lelli complained, and I noted that he is reported to have said:
Mr Lelli said as a result of Senator Baume gaining first look at the figures, the unions were put in a defensive situation.

They were put in a defensive situation because the figures showed what an appalling performance they had put up. What concerns me is that this table, which, as the Steel Industry Authority says, is a more accurate measure of industrial relations, does not appear-on my brief look-in the latest annual report. The significance of this is quite simple. Obviously, if there are fewer people employed, as there are now at BHP, and yet the number of man hours lost increases, the percentage of people who are on strike all the time is going up at a far greater rate. I would be grateful if the Minister could explain to the chamber-this might be an appropriate time-why this more appropriate measure-a table-of what is perhaps the most depressing and central issue in the whole question of the steel industry plan-that is, the question of industrial disruption-does not appear in the lastest annual report.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will address the question to the Steel Industry Authority and provide Senator Baume with an answer as quickly as possible.

—I am concerned that the Minister was not prepared to answer my questions, which he started to answer, apparently because I turned behind me and sought some advice from one of my colleagues about a matter. That shows a petulance which I would not have believed this Minister would display. He goes around with a high reputation, and yet I am sure that people in industry would be surprised to discover such a petulant, childish performance simply because I sought some information from a colleague behind me while he was--
—You asked a question and you were not prepared to listen to the answer.

—It may be that he was unable to answer the question. If he is unable to answer the question at this stage, why does he not say so? He started off by saying that he would deal firstly with the last part of the question, about the 150 per cent rebate. I offer the Minister the opportunity, again, to let me have an answer to the questions which I raised in connection with this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —With respect to the tax concession, the Government is not about discriminating against multinational companies which do research and development work in Australia. His sort of voodoo theory that they will come here, pick the best of Australian brains and somehow steal them is, if I might say so, antiquated in what is increasingly an international economy. Many benefits flow from research and development being done in Australia, including benefits of improving the research and development infrastructure, the employment of skilled personnel, the technological transfer which results, and all those things.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable senator led into this question by referring to the fact that certain companies might be asked to, what is sometimes called, `mandate' particular products here. That is right. But it will not be done on the basis that they are not competitive or operating competitively in Australia in respect of those product developments. For example, Australia has particular strengths in areas of software development and so on which make it very attractive for some countries to develop products here and market them in the region. If they do market them in the region, world markets and benefits flow to Australia not only in terms of the taxation revenue which is earned but also in terms of the export earnings. Those are the more general issues which have to be taken into account. One cannot go back to the mentality of previous years and think about this country as a little protected island which has to be relieved from the burdens of the big wide world. It has to operate in that world. It is through these sorts of mechanisms that it will best do so.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask the Minister a very simple, quick and direct question: Is the steel industry plan still alive or have the unions today killed it?

TALKER.NAME: Senator BUTTON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce)

TALK.START.PARA: —I honestly do not know what Senator Baume is talking about. He is hysterically excited about the fact that the Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd (BHP) today uttered a warning to the unions at Port Kembla, and he asked me the silly question: Does it mean the unions today killed the plan because BHP made a statement? The obvious answer to that question is no, but the further answer-if the honourable senator wants a short one-is that it is a silly question. He will bear with me for making that point. If Senator Baume analyses his own question, I think that even he will reach the same conclusion. The answer to that question is no.
—How long do you think it will survive?
—Until 31 December 1988.

—I understand that the motion before the Committee at the moment is that the votes for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce be passed without amendment or request. To that the Opposition wishes to move as an amendment that the votes for the Department of Industry, Technology and Commerce be reduced by $1 in order to express its profound disapproval of the unparliamentary conduct of Senator Peter Walsh during the debate on these estimates.
—Can't we leave that until tomorrow?

—I want to resolve it tonight. I do not need to rehearse the events which took place in the chamber this evening other than to say that there are certain standards of propriety and behaviour which we believe ought to be properly adhered to. We believe that they were not properly adhered to by Senator Walsh this evening. It is unusual to have on the Senate Notice Paper a contingent notice of motion which refers to a senator by name. There is already one in the name of the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) and, indeed, another in the name of the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Haines), which draw attention to this particular matter.

—Order! Senator Puplick, before you go any further, I think I should put this in order. Technically there is not a motion before the Chair. We are considering the votes as a whole. You are not entitled to move an amendment to the motion but you are entitled to move a request. I take it what you are moving is a request that the vote be reduced by $1. Is that correct?
—That is correct. Mr Chairman, I will seek your guidance on this matter.
—You should have sought that guidance before you got up.

—I have received a great deal of advice on this matter. I do not claim to be an expert on it. I am attempting to do what I can to conform with the conflicting advice which I am receiving. It had been my original intention to move quite simply that certain words be added to the end of the motion that the votes of the Department be passed without amendment or request. Mr Chairman, I will be guided by you in terms of the appropriate motion to be moved at this stage.

—The situation is that there is no motion before the Chair. There is a question at the end of each vote which is put formally. There is no formal motion. You are entitled, if you wish to do so, to request that the vote be reduced by an amount of $1. You can do so as an expression of opinion. If you move that as a motion, that is in order. You may give whatever reasons you choose.
—Mr Chairman, I am loath to move a motion which, if carried, would in fact require some reference back to the House of Representatives by way of request. That is not the intention.
—That would have to happen with a request.
—That is obviously not the purpose of what the Opposition is attempting to do this evening, Mr Chairman.
—Why don't I just give you a dollar and I will get it back from Walsh later. Would that make you happy?

—If I received a dollar from Senator Button, the first thing I would want to know is whether it was a false one or not. As far as this is concerned, what we are seeking to formally record is that in the opinion of the Senate the behaviour of Senator Walsh this evening during the course of the debate on these estimates was unparliamentary, that it was provocative of all honourable senators, that it was a blatant disregard of the rulings of the Chair and that it should not pass without being formally noted in a disapproving fashion by the Committee of the Whole. It is clearly a matter of some particular difficulty to find the appropriate form of words, since it is not our intention to seek to reduce the vote for the Department which is before us.
—Then why don't you move to reduce it?

—That was the advice which was given. My initial view would be that I should be given leave to add certain words to the motion that the vote be passed without amendment or request. I am loath to move to the suspension of Standing Orders in order to do that. I do not want to delay the Committee for that particular purpose. Perhaps, therefore, Mr Chairman, I can simply ask your advice as to whether, with leave, it would be possible to move an expression of the opinion of the Senate to add certain words at the end of the motion that the vote for this Department be passed without amendment or request along the lines of `but the Senate expresses its profound disapproval of the unparliamentary conduct of Senator Peter Walsh during the course of the debate on these estimates'.
—Senator Puplick, if you can get leave, you may move such a motion.
—Mr Chairman, I seek leave to formally move such a motion.
—Is leave granted?
—I would like some advice, seeing that everybody else is getting free advice.
—Is leave granted?
—He is asking a question of the Clerk.
—No, I am not-I am asking the question of the Senate.
—He is asking a question of the Clerk. There are thousands of people advising on the other side.
—Is leave granted?
—There is a question to be resolved before leave is granted.
—Is leave granted for Senator Puplick to move such a motion?
—Why can't we seek some advice before we give an answer?
—All right, seek your advice. I will help you if I can.
—If he suspends Standing Orders, what does he do next?

—If leave is refused-and any one senator may refuse leave-Senator Puplick cannot move his motion. If leave is granted, he may move his motion and it is then up to the Committee to decide what it does with the motion. Is leave granted for Senator Puplick to move his motion?
—Leave is not granted.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Home Births-Fiji-Australia Post: America's Cup Stamps

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Tate) proposed:
That the Senate do now adjourn.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I call Senator Walters.

INTERJECT.PARA: Senator Haines-What do you call Senator Walters?

TALK.START.PARA: —At 10.48 p.m., do not tempt me!

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, you will be pleased to know that I will be speaking about a matter entirely different from that which we have been discussing. As this is only the second time in 12 years that I have spoken in the adjournment debate, I will be as quick as possible. Earlier this month a working party of the National Health and Medical Research Council brought down a report on home births and alternative birth centres. The National Health and Medical Research Council unanimously endorsed that working party's recommendations on 4 November 1987, at its 104th Congress. As a result of those recommendations being endorsed, most of the major newspapers carried sensational headlines. Let me quote from just one article which is headed `Home safe alternative for births, says health body'. The article states:

SPEECH.PARA: In a major policy turnaround, Australia's premier health advisory body has backed home births as safe for most mothers.
The National Health and Medical Research Council has also criticised hospitals for failing to meet the needs of consumers.

``We concluded that if you give careful consideration to the individual and the skills of the attendants there is no reason to assume that birth is any safer in hospital'', spokeswoman Dr Cathy Mead said yesterday.
Because I was concerned about the headlines, I immediately turned to the report. I would like to quote just a few points in the summary of conclusions of that report:

Women should be able to make their own choice about place of birth depending on their geographical location, factors relating to their pregnancy and the professional and support services available to them.
Many obstetric services are not meeting the expressed needs of many of their customers and all hospitals should address this.
It goes on to suggest what the hospitals should do. It says:

An extensive review of the literature did not substantiate the expressed concern about the safety of home births. However, it is now highly unlikely that a study of sufficient statistical power could even be undertaken to unequivocally answer the questions of relative safety of place of birth.
On page 4, the report says-and it is now referring to how unlikely that statistical study would be:

A randomised control study is the ideal way of evaluating the safety of place of birth. However, as maternal deaths are now very rare and perinatal mortality associated with full term delivery (and not attributable to congenital malformation) is also very low the number of participants required for such a study would be too large. In addition it is unlikely that there would be acceptance of the idea of random allocation to a place of birth.

Of course, there could not be random samples of place of birth-hospital patients and births at home-because those people in hospital would include all those patients who are very much at risk. In the introduction to the report, it is stated:
In June 1978 . . . the National Health and Medical Research Council made the following statement on home births:

The Council noted that the trend for women to request home delivery has occurred partly because of unfamiliar and forbidding clinical surroundings in hospitals. It therefore recommended that in the interests of reducing the number of requests for homebirths, obstetric hospitals should review their procedures and facilities so that without compromising the necessary clinical requirements, a more homelike atmosphere permitting family-child interaction could be promoted.
With that, there is no argument. The report goes on:
Although birth centres have been established-
and this report, of course, had been referring to birth centres in hospitals-
around Australia the demand for home births is not lessening and in recent years the number of births taking place at home has continued to rise.

This statement surprised me particularly. So I rang the chairman of that working part, Dr John Campbell, who is an obstetrician at the Queen Victoria Medical Centre. To my surprise, when I asked Dr Campbell what figures he had to substantiate his statement, he said, `We have no figures to substantiate that statement. There are no figures for home births'. When I said that he had said in the report, `The demand for home births is not lessening and in recent years the number of births taking place at home has continued to rise' he merely said, `People believe that they are on the rise'. The only figures on home births in this report are for 1985 and 1986. In 1985 there were 1,135 and in 1986 there was a decrease to 1,068. There is a little asterisk beside the 1986 figures which says:
Although the number of home births had fallen in 1986, those working in this area believe that the demand for home births had increased.

It seems incredible to me that a report that has been brought down by the working party of a very august body-I believe it to be-should use words clearly saying that the demand for home births in recent years is not lessening and that the number of births taking place in homes has continued to rise, and that it should be unable to substantiate that statement with any figures. The only figures produced in the report indicate a decrease in the number of home births. The report goes on:
In March 1986 the Women's Health Committee NH&MRC acknowledged that home births and alternative birth centres were well established.

These sorts of statements which are only anecdotal are perhaps all right for Homebirths Australia, that has a vested interest, but surely they are not good enough for a scientific body such as the National Health and Medical Research Council to abide by. It says that its working party recognised in March 1986 that home births are established. Yet, in this report, it is pointed out that only 0.44 per cent of births take place in the home. I fail to understand, when such a small number of births take place in the home, that it can be concluded that home births are well established. The terms of reference that the committee was to look at are as follows:

To carry out an overview of the homebirth movement with the aim of establishing better professional relationships between homebirth practitioners and the medical profession, and of establishing better relationships between families and support people and the medical profession.

That is the first one. Unfortunately, the way the working party seems to have carried out that term of reference is indicated by its spokesperson, Dr Cathy Mead who said she did not expect the National Health and Medical Research Council's change of policy to result in a massive increase in the number of women requesting births at home or a backlash from the doctors. She said that home births make up only half of one per cent of all births, so even if the number is doubled it would not be a significant threat to anyone's income. That sort of statement from a spokesman for the working party of the National Health and Medical Research Council hardly acts towards a better professional relationship between the home birth practitioners and the medical profession. Her statement only underlines that this attitude would create far greater divisions.

My husband, who happens to be an obstetrician, both in private practice and as a staff member of the Royal Hobart Hospital, took great exception to that comment from Dr Mead. In an article in the newspaper following the announcement he was reported as saying that he believed the statement by Dr Cathy Mead was degrading to his profession. He said:
If they think money is the reason most obstetricians oppose home births, then their opinion is not worthy of consideration and they should give us a public apology.
Dr Mead was responding, I gather, to a term of reference which suggested that the aim should be:

. . . establishing better professional relationships between home birth practitioners and the medical profession, and of establishing better relationships between families and support people in the medical profession.
I can only say that I believe she has failed dismally. The next terms of reference are:
To develop principles for alternate birth practice, in and out of hospital. To look at criteria for education of homebirth midwives. Report to the Women's Health Committee.

The results of this report are very similar to what was put out by the Women's Health Committee of the New South Wales Health Department and it seems quite extraordinary that there is such a great similarity. I wonder why that is so.

I move now to the birth centres. There is one in Tasmania; one in South Australia; two in New South Wales; and five in Victoria. So, many of them have been established. A recent study of the Royal Women's Hospital in Victoria took at random 30 women who had their babies in the labour ward and 30 women from the birthing centre in that hospital. The study followed through for eight months of pregnancy, and it found that 15-exactly half-of those in birthing centres, who were all well screened patients-indeed, all those patients were meant to have absolutely no risk, no problem at all-needed to be removed to the labour ward. They were taken out of the birthing centre and their delivery was finished in the labour ward. All of those who were removed had a healthy baby as a result. The Committee's report goes on:
Over the last two decades obstetric care has become more interventionalist and the birthing process is well entrenched in a traditional medical model.

It says that in response to this demands by women for a more sensitive birthing environment are increasing. I will go into what has occurred over the last two decades when obstetric care has become more interventionalist and the birthing process has been well entrenched in a traditional medical model. Between 1961 and 1965, neonatal deaths-that is, deaths between birth and four weeks-totalled 3,260. Between 1966 and 1970 that figure dropped to 3,141. Between 1971 and 1975 the figure dropped to 2,930. Between 1976 and 1980 it dropped to 1,869 and between 1981 and 1985 it dropped to 1,481. So with the intervention of the medical profession, the figure has dropped in those two decades from 3,260 to 1,481. I doubt whether anyone would be critical of that. Foetal death figures have been recorded only since the 1973 to 1975 period. Between 1973 and 1975 there were 2,751 deaths. Between 1976 and 1980 the figure was 1,980 and between 1981 and 1985 it was 1,628. In respect of maternal deaths the situation is even more dramatic. Between 1961 and 1965 there were 81 maternal deaths. Between 1966 and 1970 there were 54. Between 1968 and 1970 there were 50, and from 1971 to 1975 there were 31. From 1976 to 1980 there were 20. From 1981 to 1985 there were 19 on average. In 1986 there were only 15.

Intervention by the medical profession in delivery of babies has increased and has obviously resulted in far better and far safer deliveries and better baby health than if that intervention had not occurred. There has been no consultation between the Committee and the Royal Australian College of Obstetricians and Gynaecologists, even though two obstetricians were on that Committee. The other thing that really surprised me was that in the whole report there was absolutely no mention of morbidity. Morbidity relates just to the general health of the patient. Mortality relates to death, but morbidity relates to general health. There is nothing at all in this report that points to morbidity, which is often an even greater issue in home births than mortality. The report said:

All available evidence suggests that in carefully selected and well supervised low-risk deliveries the extra risk to mother and baby attributed only to the absence of hospital facilities must be low and the satisfaction of a successful delivery high.

However, a number of reports were not included in the list in the appendixes. I wondered why that was so. I wondered whether the reading list was rather selective. The figures for birth profile from the Home Birth Association points out, as I said, that in 1986 there were 1,068 home births, which is 0.44 per cent of all births. Registered midwives delivered 944, lay midwives 62 and doctors 62. Transfers to the hospital represented, amongst the registered midwives, 9.6 per cent. The figure for lay midwives climbed to 12.1 per cent, and for doctors delivering at home 2.4 per cent had to be transferred to hospitals. This points out that lay midwives have a rather bad reputation in this area.

Another thing that concerned me considerably was the type of selection that occurred. In the report by the National Health and Medical Research Council there was no comment on the selection of patients already delivered at home. The delivery characteristics stated that, in 1986, 18 vaginal births were recorded as having occurred after the patient had had a caesarean section. I would have thought that no midwife-whether she be a registered midwife or a lay midwife-and certainly no doctor would suggest that a women should have a home birth following a previous caesarean section. The risks are far too great.

I will only touch on a few of the recommendations of the Committee. There would be no argument with the majority of them. The principles of safe home births that have been gone into suggest that there should be very strict screening. Only those mothers who have a clear bill of health and medical history should have home deliveries. However, the Committee states that to develop a single definitive set of guidelines is not feasible, given the differing environments in which home births and birthing centres may operate and the difficulty of obtaining adequate scientific evidence properly to justify such a definitive set of guidelines. Indeed, the Committee is not able to put down any guidelines to say that it is really safe for a woman to have a home birth. There are no statistics to prove that it is safe to have a home birth. The Committee obviously has thrown its hands in the air and said, `Because we can't prove anything, we have no statistics, and we do not have any method of giving definitive guidelines as to who should and who should not be looked after at home, we will leave it to the doctor, the midwife or the lay midwife to make that decision'.

Every honourable senator would know that we have had some tragic results. Just recently there was the very tragic death of a baby who was delivered at home. The baby was born underwater and subsequently died. The Committee recommends that there be an alteration to the Poisons Act to allow the midwife to administer a number of drugs. There is no suggestion that pethidine or morphia be allowed to be given. Yet there is a suggestion that neonatal naloxone be allowed to be carried and given. This is used only to reverse the effect that pethidine would have on the baby following the administration of that drug to the mother. I am not sure who the Committee thinks would give the pethidine if the nurse is not permitted to give it, yet she is permitted to give a drug that reverses its effects on the baby.

The Committee must understand that if it brings down a recommendation that, no matter how gently, supports home births, without any substantial data-indeed, without any data at all-and without any substantial reasons as to why it should advocate home births, it cannot resile from the responsibility for additional decisions being made by women which could well result in similar tragedies to that which we witnessed the other day. As a nurse, I have seen how some of the emergencies can occur. There is no way that if one has a baby at home and there is a prolapsed cord, for instance, one could be removed from the home situation to the hospital in time to have a caesarean. The only way this can be remedied is for the attending doctor to push the baby back while the mother is taken, as speedily as possible, to the operating theatre, where a caesarean is performed. This is the only way one can possibly save the baby's life. It is very obvious that this sort of thing cannot be done at home. There is no way that the baby's life could be saved. Such an occurrence cannot be anticipated. It can happen to any mother who is perfectly healthy. No matter how many normal babies she has previously had, it can happen at any time. It is one of those risks that are completely unforeseeable. The National Health and Medical Research Council, with its reputation, has brought down a report that I believe is totally irresponsible, particularly when the Council is not prepared to substantiate its statements with figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —In view of the hour, I will not keep the Senate long, but I do wish to raise the issue of Fiji, which is causing me deep concern. I refer to what is happening in Fiji, the inability of the Australian Government to respond in any constructive way to it and the fact that this Government appears to be burying its head in the sand rather than facing up to its responsibility. Those in Australia who treasure our basic human and political rights must be deeply concerned about events in Fiji and the deprivation of such rights being experienced by so many Fijian citizens.

SPEECH.PARA: I suggest tonight that it is time we received a considered response from a number of Government Ministers to matters within their respective spheres of responsibility. Australia and Fiji are part of this one region and, therefore, not only should we be looking compassionately at those who are suffering as a result of the destruction of democracy in our neighbouring country but also we should be addressing constructively the question of how we can help.

The first aspect of the matter that I wish to raise concerns allegations of torture and human rights abuses which are continuing to come to our attention. Mr President, you will be aware that the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade of this country, Mr Hayden, apparently saw the foreign affairs spokesman of the Rabuka regime in Sydney earlier this week. We understand that he presented to that spokesman a list of alleged human rights abuses which had been prepared and given to him by the Australian Council for Overseas Aid. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard that list of abuses, which is not a long list, but only one and a half pages, reported to the Australian Council for Overseas Aid.
Leave granted.
The list read as follows-

PROCTEXT.PARA: Reported instances of human rights abuse.
A. Labasa
1. JAMUNA PRASAD (Administrative Officer): human excrement placed in hands and made to walk naked on the streets after being released.
2. BHARAT BHUSAN (Dental Assistant): made to bath in sewerage pool.
3. MARY SCHRAHM (Medical Superintendent): made to bath in sewerage pool.
4. SAHU KHAN (Magistrate): forced to bath in sewerage pool.
5. RAVIND SINGH (Sheriff): forced to bath in sewerage pool.
6. SUBRAMANI (Farmer): forced to bath in sewerage pool and kept in it for a further 4 hours.
7. SUGRIM SINGH (Farmer): forced to bath in sewerage pool and kept in it for several hours.
8. MUTTHU SAMI (President, FPSA, Labasa): kept under stressful conditions that triggered a heart attack. Has been hospitalised after release.
9. SOHAM SINGH (Proprietor): forced to walk barefoot for several hours on hot tarsealed road.
10. ARUN KUMAR (Taxi Driver): forced to walk barefoot for several hours on hot tarsealed road.
11. WAHID ALI (retired School Teacher): forced to fill a drum full of sand with a small cup. Mr Wahid's left arm had been amputated several years ago.
12. LATCHMI CHAND (Farmer): forced to swim in sewerage pond and beaten.
13. BOB VITHAK (Pharmacist): forced to bath in sewerage pond.
14. KAMPTA PRASAS (Bailiff): forced to bath in sewerage pond.
15. SANTA RAM (Doctor): forced to bath in sewerage pool, and is now suffering from psychological after-effects.
B. Suva
1. VIJAY NAIDU (Lecturer): brutally bashed up while under detention.
2. RICHARD NAIDU (Coalition Spokesman): brutally bashed up while under detention.
3. SOHAN SINGH (Lawyer): assaulted while being arrested and bashed up while in custody.
C. Children
The following incidents of torture have resulted from alleged cases of violation of the Sunday Restrictions.

1. BA: 17 children between ages 5 to 12 were arrested by security forces for violating Sunday restrictions. They were all stripped and corporal punishment was inflicted to an extent that they could no longer stand up. They were then made to rub their noses against a course concrete floor until their noses bled.

2. NAUSORI: a group of children arrested for the same offence were made to lick cowdung (fresh) and corporal punishment was inflicted upon them. Other humiliating punishment was also given to these children.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator HILL

TALK.START.PARA: —It is of regret to me that, after those discussions, our Foreign Minister was not prepared to make any statement about his discussions, let alone a statement concerning these alleged human rights abuses, which are really quite revolting. Many of them concern persons apparently being made to bathe, to stand and to swim in sewage pools for considerable lengths of time. There are also allegations of bashings, assaults and other brutalities. I would have thought that we would hear afterwards from our Foreign Minister the reaction of the Fijian spokesman to such a list. What we should also have heard from our Foreign Minister is whether in the opinion of this Government such allegations are well founded.

INTERJECT.PARA: I remind the Senate that our Government has intelligence facilities within Fiji, although they were found wanting, having not been able to predict either of the two coups that occurred in that country. Nevertheless, they exist. We have a continuing diplomatic presence there. I would like to know, the Australian Council for Overseas Aid would like to know, and I know that many of my colleagues in this place would like to know, whether these allegations of most horrific abuses that are said to be occurring in Fiji are in fact true. I understand that Australian authorities in Fiji have brought them to the attention of the Fijian authorities. Again we do not know the response but the mere fact that this matter was brought to the attention of the Fijian authorities would suggest that there is some evidence to suggest that the allegations are well founded.

If that is the case, I would like to know what further efforts the Australian Government is making diplomatically or in other ways to exert pressure on the Fijian authorities to desist from such abhorrent practices. Furthermore, if these allegations are true I would also like to know whether Australia would consider accepting, under a humanitarian category, applications for immigration from those who are physically or mentally suffering as a result of such abuses or who can substantiate the well founded fear that they are likely to suffer from such abuses. As part of this region and having a responsibility to those who are suffering within the region, that is the sort of question the Australian Government should be addressing rather than simply burying its head in the sand. I would like to hear its reaction to that suggestion.

The second area of concern I raise is the effect of what is happening on children in Fiji and the education of those children. Even apart from the human rights abuses which are alleged, it is clear that about half of the population of Fiji-that is the Indians-will have reduced political rights which will be based on an assessment of race alone under any new arrangement that might follow. Presuming that the loss of political rights or the granting of lesser political rights on a determination of race alone is abhorrent to this Government, I ask: Will the Government at least increase the quotas allowable for private students from Fiji to undertake schooling in this country? This would at least provide some comfort to parents who reasonably desire their children to have the opportunity to study in a peaceful environment.

Two months ago I wrote to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) making this suggestion and I received a reply only today. Basically, the reply is to the effect that the Government will not give further consideration to the matter on the basis of the political events that have occurred in Fiji. He mentioned that there has been a slight increase in the number of places allocated to Fijians but that that is based on factors entirely irrelevant to this matter. In the circumstances of what has happened in Fiji, I believe that the Minister should now be considering whether we in this country can allow further school children to come here in order that they might complete their education in a much more satisfactory environment. I urge him to consider positively that suggestion.

The third area of concern is in relation to tourist visas. I was told only last night of a teacher who was refused a tourist visa to visit this country during the Christmas period without any reason being given. What disturbed me particularly was a suggestion that the Australian Government is generally refusing to give tourist visas to teachers and public servants on the basis that, in any event, they would be stopped at the airport from leaving Fiji, according to apparent current practice of the Fijian authorities. If that allegation is true, the Australian Government is facilitating what are obviously intolerable practices of the Rabuka regime, and that would cause me great concern. I would like to know what are the facts. I was even told today that tourist visas, even in a broader sense, simply are not given by Australia in Fiji. I would like an assurance that such a situation is not the case and that the basis for granting tourist visas has not changed since the coup. If it has changed I would like to know how it has changed. Surely we can grant tourist visas on the merits notwithstanding what has happened in that country.

The last area of concern I raise is that of immigration. Like other senators I have received many allegations of delays in the processing of applications and practices of authorities which, it is suggested, are designed to frustrate the orderly processing of applications for migration to this country. I even received one letter on 19 October advising that Suva `has stopped giving out application forms'. I would like an assurance that that is not the case. I have other letters in which applicants claim that the Australian authorities are telling them that there is a processing time of 12 to 18 months. I would like an assurance that this also is not true. I would like an assurance that applications for migration are being handed out and that they are being dealt with expeditiously and on merit. It is of further concern to me that I am told that there has not been any increase in the immigration staff in Fiji since the coup notwithstanding what has been obviously a great increase in the number of Indian Fijians seeking to leave that country. That causes me concern because it suggests to me that if this Government were acting in the best interests of the Fijian community it would facilitate these extra applications rather than create a bottleneck. Is it in fact the intention of this Government to create a bottleneck? I would like an assurance that that is not the case.

As Australia is a member of this region, one which recognises the importance of maintaining stability within the region, and we appreciate the value of democratic principles, I urge the Government to get its head out of the sand on this issue and face up to its responsibilities in the areas I have raised.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baume Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —When Australia lost the America's Cup early this year the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) was not the only person to lose money on the venture; many Australians lost money, some without realising it. In fact, all of us lost money inadvertently because Australia Post decided to gamble on the outcome. Australia Post's gamble involved printing 35 million stamps on which a victory sign was later printed over them. The stamps used were existing America's Cup stamps on issue. The art work involved in converting those stamps consisted of putting an overprint of the victory sign on them. Thirty-five million stamps represents about a two weeks supply.

SPEECH.PARA: The total cost of producing, overprinting, perforating, packaging and, ultimately, destroying those stamps, was $120,000. I wonder why on earth Australia Post found any sound commercial reason for printing $120,000 worth of stamps on the off-chance that we would win the America's Cup. It is a bet to nothing. What commercial advantage would Australia Post have from printing America's Cup stamps with the V for victory overprint? I wonder why it provided a two weeks supply of them. Doing this sort of thing in advance may be seen by someone in Australia Post as a great public relations coup, but it seems to me to be an extraordinary one which cost the Australian public money.

At a time when Australia Post was going around closing 105 small community local post office agencies, because it said they were uneconomic, it seems strange that $120,000 should be gambled away in this fashion. I wonder how many of those 105 local post office agencies could have been kept open at less than the cost of destroying 35 million stamps. I draw this matter to the attention of the Senate as another example of one of our governmental monopolies having very little care, very little concern for the real needs of Australian consumers and acting in a way which may have given some potential for pleasure to some of the administrators of Australia Post. It certainly gave no pleasure whatsoever to the taxpayers of Australia.

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following answer to a question was circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What measures are currently in place regarding the Federal Police in the control of prostitution and drug dealing in the A.C.T. and the N.T.
(2) How many prosecutions for violations of Acts affecting prostitution and drug dealing in the two Territories were effected in (a) 1985-86; and (b) 1986-87.
(3) Has the Federal Government issued any instruction to police in either Territory to contain rather than eliminate massage parlours or escort agencies.
(4) Has, to the knowledge of the Government, the Federal Police delivered such instructions from senior officers to junior ranks.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Australian Federal Police (AFP) is responsible for enforcing laws relating to prostitution and illicit drug dealings in the A.C.T. only. The force has no responsibility for law enforcement in the Northern Territory other than for Commonwealth law. Consequently, the information provided below relates only to the A.C.T.
(1) The offences relating to prostitution in the A.C.T. are contained in the Police Offences Ordinance 1930 at Sections 18, 19, 19A, 23 and 34.

The Ordinance is explicit in creating offences for managing or being knowingly concerned in the management of a brothel and knowingly permitting or leasing premises to be a brothel. Accordingly, the AFP has standing internal instructions to investigate their operation with a view to obtaining evidence for prosecution. The very nature of the offences, proof of which requires detail of privately arranged transactions of sexual activity in exchange for the payment of money, does present police with difficulties in obtaining evidence sufficient to instigate successful prosecutions.

Section 19B of the Ordinance provides that a prosecution for an offence under the Ordinance is not to be instituted without the consent of the Attorney-General or a person authorised by him. For these purposes the Attorney-General has authorised the Director of Public Prosecutions (DPP) to consent. When determining whether to prosecute, the DPP firstly considers whether the available evidence establishes a prima facie case and secondly whether the public interest requires a prosecution.

In 1985-86, the AFP submitted one brief of evidence to the DPP for consent to prosecute. In 1986-87, three briefs of evidence were submitted. Consent to prosecute was granted in relation to two premises; one resulting in a conviction and one yet to be finalised at court. In the other two referrals consent was refused, one on grounds relative to the evidence and a procedural delay, and the other on the grounds that the prosecution was not considered by the DPP to be necessary in the public interest.

Legislation regulating drug related crime in the A.C.T. is contained in the Poisons and Dangerous Drugs Ordinance 1987. Under the Ordinance, the offences relating to `drug dealing' are supplying a controlled substance and possessing a controlled substance for the purpose of supply.

As well as action to enforce the legislation generally, the AFP A.C.T. Command Drug Squad has recently initiated a system of target policing directed specifically at individuals suspected of being major drug dealers within the Territory. This system of policing has led to the arrest of persons of greater significance in the organisation of illegal drug activities in the A.C.T.
(2) (a) Prostitution-one; Drug dealing-79; (b) Prostitution-one; Drug dealing-48.
